title: Contracts
description: Contracts flashcards for bar exam prep

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 001. Contract Requirements
cards.backPlain: 1. In General: A contract is a promise or set of promises enforced by law; a legally enforceable agreement. 2. Requirements to form a valid contract: A contract is formed when there exists: 2.1 Mutual assent: A meeting of the minds, demonstrated by an offer and valid acceptance, determined by the parties' objective (not subjective) manifestations of assent. 2.2 Consideration: A bargained-for exchange of legal value between the parties. 2.3 No defenses to contract formation: No defenses to formation exist that would invalidate the contract. 3. Void, voidable, and unenforceable contracts: If there is a valid defense to contract formation or enforcement, a contract may become: 3.1 Void: The contract never had any legal effect. 3.2 Voidable: One or both parties may elect to void the contract. 3.3 Unenforceable: An otherwise valid contract that is unenforceable because a defense applies (e.g., incapacity, Statute of Frauds).
cards.frontPrompt: What are the basic requirements to form a valid contract, and how do void, voidable, and unenforceable contracts differ?
cards.cloze: 1. In General: A {{c1::contract}} is a {{c2::promise or set of promises enforced by law}}; a {{c3::legally enforceable agreement}}. 2. Requirements to form a valid contract: A contract is formed when there exists: 2.1 {{c4::Mutual assent}}: A {{c5::meeting of the minds}}, demonstrated by an {{c6::offer and valid acceptance}}, determined by the parties' {{c7::objective (not subjective) manifestations of assent}}. 2.2 {{c8::Consideration}}: A {{c9::bargained-for exchange of legal value}} between the parties. 2.3 {{c10::No defenses to contract formation}}: No defenses to formation exist that would invalidate the contract. 3. {{c11::Void, voidable, and unenforceable contracts}}: If there is a valid defense to contract formation or enforcement, a contract may become: 3.1 {{c12::Void}}: The contract {{c13::never had any legal effect}}. 3.2 {{c14::Voidable}}: {{c15::One or both parties may elect to void}} the contract. 3.3 {{c16::Unenforceable}}: An otherwise valid contract that is {{c17::unenforceable because a defense applies}} (e.g., {{c18::incapacity, Statute of Frauds}}).
cards.easyContent: A contract is a legally enforceable agreement formed by mutual assent and consideration, with no valid defenses to formation; contracts may be void, voidable, or unenforceable depending on applicable defenses.
cards.mediumContent: A contract is a promise or set of promises that the law will enforce. To form a valid contract, there must be (1) mutual assent—a meeting of the minds shown by offer and valid acceptance based on the parties’ objective manifestations—and (2) consideration—a bargained-for exchange of legal value—plus (3) no defenses to formation. If a defense applies, the agreement may be void (no legal effect), voidable (a party may elect to avoid it), or unenforceable (otherwise valid but not enforceable due to a defense such as incapacity or Statute of Frauds).
cards.hardContent: A contract is a promise or set of promises that the law recognizes as creating a duty and will enforce—a legally enforceable agreement. A valid contract requires: (1) mutual assent, meaning a meeting of the minds evidenced by an offer and a valid acceptance, judged by the parties’ objective, not subjective, manifestations; (2) consideration, meaning a bargained-for exchange of legal value between the parties; and (3) the absence of any defenses to contract formation. If a defense to formation or enforcement applies, the agreement may be classified as (a) void, having no legal effect from the outset; (b) voidable, where one or both parties may elect to avoid the contract; or (c) unenforceable, where the contract is otherwise valid but cannot be enforced because a defense applies, such as incapacity or failure to satisfy the Statute of Frauds.
cards.mnemonic: MAC-D: Mutual Assent, Consideration, no Defenses.
cards.clozeLite: A valid {{c1::contract}} requires {{c2::mutual assent}}, {{c3::consideration}}, and {{c4::no defenses to formation}}; defenses can make it {{c5::void, voidable, or unenforceable}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 002. Types of Contracts
cards.backPlain: 1. Bilateral contract: 1.1. Exchange of mutual promises. 1.2. Each party is both a promisor and a promisee. 1.3. Example: A offers to sell his car to B for $5,000 and B promises to purchase A's car at that price. 2. Unilateral contract: 2.1. Offer requires performance as the manner of acceptance. 2.2. Offeror–promisor agrees to pay upon completion of the act requested by the promisee; once the act is completed, the contract is formed. 2.3. Example: A promises to pay B $100 if B paints A's fence; B is not obligated to paint A's fence, but if B does, a contract is formed and A must pay B $100. 3. Quasi-contract (restitution / unjust enrichment): 3.1. Not a contract, but a restitution remedy designed to prevent unjust enrichment. 3.2. An implied-in-law obligation arises when there is an unenforceable or non-existent agreement, but one side has realized a benefit. 3.3. Elements: (a) P has conferred a benefit on D; (b) P reasonably expects to be paid; (c) D knowingly accepted the benefit; and (d) D will be unjustly enriched if P is not compensated.
cards.frontPrompt: What are bilateral contracts, unilateral contracts, and quasi-contracts, and how do they differ?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Bilateral contract}}: 1.1. Exchange of {{c2::mutual promises}}. 1.2. Each party is both a {{c3::promisor and a promisee}}. 1.3. Example: A offers to sell his car to B for $5,000 and B promises to purchase A's car at that price. 2. {{c4::Unilateral contract}}: 2.1. Offer requires {{c5::performance as the manner of acceptance}}. 2.2. Offeror–promisor agrees to pay upon {{c6::completion of the act requested by the promisee}}; once the act is completed, the contract is formed. 2.3. Example: A promises to pay B $100 if B paints A's fence; B is not obligated to paint A's fence, but if B does, a contract is formed and A must pay B $100. 3. {{c7::Quasi-contract}} ({{c8::restitution / unjust enrichment}}): 3.1. Not a contract, but a {{c9::restitution remedy designed to prevent unjust enrichment}}. 3.2. An {{c10::implied-in-law obligation}} arises when there is an unenforceable or non-existent agreement, but one side has realized a benefit. 3.3. Elements: (a) P has {{c11::conferred a benefit on D}}; (b) P {{c12::reasonably expects to be paid}}; (c) D {{c13::knowingly accepted the benefit}}; and (d) D will be {{c14::unjustly enriched if P is not compensated}}.
cards.easyContent: Bilateral contracts are formed by an exchange of mutual promises, unilateral contracts by performance of the requested act, and quasi-contract is a restitution remedy to prevent unjust enrichment when there is no enforceable contract.
cards.mediumContent: A bilateral contract is an exchange of mutual promises where each party is both promisor and promisee. A unilateral contract is accepted only by performance of the requested act, and the offeror is bound once performance is completed. A quasi-contract (implied-in-law) is not a true contract but a restitution remedy where P confers a benefit on D, reasonably expects to be paid, D knowingly accepts the benefit, and it would be unjust for D to retain it without payment.
cards.hardContent: A bilateral contract is formed by an exchange of mutual promises, with each party both a promisor and a promisee, such as A promising to sell his car to B for $5,000 and B promising to buy it. A unilateral contract is one where the offer requires performance as the manner of acceptance; the offeror agrees to pay only upon completion of the requested act, and the contract is formed once the act is completed, as when A promises to pay B $100 if B paints A's fence. A quasi-contract (implied-in-law obligation) is not a contract but a restitution remedy to prevent unjust enrichment where there is no enforceable agreement but P has conferred a benefit on D, P reasonably expects to be paid, D knowingly accepts the benefit, and D would be unjustly enriched if P is not compensated.
cards.mnemonic: BUQ: Bilateral=Both promise, Unilateral=Act, Quasi=Unjust enrichment fix.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::bilateral contract}} is an {{c2::exchange of mutual promises}}; a {{c3::unilateral contract}} is accepted only by {{c4::performance of the requested act}}; {{c5::quasi-contract}} is a {{c6::restitution remedy for unjust enrichment}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 003. Applicable Law
cards.backPlain: 1. In general: Most contracts are governed by either common law or the UCC. 1.1. Common law: 1.1.1. Applies to most contracts, except sales of goods. 1.1.2. Any contract not involving the sale of goods should be treated under common law contract principles. 1.1.3. Generally applies to contracts for real estate or services. 2. UCC Article 2: 2.1. Governs the sale of goods. 2.2. If both parties to a contract are merchants, the UCC has additional special rules (e.g., acceptance with additional terms). 3. Mixed contracts: 3.1. For contracts involving both goods and services, the predominant purpose of the contract dictates the applicable law. 3.2. Exception: if contract terms divide payment between the goods and the services, apply the UCC to the sale-of-goods portion of the contract and common law to the remainder. 4. Duty of good faith: 4.1. In both UCC and common law contracts, an obligation of good faith is imposed on the performance and enforcement of a contract.
cards.frontPrompt: How do you determine whether common law or UCC Article 2 applies to a contract, including mixed contracts, and what duty of good faith applies?
cards.cloze: 1. In general: Most contracts are governed by either {{c1::common law}} or the {{c2::UCC}}. 1.1. {{c3::Common law}}: 1.1.1. Applies to most contracts, except {{c4::sales of goods}}. 1.1.2. Any contract not involving the sale of goods should be treated under common law contract principles. 1.1.3. Generally applies to contracts for {{c5::real estate}} or {{c6::services}}. 2. {{c7::UCC Article 2}}: 2.1. Governs the {{c8::sale of goods}}. 2.2. If both parties to a contract are {{c9::merchants}}, the UCC has additional special rules (e.g., acceptance with additional terms). 3. {{c10::Mixed contracts}}: 3.1. For contracts involving both goods and services, the {{c11::predominant purpose}} of the contract dictates the applicable law. 3.2. Exception: if contract terms {{c12::divide payment between the goods and the services}}, apply the UCC to the {{c13::sale-of-goods portion}} of the contract and common law to the {{c14::remainder}}. 4. Duty of {{c15::good faith}}: 4.1. In both UCC and common law contracts, an obligation of good faith is imposed on the {{c16::performance and enforcement}} of a contract.
cards.easyContent: Common law governs contracts for services and real estate, while UCC Article 2 governs sales of goods. Mixed contracts use the predominant purpose test, and both systems impose a duty of good faith in performance and enforcement.
cards.mediumContent: Common law applies to contracts that do not involve the sale of goods, typically services and real estate. UCC Article 2 governs contracts for the sale of goods, with special provisions when both parties are merchants. For mixed goods-and-services contracts, the predominant purpose controls, unless the contract allocates separate prices, in which case UCC applies to the goods portion and common law to the rest. Under both regimes, parties owe a duty of good faith in performing and enforcing contracts.
cards.hardContent: To determine applicable law, first ask whether the contract is for a sale of goods; if so, UCC Article 2 applies, and additional special rules may apply when both parties are merchants (e.g., acceptance with additional terms). If the contract does not involve goods, common law governs, typically for real estate or services. For mixed contracts involving both goods and services, use the predominant purpose test to decide whether UCC or common law governs overall, unless the contract specifies separate payments for goods and services, in which case Article 2 governs the sale-of-goods portion and common law governs the remainder. In all contracts, whether under UCC or common law, the parties have an obligation of good faith in the performance and enforcement of the agreement.
cards.mnemonic: G-SPLIT: Goods–Sale–Predominant, Law–If–Terminated (split prices).
cards.clozeLite: Common law governs {{c1::services and real estate}}; {{c2::UCC Article 2}} governs {{c3::sales of goods}}. Mixed contracts use the {{c4::predominant purpose test}}; both require {{c5::good-faith performance and enforcement}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 004. Offer
cards.backPlain: An offer is an objective manifestation of a present intent to contract such that a reasonable offeree would believe the communication invites acceptance. It is typically shown by a promise, undertaking, or commitment with sufficiently definite and certain terms, communicated to an identified offeree who knows of it and has the power to accept. Courts assess offers using a reasonable person standard and distinguish true offers from vague negotiations or invitations to deal such as most advertisements. For sales of goods under UCC Article 2, a certain or ascertainable quantity term is the key requirement, while many other terms (including price) may be left open if the parties intended to contract and there is a reasonably certain basis for granting a remedy.
cards.frontPrompt: What is an offer in contract law at a high level, and how do common law and the UCC frame its key requirements?
cards.cloze: An offer is an {{c1::objective manifestation of a present intent to contract}} such that a {{c2::reasonable offeree}} would believe the communication {{c3::invites acceptance}}. It requires {{c4::definite and certain terms}} and {{c5::communication to an identified offeree}}. Under {{c6::UCC Article 2}}, the key requirement is a certain or {{c7::ascertainable quantity term}}, while many other terms (including {{c8::price}}) may be left open if the parties {{c9::intended to contract}} and there is a {{c10::reasonably certain basis for a remedy}}.
cards.easyContent: An offer is an objective, reasonable-person signal that someone is presently willing to contract on certain terms, communicated to a specific offeree. Under the UCC, the main required term is quantity; many other terms can be left open if the parties intended a binding deal and a remedy can be fashioned.
cards.mediumContent: An offer is an objective manifestation of present intent to contract that would lead a reasonable offeree to believe the communication invites acceptance. It typically consists of a promise, undertaking, or commitment with definite and certain terms, communicated to an identified offeree. Courts use a reasonable person standard to distinguish real offers from preliminary negotiations, and most advertisements are only invitations to deal. Under UCC Article 2, a certain or ascertainable quantity term is required (including in requirement and output contracts), but other terms such as price may be missing if the parties intended to contract and there is a reasonably certain basis for granting a remedy.
cards.hardContent: An offer is an objective manifestation of a present intent to contract such that a reasonable offeree would believe the communication invites acceptance. It is usually evidenced by a promise, undertaking, or commitment, with sufficiently definite and certain terms—like quantity, time for performance, and price—so that a court can enforce the agreement, and it must be communicated to an identified offeree who knows of it and has the legal power to accept. Courts apply a reasonable person standard to separate true offers from mere preliminaries or negotiations, and most advertisements are treated as invitations to deal rather than offers unless they are highly specific and clearly identify who may accept. Under UCC Article 2, the critical requirement is a certain or ascertainable quantity term; in requirement and output contracts, unreasonably disproportionate increases in quantity are barred. Other terms, particularly price, may be left open so long as the parties clearly intended to make a contract and there is a reasonably certain basis for supplying missing terms and granting a remedy.
cards.mnemonic: Offer = PIC: Present intent, Identified offeree, Clear terms; UCC needs Quantity.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into three children: (1) definition and core elements of an offer, (2) objective intent and advertisements, (3) UCC-specific offer rules including quantity and gap-fillers.
cards.clozeLite: An {{c1::offer}} is an {{c2::objective manifestation of present intent to contract}} that would lead a {{c3::reasonable offeree}} to believe the communication {{c4::invites acceptance}}; under the {{c5::UCC Article 2}} the key required term is {{c6::quantity}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 005. Termination of Offer
cards.backPlain: 1. In general: An offer may be terminated by an act of a party or by operation of law. 2. Acts of parties: 2.1. Revocation by offeror. 2.2. Rejection by offeree. 2.3. Lapse of time. 2.4. The offeror can set a time limit for acceptance, at the end of which the offeree's power of acceptance automatically terminates. 3. Operation of law: 3.1. Death or insanity of either party. 3.2. Destruction of the proposed contract's subject matter. 3.3. Supervening illegality.
cards.frontPrompt: How can an offer be terminated, both by acts of the parties and by operation of law?
cards.cloze: 1. In general: An offer may be terminated by an {{c1::act of a party}} or by {{c2::operation of law}}. 2. Acts of parties: 2.1. {{c3::Revocation}} by the offeror. 2.2. {{c4::Rejection}} by the offeree. 2.3. {{c5::Lapse of time}}. 2.4. The offeror can set a {{c6::time limit for acceptance}}, at the end of which the offeree's {{c7::power of acceptance}} automatically terminates. 3. Operation of law: 3.1. {{c8::Death or insanity}} of either party. 3.2. {{c9::Destruction of the proposed contract's subject matter}}. 3.3. {{c10::Supervening illegality}}.
cards.easyContent: An offer can end either by party action—revocation, rejection, or lapse of time—or automatically by operation of law, such as death or insanity, destruction of the subject matter, or supervening illegality.
cards.mediumContent: An offer terminates if a party revokes it, the offeree rejects it, or it lapses after the time stated (or a reasonable time). The offeror may specify an acceptance deadline, after which the offeree's power of acceptance automatically ends. Independently, operation of law terminates an offer upon death or insanity of either party, destruction of the contract's subject matter, or supervening illegality of the proposed contract.
cards.hardContent: Termination of an offer can occur through party action or by operation of law. By party action, an offer ends when the offeror revokes, the offeree rejects, or the offer lapses after the stated or a reasonable time; the offeror may set a specific time limit for acceptance, and once that period ends, the offeree's power of acceptance automatically terminates. By operation of law, an offer is terminated by the death or insanity of either party, destruction of the proposed contract's subject matter, or a change in the law that makes the proposed contract illegal.
cards.mnemonic: Termination by PRL + DDI: Party action (Revocation, Rejection, Lapse) or Death, Destruction, Illegality.
cards.clozeLite: An offer ends by {{c1::party action}}—{{c2::revocation, rejection, or lapse}}—or by {{c3::operation of law}} like {{c4::death, destruction, or illegality}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 006. Revoking Offers and Irrevocable Offers
cards.front: Revoking Offers and Irrevocable Offers – Overview
cards.backPlain: Revocation terminates an offer and the offeree's power of acceptance. It generally occurs when the offeror clearly indicates an unwillingness or inability to contract, and this is communicated to the offeree. Revocation is effective only upon receipt and is no longer possible once the offer is accepted. Some offers are irrevocable. Irrevocability can arise in unilateral contracts once performance begins, under option contracts supported by consideration, under UCC firm offers (merchant’s signed writings assuring the offer will be held open), and when the offeree reasonably and detrimentally relies on the offer. These doctrines limit the offeror’s ability to revoke.
cards.frontPrompt: What is revocation of an offer, when is it effective, and what are the main categories of irrevocable offers?
cards.cloze: Revocation {{c1::terminates an offer}} and the offeree's {{c2::power of acceptance}}. It generally requires a {{c3::clear indication}} by the offeror of an unwillingness or inability to contract that is {{c4::communicated to the offeree}} and is effective only upon {{c5::receipt}}. Once an offer is {{c6::accepted}}, it can no longer be revoked. Some offers are {{c7::irrevocable}}, including those in {{c8::unilateral contracts once performance begins}}, {{c9::option contracts with consideration}}, {{c10::UCC firm offers}}, and offers on which the offeree has {{c11::reasonably and detrimentally relied}}.
cards.easyContent: Revocation ends an offer and the offeree’s power to accept, and is effective only when received and before acceptance. Some offers are irrevocable, including unilateral offers once performance begins, option contracts with consideration, UCC firm offers, and offers reasonably and detrimentally relied on.
cards.mediumContent: Revocation occurs when the offeror clearly indicates an unwillingness or inability to contract, and this is communicated to the offeree. It terminates the offer and the offeree’s power of acceptance and is effective only upon receipt; once accepted, an offer can no longer be revoked. Offers can be made irrevocable in several ways: (1) unilateral contracts become irrevocable for a reasonable time once performance (beyond mere preparation) begins; (2) option contracts supported by consideration; (3) UCC firm offers—merchant’s signed writings assuring the offer will be held open, irrevocable for the time stated or up to three months if none is stated; and (4) reasonable detrimental reliance by the offeree.
cards.hardContent: Revocation is the offeror’s withdrawal of an offer, which terminates both the offer and the offeree’s power of acceptance. It generally requires an unambiguous indication of unwillingness or inability to contract that is communicated to the offeree and is only effective upon receipt. After acceptance, revocation is no longer possible. Several doctrines restrict revocation by making offers irrevocable: (a) in unilateral contracts, the offeree’s commencement of performance (beyond mere preparation) renders the offer irrevocable for a reasonable time to complete performance; (b) an option contract—a separate promise to keep an offer open—must be supported by consideration at common law and under the UCC when the firm-offer rule does not apply; (c) a UCC firm offer arises when a merchant makes an offer in a signed writing that gives assurances it will be held open, making it irrevocable for the time stated, or if none is stated, for a reasonable time not exceeding three months; and (d) reasonable and detrimental reliance by the offeree can render an offer irrevocable.
cards.mnemonic: Irrevocable offers = UDOF: Unilateral, Detrimental reliance, Option, Firm offer.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into four children: (1) methods and timing of revocation; (2) unilateral contracts and start of performance; (3) option contracts and UCC firm offers; (4) detrimental reliance as a basis for irrevocability.
cards.clozeLite: Revocation {{c1::terminates the offer and offeree’s power to accept}} and is {{c2::only effective when received}}. Offers are irrevocable for {{c3::begun unilateral performance}}, {{c4::option contracts with consideration}}, {{c5::UCC firm offers}}, and {{c6::reasonable detrimental reliance}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 007. Rejection of Offer
cards.backPlain: 1. In General 1.1. A rejection by the offeree terminates the offer and the offeree's power of acceptance. 1.2. Main methods of rejection: - Express rejection (direct saying "no" to the offer). - Counteroffer (substituting a new offer for the original). - Conditional acceptance ("I accept, if/only if..."—usually a new offer). - Acceptance with additional terms (treated differently under common law vs. UCC Article 2). 2. Overview of Methods 2.1. Express rejection is effective when received by the offeror. 2.2. A counteroffer or conditional acceptance normally terminates the original offer and becomes a new offer; mere bargaining or requests for information do not. 2.3. Under common law, acceptance must mirror the offer (mirror-image rule), so additional or different terms are a rejection and counteroffer. 2.4. Under the UCC, the effect of additional terms depends on whether the parties are merchants and on specific exceptions.
cards.frontPrompt: How does a rejection by the offeree terminate the offer and what are the main methods of rejection (express rejection, counteroffer, conditional acceptance, and acceptance with additional terms under common law and the UCC)?
cards.cloze: 1. In General 1.1. A {{c1::rejection by the offeree terminates the offer and the offeree's power of acceptance}}. 1.2. Main methods of rejection: - {{c2::Express rejection}}. - {{c3::Counteroffer}}. - {{c4::Conditional acceptance}}. - {{c5::Acceptance with additional terms (common law vs. UCC)}}. 2. Overview of Methods 2.1. Express rejection is {{c6::effective when received}} by the offeror. 2.2. A counteroffer or conditional acceptance normally {{c7::terminates the original offer and becomes a new offer}}; mere {{c8::bargaining or requests for information}} do not. 2.3. Under {{c9::common law}}, acceptance must mirror the offer ({{c10::mirror-image rule}}), so additional or different terms are a {{c11::rejection and counteroffer}}. 2.4. Under the {{c12::UCC}}, the effect of additional terms depends on whether the parties are {{c13::merchants}} and on specific exceptions.
cards.easyContent: A rejection by the offeree terminates the offer and the offeree’s power of acceptance. This can happen by express rejection, by making a counteroffer, by giving a conditional acceptance, or by accepting with additional terms (which is treated differently at common law and under the UCC).
cards.mediumContent: A rejection by the offeree terminates the offer and the offeree’s power of acceptance. Key methods: (1) express rejection, effective when received; (2) counteroffer and conditional acceptance, which usually terminate the original offer and become new offers (mere bargaining or information requests are not counteroffers); and (3) acceptance with additional terms—at common law, any additional or different term is a rejection and counteroffer, while under the UCC the effect of additional terms depends on merchant status and specific exceptions.
cards.hardContent: A rejection by the offeree terminates the offer and the offeree’s power of acceptance. Main types of rejection include: (1) express rejection, effective upon receipt; (2) counteroffer and conditional acceptance, which ordinarily terminate the original offer and become new offers (while mere bargaining or requests for information do not); and (3) acceptance with additional terms, which under common law violates the mirror-image rule and operates as a rejection and counteroffer, but under the UCC may still form a contract, with additional terms sometimes becoming part of the contract depending on merchant status and stated exceptions.
cards.mnemonic: R-CAC: Rejection by Counteroffer, Acceptance with terms, Conditional acceptance.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into 4 children: (1) general rule + express rejection, (2) counteroffers vs bargaining, (3) conditional acceptance and its exception, (4) acceptance with additional terms under common law vs UCC (merchant vs non-merchant).
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::rejection by the offeree}} terminates the {{c2::offer and power of acceptance}} by {{c3::express rejection}}, {{c4::counteroffer or conditional acceptance}}, or {{c5::acceptance with additional terms (CL vs UCC)}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 008. Acceptance
cards.backPlain: Acceptance is the offeree’s clear expression of assent to the terms of the offer, in the manner specified by the offeror (who is the master of the offer). At common law, acceptance must mirror the terms of the offer (mirror-image rule). Under the UCC, an acceptance can include additional terms (with different treatment depending on whether the parties are merchants) and, for sales of goods, a merchant may accept by promising to ship or promptly shipping conforming goods; shipment of nonconforming goods usually operates as an acceptance and breach unless clearly offered only as an accommodation.
cards.frontPrompt: What is acceptance of an offer, and how do common-law and UCC rules (including shipment) structure how acceptance operates?
cards.cloze: Acceptance is the offeree’s {{c1::clear expression of assent}} to the terms of the offer, in the manner specified by the {{c2::offeror (master of the offer)}}. At {{c3::common law}}, acceptance must {{c4::mirror the terms of the offer}} (mirror-image rule). Under the {{c5::UCC}}, an acceptance can include {{c6::additional terms}} (with different treatment depending on whether the parties are {{c7::merchants}}), and a {{c8::merchant}} may accept by {{c9::promising to ship}} or {{c10::promptly shipping conforming goods}}; shipment of {{c11::nonconforming goods}} usually operates as an {{c12::acceptance and breach}} unless clearly offered only as an {{c13::accommodation}}.
cards.easyContent: Acceptance is the offeree’s clear assent to the offer on the terms and in the manner the offeror specifies. Common law uses the mirror-image rule. Under the UCC, acceptance can include additional terms and, in sales of goods, merchants can accept by promising to ship or by shipping conforming goods; nonconforming shipments are usually acceptance plus breach unless labeled an accommodation.
cards.mediumContent: Acceptance arises when the offeree clearly assents to the offer, using the mode and manner set by the offeror as master of the offer. At common law, the mirror-image rule requires the acceptance to exactly match the offer’s terms. Under the UCC, an expression of acceptance may include additional terms, with their effect depending on whether the parties are merchants. For sales of goods, a merchant can accept an offer by promising to ship or by promptly shipping conforming goods, while shipment of nonconforming goods generally counts as acceptance plus breach unless the seller seasonably notifies the buyer that the shipment is only an accommodation.
cards.hardContent: Acceptance is the offeree’s clear expression of assent to the terms of the offer, in the manner authorized or specified by the offeror, who is the master of the offer. Under common law, the mirror-image rule requires that acceptance mirror the offer’s terms; any addition, omission, or change is a counteroffer rather than an acceptance. Under the UCC, an expression of acceptance can contain additional terms whose treatment depends on whether both parties are merchants, and in sales of goods a merchant can accept by promising to ship or by promptly shipping conforming goods. Shipment of nonconforming goods normally operates as an acceptance and a breach, unless the seller seasonably notifies the buyer that the shipment is offered only as an accommodation, in which case it is a counteroffer rather than an acceptance.
cards.mnemonic: Mirror vs. Merchants: Common mirrors, UCC flexes and ships.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into three children: (1) general rule and mirror-image rule, (2) UCC acceptance with additional terms (merchant vs non-merchant), (3) acceptance by shipment and nonconforming goods as acceptance plus breach/accommodation.
cards.clozeLite: Acceptance is the offeree’s {{c1::clear assent}} in the {{c2::mode and manner set by the offeror}}. Common law uses the {{c3::mirror-image rule}}; the UCC allows {{c4::additional terms}} and {{c5::acceptance by shipment}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 009. Mailbox Rule
cards.backPlain: 1. In General 1.1. The mailbox rule governs offers and acceptances transmitted via mail or similar non-instantaneous means (it generally does not apply to email or instantaneous communications). 1.2. Offers are effective upon receipt by the offeree. 1.3. Rejections and counteroffers are effective upon receipt by the offeror. 1.4. Acceptances are effective upon dispatch if properly addressed and stamped, unless an exception applies. 2. Method of Communication 2.1. Unless otherwise provided, offers invite acceptance in any reasonable manner under the circumstances. 2.2. Example: A sends an offer to B via email and B accepts via text message; a valid contract has been formed. 2.3. If acceptance is via instantaneous two-way communication (e.g., phone), it is treated as if the parties are in each other's presence, and the mailbox rule does not apply. 3. Limitations on the Mailbox Rule 3.1. If the offer stipulates that acceptance is not effective until received, the offer controls (the offeror can opt out of the mailbox rule). 3.2. If the offeree sends both a rejection and an acceptance, the first communication to arrive controls. 3.3. For option contracts, acceptance is effective upon receipt, not dispatch. 4. Revocation 4.1. Revocation of an offer is effective only upon receipt by the offeree; the mailbox rule does not apply to revocations.
cards.frontPrompt: What does the mailbox rule provide about when offers, acceptances, rejections, and revocations become effective, and what are the main limitations on the rule?
cards.cloze: 1. In General 1.1. The {{c1::mailbox rule}} governs offers and acceptances transmitted via mail or similar non-instantaneous means (it generally does not apply to {{c2::email or instantaneous communications}}). 1.2. {{c3::Offers}} are effective upon {{c4::receipt}} by the offeree. 1.3. {{c5::Rejections and counteroffers}} are effective upon {{c6::receipt}} by the offeror. 1.4. {{c7::Acceptances}} are effective upon {{c8::dispatch}} if properly addressed and stamped, unless an exception applies. 2. Method of Communication 2.1. Unless otherwise provided, offers invite acceptance in any {{c9::reasonable manner under the circumstances}}. 2.2. Example: A sends an offer to B via email and B accepts via text message; a valid contract has been formed. 2.3. If acceptance is via {{c10::instantaneous two-way communication}} (e.g., phone), it is treated as if the parties are in each other's presence, and the mailbox rule does not apply. 3. Limitations on the Mailbox Rule 3.1. If the offer {{c11::stipulates that acceptance is not effective until received}}, the offer controls (the offeror can opt out of the mailbox rule). 3.2. If the offeree sends both a {{c12::rejection and an acceptance}}, the {{c13::first communication to arrive}} controls. 3.3. For {{c14::option contracts}}, acceptance is effective upon {{c15::receipt}}, not dispatch. 4. Revocation 4.1. {{c16::Revocation of an offer}} is effective only upon {{c17::receipt}} by the offeree; the mailbox rule does not apply to revocations.
cards.easyContent: Under the mailbox rule, an acceptance sent by mail is effective when dispatched, while offers, rejections, counteroffers, and revocations are effective when received. The rule does not apply to option contracts, revocations, or when the offeror specifies that acceptance is only effective upon receipt.
cards.mediumContent: The mailbox rule applies to non-instantaneous communications like mail. An offer is effective when received by the offeree; rejections and counteroffers are effective when received by the offeror. An acceptance is effective when it is properly dispatched, unless the offeror specifies otherwise. The rule does not apply to instantaneous communications (e.g., phone calls). Limitations include: the offeror can require receipt to make acceptance effective; if an offeree sends both a rejection and an acceptance, the first to arrive controls; and for option contracts, acceptance is effective only upon receipt. Revocations are always effective only upon receipt by the offeree.
cards.hardContent: The mailbox rule governs timing issues for non-instantaneous communications. Offers become effective when received by the offeree. Rejections and counteroffers become effective when received by the offeror. Acceptances are generally effective upon dispatch if properly addressed and stamped, even if later lost or delayed, unless an exception applies. Unless the offer states otherwise, it invites acceptance in any reasonable manner in light of the circumstances, and acceptance via different but reasonable means (e.g., reply by text to an email offer) can form a valid contract. The rule does not apply to instantaneous two-way communications, which are treated as if the parties are in each other's presence. The main limitations are: (1) the offeror can opt out by stipulating that acceptance is effective only upon receipt; (2) if an offeree sends both a rejection and an acceptance, the communication that arrives first controls; and (3) for option contracts, acceptance is effective only upon receipt, not dispatch. Revocation of an offer is effective only upon receipt by the offeree; the mailbox rule does not apply to revocations.
cards.mnemonic: Think ROAD: Rejection, Offer, and revOcation effective on Arrival; Dispatch makes Acceptance effective.
cards.clozeLite: Under the {{c1::mailbox rule}}, an {{c2::acceptance}} is effective {{c3::on dispatch}}, while {{c4::offers, rejections, counteroffers, and revocations}} are effective {{c5::on receipt}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 010. Acceptance by Performance
cards.backPlain: 1. In General 1.1. Unless acceptance is limited by the terms of the offer, the offeree may accept by partial performance (for bilateral contracts) or complete performance (for unilateral contracts). 2. Unilateral Contracts 2.1. Complete performance is required to accept a unilateral contract. 2.2. The offeree is not obligated to start or complete performance. 2.3. Failure to perform does not give rise to breach because no contract is formed absent complete performance. 2.4. Revocability: Once the offeree begins performance, many courts treat the offer as irrevocable for a reasonable time to allow completion. 2.5. Notice: The offeree is not required to give notice upon the start of performance, but must notify the offeror within a reasonable time upon completion, unless the offeror learns of the performance by other reasonable means or notice is waived. 3. Bilateral Contracts 3.1. Partial performance (or beginning performance) gives rise to acceptance of a bilateral contract. 3.2. The offeree must make the offeror aware of the acceptance, either by performance in the offeror's presence or by reasonable notice. 4. Offers Requiring Acceptance by Promise 4.1. An offer that appears to require acceptance by promise may still be accepted by performance if: 4.1.1. The offeree begins to perform; and 4.1.2. The offeror knows the offeree has begun performance and acquiesces. 4.2. However, an offer may always limit methods of acceptance, in which case the stated method controls.
cards.frontPrompt: When can an offeree accept an offer by performance in unilateral and bilateral contracts, and how do revocability and notice work in acceptance by performance?
cards.cloze: 1. In General 1.1. Unless acceptance is limited by the terms of the offer, the offeree may accept by {{c1::partial performance (for bilateral contracts)}} or {{c2::complete performance (for unilateral contracts)}}. 2. {{c3::Unilateral Contracts}} 2.1. {{c4::Complete performance}} is required to accept a unilateral contract. 2.2. The offeree is {{c5::not obligated to start or complete performance}}. 2.3. Failure to perform does not give rise to breach because {{c6::no contract is formed absent complete performance}}. 2.4. Revocability: Once the offeree {{c7::begins performance}}, many courts treat the offer as {{c8::irrevocable for a reasonable time}} to allow completion. 2.5. Notice: The offeree is not required to give notice upon the start of performance, but must {{c9::notify the offeror within a reasonable time upon completion}}, unless the offeror {{c10::learns of the performance by other reasonable means}} or notice is {{c11::waived}}. 3. {{c12::Bilateral Contracts}} 3.1. {{c13::Partial performance (or beginning performance)}} gives rise to acceptance of a bilateral contract. 3.2. The offeree must {{c14::make the offeror aware of the acceptance}}, either by performance in the offeror's presence or by {{c15::reasonable notice}}. 4. {{c16::Offers Requiring Acceptance by Promise}} 4.1. An offer that appears to require acceptance by promise may still be accepted by performance if: 4.1.1. The offeree {{c17::begins to perform}}; and 4.1.2. The offeror {{c18::knows the offeree has begun performance and acquiesces}}. 4.2. However, an offer may always {{c19::limit methods of acceptance}}, in which case the stated method controls.
cards.easyContent: Unless the offer says otherwise, an offeree can accept by performance: complete performance for unilateral contracts, and beginning performance for bilateral contracts. In unilateral contracts, the offer often becomes temporarily irrevocable once performance begins, and the offeree usually must give notice upon completion.
cards.mediumContent: If the offer does not restrict the mode of acceptance, the offeree may accept by performance. For unilateral contracts, acceptance requires complete performance; failure to perform is not a breach because there is no contract until performance is complete, and once the offeree begins performance the offer generally becomes irrevocable for a reasonable time to allow completion. The offeree typically must give notice of completion within a reasonable time unless the offeror learns of performance otherwise or notice is waived. For bilateral contracts, beginning or part performance creates acceptance, but the offeree must make the offeror aware of that acceptance, either in the offeror’s presence or by reasonable notice. Even if an offer appears to require a promise, it may be accepted by performance if the offeree begins to perform and the offeror knows of and acquiesces in that performance, unless the offer expressly limits the method of acceptance.
cards.hardContent: Acceptance by performance depends on the type of contract and the terms of the offer. If the offer is silent, the offeree may accept by performance: complete performance for unilateral contracts and part or beginning performance for bilateral contracts. In unilateral contracts, complete performance is required to accept; the offeree is not obligated to start or finish, and failure to perform is not a breach because no contract forms until performance is complete. However, once the offeree begins performance, many courts treat the offer as irrevocable for a reasonable time to allow completion. Notice of acceptance is generally not required at the start of performance, but the offeree must notify the offeror of completion within a reasonable time unless the offeror otherwise learns of performance or notice is waived. In bilateral contracts, beginning or partial performance constitutes acceptance, but the offeree must make the offeror aware of acceptance, either through performance in the offeror’s presence or through reasonable notice. Even when an offer appears to require acceptance by promise, it can often be accepted by performance if the offeree begins performing and the offeror knows of that performance and acquiesces, unless the offer specifically limits acceptable modes of acceptance—in which case that limitation controls.
cards.mnemonic: U-BOP: Unilateral = full; Bilateral = outset; Offer may limit.
cards.clozeLite: If an offer is {{c1::silent on method}}, the offeree may accept by {{c2::complete performance for unilateral}} and {{c3::beginning performance for bilateral}}; unilateral offers become {{c4::irrevocable once performance begins}} and usually {{c5::require notice of completion}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 011. Consideration and Substitutes for Consideration
cards.backPlain: 1. In General 1.1. Consideration is a bargained-for exchange of legal value between the parties. 1.2. There must be a benefit to the promisor or a detriment to the promisee. 1.3. Consideration is a required element of every contract: the promise must induce the detriment, and the detriment must induce the promise. 2. Detriment and Pre-Existing Duty 2.1. Detriment is an obligation to do or refrain from doing something one would otherwise not be obligated to do or refrain from doing. 2.2. Pre-existing duty: A promise to perform a pre-existing duty or obligation generally does not constitute consideration. 2.3. Exception: A promise to pay a debt after the statute of limitations has run is binding despite lack of new consideration. 3. Invalid Consideration 3.1. The following do not constitute consideration: 3.1.1. Promises of gifts or conditional gifts (where the condition is merely a way to receive the gift). 3.1.2. Illusory promises: a promise where there is no real obligation to perform (for example, "I will do your chores if I feel like it" or "if I have time"). 4. Promissory Estoppel (Reliance) 4.1. Courts may enforce a promise without consideration under promissory estoppel if: 4.1.1. The promisor reasonably expects reliance by the promisee; 4.1.2. The promisee acts or refrains from acting in detrimental reliance; and 4.1.3. Injustice can be avoided only by enforcement of the promise.
cards.frontPrompt: What is consideration in contract law, what does not qualify as valid consideration, and when can promissory estoppel substitute for consideration?
cards.cloze: 1. In General 1.1. Consideration is a {{c1::bargained-for exchange of legal value}} between the parties. 1.2. There must be a {{c2::benefit to the promisor}} or a {{c3::detriment to the promisee}}. 1.3. Consideration is a required element of every contract: the {{c4::promise must induce the detriment, and the detriment must induce the promise}}. 2. Detriment and Pre-Existing Duty 2.1. Detriment is an obligation to {{c5::do or refrain from doing something one would otherwise not be obligated to do or refrain from doing}}. 2.2. {{c6::Pre-existing duty}}: A promise to perform a pre-existing duty or obligation generally {{c7::does not constitute consideration}}. 2.3. Exception: A promise to {{c8::pay a debt after the statute of limitations has run}} is binding despite lack of new consideration. 3. Invalid Consideration 3.1. The following do not constitute consideration: 3.1.1. {{c9::Promises of gifts or conditional gifts}} (where the condition is merely a way to receive the gift). 3.1.2. {{c10::Illusory promises}}: a promise where there is {{c11::no real obligation to perform}} (for example, "I will do your chores if I feel like it" or "if I have time"). 4. {{c12::Promissory Estoppel}} (Reliance) 4.1. Courts may enforce a promise without consideration under promissory estoppel if: 4.1.1. The {{c13::promisor reasonably expects reliance}} by the promisee; 4.1.2. The {{c14::promisee acts or refrains from acting in detrimental reliance}}; and 4.1.3. {{c15::Injustice can be avoided only by enforcement}} of the promise.
cards.easyContent: Consideration is a bargained-for exchange of legal value, requiring either a benefit to the promisor or a detriment to the promisee, and is necessary for every contract. Gifts, conditional gifts, illusory promises, and mere pre-existing duties are not valid consideration, but promissory estoppel can enforce certain relied-upon promises even without consideration.
cards.mediumContent: Consideration exists when there is a bargained-for exchange of legal value—either a benefit to the promisor or a detriment to the promisee—and the promise induces the detriment while the detriment induces the promise. Detriment means doing or forbearing something one is not otherwise legally obligated to do or forbear. A promise to perform a pre-existing duty is ordinarily not consideration, although a promise to pay a debt after the statute of limitations has run is enforceable without new consideration. Promises of gifts or conditional gifts (where the condition is just a way to receive the gift) and illusory promises where the promisor has no real obligation to perform do not qualify as consideration. However, under promissory estoppel, a promise can be enforced if the promisor reasonably expects reliance, the promisee actually relies to their detriment, and only enforcement will avoid injustice.
cards.hardContent: Consideration is a bargained-for exchange of legal value between the parties and is required for every contract. It exists where there is either a benefit to the promisor or a detriment to the promisee, and the promise and detriment mutually induce each other. Detriment means taking on an obligation to do or refrain from doing something that one has no prior legal duty to do or refrain from doing. A promise to perform a pre-existing legal duty generally is not consideration, because it adds nothing of legal value; an important exception is that a written promise to pay a debt after the statute of limitations has expired is binding even without new consideration. Invalid forms of consideration include promises of gifts or conditional gifts when the condition is only a means of taking delivery, and illusory promises where the promisor retains unfettered discretion whether to perform (e.g., "if I feel like it" or "if I have time"). As a substitute, courts may invoke promissory estoppel to enforce a promise without consideration when the promisor reasonably expects the promisee to rely, the promisee actually relies by acting or refraining from acting to their detriment, and only enforcement of the promise will prevent injustice.
cards.mnemonic: Consideration is BFD: Bargained-For detriment/benefit, not Duties, gifts.
cards.clozeLite: {{c1::Consideration}} is a {{c2::bargained-for exchange of legal value}}—a {{c3::benefit to the promisor or detriment to the promisee}}. {{c4::Pre-existing duties, gifts, and illusory promises}} are not consideration, but {{c5::promissory estoppel}} can enforce relied-upon promises without it.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 012. Defenses to Contract Formation
cards.backPlain: Defenses to contract formation or enforcement allow a court to refuse to enforce an otherwise valid agreement, rendering it void or voidable by a party. The main categories of defenses are: 1. Incapacity 2. Statute of Frauds (SoF) 3. Illegality 4. Misrepresentation/Fraud 5. Duress 6. Unconscionability 7. Misunderstanding (ambiguity) 8. Mistake Each of these is a separate doctrine that can prevent contract formation or make a formed contract unenforceable.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the main categories of defenses to contract formation or enforcement, and what is their general effect on an otherwise valid contract?
cards.cloze: Defenses to {{c1::contract formation or enforcement}} allow a court to refuse to enforce an otherwise valid agreement, making it {{c2::void or voidable}} by a party. The main categories are: {{c3::incapacity}}, {{c4::Statute of Frauds}}, {{c5::illegality}}, {{c6::misrepresentation/fraud}}, {{c7::duress}}, {{c8::unconscionability}}, {{c9::misunderstanding}}, and {{c10::mistake}}.
cards.easyContent: Defenses to contract formation or enforcement can make an otherwise valid agreement void or voidable. The main categories are: incapacity, Statute of Frauds problems, illegality, misrepresentation/fraud, duress, unconscionability, misunderstanding, and mistake.
cards.mediumContent: Defenses to contract formation or enforcement allow a court to refuse to enforce an otherwise valid agreement, making it void or voidable by a party. The key categories are: (1) incapacity; (2) failure to satisfy the Statute of Frauds for covered contracts; (3) illegality of the contract’s subject matter or purpose; (4) misrepresentation or fraud; (5) duress; (6) unconscionability; (7) misunderstanding due to ambiguity; and (8) mistake about underlying facts.
cards.hardContent: Defenses to contract formation or enforcement are doctrines that allow a court to decline to enforce an otherwise valid agreement, making it void or voidable by an affected party. The principal categories are: 1. Incapacity – a party lacks legal capacity to contract (e.g., minor, mentally incompetent, intoxicated under some regimes). 2. Statute of Frauds (SoF) – certain types of contracts must satisfy specific formal (usually writing and signature) requirements; failure to comply makes the contract unenforceable. 3. Illegality – the subject matter or purpose of the contract is illegal or contrary to public policy. 4. Misrepresentation/Fraud – the agreement is induced by fraudulent or materially misleading statements. 5. Duress – the agreement is induced by wrongful threats, force, or coercive pressure. 6. Unconscionability – the terms or bargaining process are so unfair or oppressive that enforcement would be unjust. 7. Misunderstanding – there is ambiguity concerning a term, and the parties attach materially different meanings. 8. Mistake – one or both parties are mistaken about underlying facts that are material to the bargain. Each doctrine has its own specific elements and consequences, but all operate to limit enforcement of contracts.
cards.mnemonic: I-SLIM DUM: Incapacity, SoF, Illegality, Misrep, Duress, Unconscionability, Misunderstanding, Mistake.
cards.atomizationNotes: Atomized into overview parent plus four children: (1) capacity/SoF/illegality, (2) misrepresentation/fraud and duress, (3) unconscionability, (4) misunderstanding and mistake.
cards.clozeLite: Defenses to contract {{c1::formation or enforcement}} can make an otherwise valid agreement {{c2::void or voidable}}. Main categories include {{c3::incapacity}}, {{c4::Statute of Frauds problems}}, {{c5::illegality}}, and {{c6::misrepresentation/fraud, duress, unconscionability, misunderstanding, and mistake}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 013. Incapacity
cards.backPlain: Certain parties lack capacity to contract: infants, mentally incompetent persons, and some intoxicated persons (where the other party has reason to know of the intoxication). Contracts with such parties are generally voidable at the option of the party lacking capacity, who has a right to disaffirm. However, there are important limitations in the case of minors, including possible implied affirmation (ratification) after gaining capacity and quasi-contract liability for the reasonable value of necessities.
cards.frontPrompt: Who generally lacks capacity to contract, what is the basic right to disaffirm, and what are the key limitations for minors?
cards.cloze: Certain parties lack capacity to contract: {{c1::infants}}, {{c2::mentally incompetent persons}}, and some {{c3::intoxicated persons}} (where the other party has {{c4::reason to know}} of the intoxication). Contracts with such parties are generally {{c5::voidable}} at the option of the party lacking capacity, who has a {{c6::right to disaffirm}}. However, minors face key limitations, including possible {{c7::implied affirmation (ratification)}} after gaining capacity and {{c8::quasi-contract liability}} for the reasonable value of {{c9::necessities}}.
cards.easyContent: Infants, mentally incompetent persons, and some intoxicated persons lack capacity to contract and usually may disaffirm, making the contract voidable. For minors, there are important limits: they may later ratify by implied affirmation and are still liable for necessities in quasi-contract.
cards.mediumContent: Capacity defenses arise when the contracting party is an infant, mentally incompetent, or intoxicated in circumstances where the other party has reason to know of the intoxication. Such contracts are generally voidable at the option of the party lacking capacity through disaffirmance. For minors, incapacity is limited by two doctrines: (1) implied affirmation (ratification) after gaining capacity, and (2) quasi-contract liability for the reasonable value of necessities such as food, clothing, and medical care.
cards.hardContent: Incapacity in contract law focuses on categories of persons who may avoid contractual obligations: infants, mentally incompetent persons, and intoxicated persons where the other party has reason to know of the intoxication. Contracts with these parties are usually voidable—not automatically void—at the option of the party lacking capacity, who may exercise a right to disaffirm. In the case of minors, however, this general rule is limited by (1) implied affirmation (ratification) after the minor gains capacity and retains the contract’s benefits and (2) an obligation to pay, in quasi-contract, for the reasonable value of necessities (such as food, clothing, and medical care), even though the underlying contract is not fully enforceable.
cards.mnemonic: I-MI: Infants, Mentally incompetent, Intoxicated; minors Ratify & pay Necessities.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into four children: (1) who lacks capacity; (2) right to disaffirm; (3) implied affirmation/ratification and its elements; and (4) infant liability for necessities.
cards.clozeLite: Capacity defenses: {{c1::infants}}, {{c2::mentally incompetent}}, and {{c3::intoxicated (other side knows)}}; contracts are {{c4::voidable by the incapacitated party}}; minors face {{c5::ratification and necessities}} limits.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 014. Statute of Frauds
cards.front: Statute of Frauds – Methods of Satisfying the SoF (Overview)
cards.backPlain: Contracts subject to the Statute of Frauds require special proof of their existence. Failure to satisfy SoF requirements may result in an invalid or unenforceable contract. The Statute of Frauds can generally be satisfied by: • A signed writing from the party to be charged. • A UCC merchant confirmation memo. • Certain performance (services and sales of goods, including custom-made goods). • Real estate part performance by the buyer (two out of three key acts). Each of these methods has specific requirements, covered in separate cards.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the main methods by which a contract subject to the Statute of Frauds can be satisfied?
cards.cloze: Contracts subject to the {{c1::Statute of Frauds}} require {{c2::special proof of their existence}} or they may be {{c3::invalid or unenforceable}}. The SoF can generally be satisfied by: (1) a {{c4::signed writing}}; (2) a {{c5::UCC merchant confirmation}}; (3) qualifying {{c6::performance}}; and (4) {{c7::real estate part performance}}.
cards.easyContent: Contracts within the Statute of Frauds need special proof. The requirement can be met by a signed writing, a UCC merchant confirmation, certain performance (services and goods), or real estate part performance by the buyer.
cards.mediumContent: The Statute of Frauds requires certain contracts to be proven by specific means. A contract can be taken out of the SoF problem if it is supported by: (1) a signed writing from the party to be charged; (2) a merchant confirmation memo under the UCC; (3) qualifying performance (full performance of services or certain performance of goods, including custom-made goods); or (4) real estate part performance by the buyer (two of: pay, possession, improvements).
cards.hardContent: Contracts subject to the Statute of Frauds require special proof of their existence, and failure to satisfy the SoF can render an agreement invalid or unenforceable. The SoF can be satisfied by four main pathways: (1) a signed writing containing the signature of the party to be charged; (2) a UCC confirmation between merchants where the recipient merchant receives and fails to timely object to a signed writing that memorializes the agreement and its essential terms; (3) performance, including full performance of a service contract and specific forms of performance for sales of goods (delivery and acceptance or substantial beginning for custom-made goods); and (4) real estate part performance by the buyer, when the buyer takes two of three key steps—payment, possession, and improvements.
cards.mnemonic: WPP-R: Writing, Paper (merchant memo), Performance, Real estate part performance.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into four children: (1) general SoF rule; (2) signed writing and UCC merchant confirmation; (3) performance for services and goods (including custom goods); and (4) real estate part performance test.
cards.clozeLite: SoF is satisfied by {{c1::a signed writing}}, {{c2::UCC merchant confirmation}}, {{c3::qualifying performance of services or goods}}, or {{c4::real estate part performance (2 of 3 acts)}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.topic: Contracts within the Statute of Frauds
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 015. Contracts within the Statute of Frauds
cards.front: Contracts within the Statute of Frauds
cards.backPlain: 1. In general: If a contract is within the Statute of Frauds, it must satisfy SoF requirements to be valid or enforceable. 2. Contracts within the Statute of Frauds (common law and UCC): 2.1 Marriage contracts: Promises made in consideration of marriage. 2.2 Service contracts incapable of being performed within 1 year: 2.2.1 The SoF does not apply to deals or contracts that say nothing about time for performance because they are technically capable of performance within one year. 2.3 Land-related contracts: Transfers of property interests, including leases for terms greater than one year. 2.4 Executor promises: Promises by executors or administrators to personally answer for the debts of the decedent's estate. 2.5 Suretyship: Promises to pay the debt of another. 2.6 UCC: Sales of goods for $500 or more.
cards.frontPrompt: Which types of contracts fall within the Statute of Frauds and therefore must satisfy its requirements?
cards.cloze: 1. In general: If a contract is within the {{c1::Statute of Frauds}}, it must satisfy SoF requirements to be {{c2::valid or enforceable}}. 2. Contracts within the Statute of Frauds (common law and UCC): 2.1 {{c3::Marriage contracts}}: Promises made in {{c4::consideration of marriage}}. 2.2 {{c5::Service contracts}} incapable of being performed within {{c6::1 year}}: 2.2.1 The SoF does not apply to deals or contracts that say nothing about time for performance because they are technically capable of performance within one year. 2.3 {{c7::Land-related contracts}}: Transfers of property interests, including {{c8::leases for terms greater than one year}}. 2.4 {{c9::Executor promises}}: Promises by executors or administrators to personally answer for the debts of the decedent's estate. 2.5 {{c10::Suretyship}}: Promises to pay the {{c11::debt of another}}. 2.6 {{c12::UCC}}: {{c13::Sales of goods for $500 or more}}.
cards.easyContent: The Statute of Frauds covers certain contracts—like marriage, long-term service, land transfers, executor promises, suretyship, and UCC sales of goods over $500—which must meet SoF requirements to be enforceable.
cards.mediumContent: A contract must satisfy the Statute of Frauds if it involves: (1) promises made in consideration of marriage; (2) service contracts that cannot be performed within one year; (3) transfers of interests in land, including leases longer than one year; (4) promises by an executor or administrator to personally pay estate debts; (5) suretyship promises to pay another’s debt; and (6) UCC sales of goods for $500 or more. Deals that do not specify a time for performance are generally outside the one-year provision because they could be performed within a year.
cards.hardContent: If a contract falls within the Statute of Frauds, it must comply with the SoF to be valid or enforceable. Covered contracts include: (1) marriage contracts—promises made in consideration of marriage; (2) service contracts that are incapable of being fully performed within one year, though contracts silent as to time fall outside this category because they are technically capable of performance within one year; (3) land-related contracts, including transfers of property interests and leases for terms greater than one year; (4) executor or administrator promises to personally answer for the debts of the decedent's estate; (5) suretyship promises to pay the debt of another; and (6) under the UCC, sales of goods for $500 or more.
cards.mnemonic: Use MY LEGS: Marriage, Year, Land, Executor, Guaranty, Sale of goods $500+.
cards.clozeLite: Statute of Frauds covers {{c1::marriage promises}}, {{c2::service not performable within one year}}, {{c3::land transfers}}, {{c4::executor personal promises}}, {{c5::suretyship}}, and {{c6::UCC goods $500+}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.topic: Illegality, Fraud, Undue Influence, Duress, and Unconscionability
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 016. Illegality, Fraud, Undue Influence, Duress, and Unconscionability
cards.front: Illegality, Fraud, Undue Influence, Duress, and Unconscionability
cards.backPlain: These doctrines operate as defenses to contract formation or enforcement: 1. Illegality and public policy: Contract subject matter or purpose is illegal, or enforcement would frustrate protective public policy. 2. Misrepresentation (fraud): A party relies to their detriment on a material false assertion, concealment, or misstatement. 3. Undue influence: A susceptible party enters a contract under excessive pressure. 4. Duress: A wrongful act or threat overcomes a party's free will (physical duress makes a contract void; non-physical duress makes it voidable). 5. Unconscionability: The bargaining process or terms are so unfair or oppressive that the court may refuse to enforce all or part of the contract.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the main contract defenses of illegality, misrepresentation (fraud), undue influence, duress, and unconscionability, at a high level?
cards.cloze: These doctrines operate as defenses to {{c1::contract formation or enforcement}}: 1. {{c2::Illegality and public policy}}: Contract subject matter or purpose is illegal, or enforcement would frustrate protective public policy. 2. {{c3::Misrepresentation (fraud)}}: A party relies to their detriment on a {{c4::material}} false assertion, concealment, or misstatement. 3. {{c5::Undue influence}}: A {{c6::susceptible party}} enters a contract under {{c7::excessive pressure}}. 4. {{c8::Duress}}: A {{c9::wrongful act or threat}} overcomes a party's {{c10::free will}} ({{c11::physical duress}} makes a contract {{c12::void}}; {{c13::non-physical duress}} makes it {{c14::voidable}}). 5. {{c15::Unconscionability}}: The {{c16::bargaining process}} or {{c17::contract terms}} are so {{c18::unfair or oppressive}} that the court may refuse to enforce all or part of the contract.
cards.easyContent: Illegality, fraud (misrepresentation), undue influence, duress, and unconscionability are major contract defenses. They focus on unlawful purposes, material false statements, overbearing pressure on a susceptible party, wrongful threats that overcome free will, and grossly unfair bargaining or terms.
cards.mediumContent: Key contract defenses include: (1) illegality and public policy, where the subject matter or purpose is illegal or enforcement would frustrate protective public policy; (2) misrepresentation (fraud), where a party is induced to contract by a material false assertion, concealment, or misstatement on which they detrimentally rely; (3) undue influence, where a susceptible party is subjected to excessive pressure; (4) duress, where wrongful acts or threats overcome a party’s free will, with physical duress rendering the contract void and non-physical duress making it voidable; and (5) unconscionability, where unfair or oppressive bargaining or terms leave the disadvantaged party without a meaningful choice and allow a court to refuse to enforce all or part of the contract.
cards.hardContent: Several doctrines serve as defenses to contract formation or enforcement: (1) Illegality and public policy: the contract’s subject matter may be illegal (making it unenforceable), or the subject may be legal but the purpose illegal, with enforcement typically only available to an innocent party; courts also consider whether enforcing or refusing enforcement would frustrate public policy, particularly where the policy is meant to protect the party seeking relief. (2) Misrepresentation (fraud): false assertions, concealment, or misstatements about a material fact before formation or performance that a party reasonably and detrimentally relies on, making the contract voidable. (3) Undue influence: a contract entered into under excessive pressure by a party unduly susceptible to such pressure, making the contract voidable. (4) Duress: a wrongful act or threat that overcomes a party’s free will; physical duress renders the contract void, while non-physical duress makes it voidable at the option of the coerced party. (5) Unconscionability: where the bargaining process or contract terms are so unfair or oppressive (often seen in adhesion contracts or exculpatory clauses for intentional acts, especially where the disadvantaged party has no meaningful choice) that a court may refuse to enforce all or part of the contract.
cards.mnemonic: Think I-FUDU: Illegality, Fraud, Undue influence, Duress, Unconscionability.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into five children: (1) illegality and public policy; (2) misrepresentation/fraud; (3) undue influence; (4) duress (physical vs non-physical); and (5) unconscionability, including examples and meaningful choice.
cards.clozeLite: Major defenses include {{c1::illegality/public policy}}, {{c2::misrepresentation (fraud)}}, {{c3::undue influence}}, {{c4::duress}}, and {{c5::unconscionability}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 017. Misunderstanding and Mistake
cards.backPlain: Misunderstanding and mistake are defenses related to problems in the parties' understanding at the time of contract formation. 1. Misunderstanding (ambiguity): - Concerned with ambiguous terms where parties may attach different meanings. - Whether a contract is formed depends on who is aware of the ambiguity (neither, one, or both parties). 2. Mutual mistake: - Both parties share the same mistaken belief about a basic factual assumption. - If certain conditions are met (basic assumption, material effect, no assumption of risk), the contract is voidable by the adversely affected party. 3. Unilateral mistake: - Only one party is mistaken, often due to clerical or computational errors. - Contract formation generally stands, but the mistaken party may sometimes void the contract if the mistake is material and either the other party knew/should have known or enforcement would be unconscionable.
cards.frontPrompt: How do misunderstanding (ambiguity) and mistake (mutual or unilateral) affect contract formation and enforceability?
cards.cloze: Misunderstanding and mistake are defenses related to problems in the parties' understanding at the time of contract formation. 1. {{c1::Misunderstanding (ambiguity)}}: focuses on ambiguous terms and whether the parties attached the {{c2::same meaning}}, with different results depending on who is aware of the ambiguity. 2. {{c3::Mutual mistake}}: both parties share the {{c4::same mistaken belief about a basic factual assumption}}, which can make the contract {{c5::voidable by the adversely affected party}} if certain conditions are met. 3. {{c6::Unilateral mistake}}: only one party is mistaken; the contract generally remains enforceable, but in limited circumstances the {{c7::mistaken party}} may {{c8::void the contract}}.
cards.easyContent: Misunderstanding (ambiguity) and mistake (mutual or unilateral) are contract defenses that arise from problems in the parties' understanding at formation and can prevent contract formation or make a contract voidable in defined circumstances.
cards.mediumContent: Misunderstanding concerns ambiguity in contract terms and whether the parties actually attached the same meaning, with outcomes depending on who knew of the ambiguity. Mutual mistake occurs when both parties share a mistaken basic assumption that materially affects the exchange and was not assumed as a risk by the adversely affected party, making the contract voidable. Unilateral mistake involves only one mistaken party; formation generally stands, but the mistaken party may void a material mistake in limited circumstances.
cards.hardContent: Misunderstanding and mistake defenses address when the parties' understandings at contract formation diverge. Misunderstanding arises from ambiguous terms and turns on whether neither, one, or both parties are aware of the ambiguity and whether they actually intended the same meaning. Mutual mistake arises when both parties share a mistaken basic assumption that materially affects the agreed exchange and was not assumed as a risk by the adversely affected party, rendering the contract voidable. Unilateral mistake arises when only one party is mistaken, often in clerical or computational contexts; the contract typically remains enforceable, but the mistaken party may sometimes void a material mistake where the other party knew or should have known of the error or where enforcement would be unconscionable.
cards.mnemonic: MMU: Misunderstanding, Mutual mistake, Unilateral mistake—different knowledge, different results.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into three children: (1) misunderstanding/ambiguity awareness cases, (2) mutual mistake elements, and (3) unilateral mistake rule and exceptions.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::misunderstanding}} turns on {{c2::ambiguity and parties’ meanings}}. {{c3::Mutual mistake}} makes a contract {{c4::voidable}}. {{c5::Unilateral mistake}} is only sometimes voidable.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 018. Parol Evidence Rule
cards.backPlain: Under the Parol Evidence Rule (PER), extrinsic evidence of prior or contemporaneous agreements or negotiations is generally inadmissible to supplement or contradict a written contract that is an integration of the parties’ agreement. The rule focuses on whether the writing is a complete (or partial) integration and then asks what kinds of evidence are barred or allowed. At common law, PER bars prior or contemporaneous extrinsic evidence that would change a completely integrated writing, but it permits certain categories of extrinsic evidence, including: (1) showing that the writing is only partially integrated or that the additional terms belong in a separate agreement; (2) showing mistake in reducing the agreement to writing; (3) misrepresentation, fraud, duress, or illegality; (4) conditions precedent to the agreement taking effect; (5) later modifications; and (6) interpretation of the parties’ intended meaning. Under the UCC, PER is more flexible: even when there is a writing, its terms may be explained or supplemented by course of dealing, course of performance, and usage of trade, although express terms generally control over inconsistent extrinsic evidence.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the Parol Evidence Rule, in general terms, and how do its main common law exceptions and UCC variations fit together?
cards.cloze: Under the {{c1::Parol Evidence Rule (PER)}}, extrinsic evidence of prior or contemporaneous agreements or negotiations is generally inadmissible to supplement or contradict a written contract that is an {{c2::integration}} of the parties’ agreement. At {{c3::common law}}, PER bars prior or contemporaneous extrinsic evidence that would change a completely integrated writing, but permits certain categories of extrinsic evidence (e.g., {{c4::partial integration or separate-agreement terms}}, {{c5::mistake, misrepresentation/fraud/duress/illegality}}, {{c6::conditions precedent}}, {{c7::later modifications}}, and {{c8::interpretation}}). Under the {{c9::UCC}}, even where there is a writing, its terms may be explained or supplemented by {{c10::course of dealing, course of performance, and usage of trade}}, though {{c11::express terms}} generally control.
cards.easyContent: The Parol Evidence Rule generally bars prior or contemporaneous extrinsic evidence that would supplement or contradict a fully integrated written contract, but it has several common law exceptions and is more flexible under the UCC, which allows trade- and dealing-based evidence to explain or supplement terms.
cards.mediumContent: The Parol Evidence Rule makes prior or contemporaneous extrinsic evidence inadmissible to supplement or contradict a written contract that the parties intended as a complete integration. Common law recognizes exceptions that allow certain kinds of extrinsic evidence—such as proof of only partial integration, separate agreements, mistake, fraud/duress/illegality, conditions precedent, later modifications, and interpretation of terms. Under the UCC, course of dealing, course of performance, and usage of trade may explain or supplement a written contract, although express terms control over inconsistent extrinsic evidence.
cards.hardContent: The Parol Evidence Rule (PER) bars extrinsic evidence of prior or contemporaneous agreements or negotiations to supplement or contradict a written contract that the parties intended as an integration. The central inquiry is whether the writing is a complete or partial integration and then which types of evidence are barred or allowed. At common law, PER excludes prior or contemporaneous extrinsic evidence that would change a completely integrated writing, but it permits evidence to show: (1) that the writing is only partially integrated or that the additional terms naturally belong in a separate agreement; (2) a mistake in reducing the agreement to writing (to reform the writing); (3) misrepresentation, fraud, duress, or illegality; (4) a condition precedent to the agreement becoming effective; (5) subsequent (oral or written) modifications; and (6) the meaning the parties intended to give particular terms. Under the UCC, PER is applied more flexibly: a written contract may be explained or supplemented by course of dealing, course of performance, and usage of trade, and parties’ particular customs may prevail over general trade practice, though express terms generally carry greater weight than inconsistent extrinsic evidence.
cards.mnemonic: PERMCI: Parol Evidence allows Mistake, Conditions, Illegality/fraud, Modifications, Interpretation.
cards.atomizationNotes: Atomized into: (1) basic PER rule and integration/merger clause; (2) common law exceptions; and (3) UCC course of dealing/performance/usage rules.
cards.clozeLite: The {{c1::Parol Evidence Rule}} bars {{c2::prior or contemporaneous extrinsic evidence}} that {{c3::supplements or contradicts}} a {{c4::completely integrated writing}}, though {{c5::common law exceptions}} and {{c6::UCC trade/dealing evidence}} can allow it.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.topic: Delivery and Risk of Loss in UCC Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 019. Delivery and Risk of Loss in UCC Contracts
