cards.front: Delivery and Risk of Loss in UCC Contracts – Overview
cards.backPlain: Under the UCC, risk of loss rules determine which party bears the loss when goods are lost or destroyed before the buyer has fully taken responsibility. The key distinctions are: 1. Shipment vs. destination contracts when goods are shipped by a carrier. 2. Merchant vs. non-merchant sellers when goods are not shipped by a carrier. 3. Allocation of risk using FOB (Free On Board) terms and the named location. 4. The effects of destruction of goods before risk passes and of breach (e.g., rejection or revocation of acceptance) on who bears the risk. Across these categories, risk generally passes to the buyer when the seller has completed its delivery obligations under the particular type of contract, subject to special rules for destruction and breach.
cards.frontPrompt: In UCC sales, what are the main categories and considerations that determine when risk of loss passes from seller to buyer?
cards.cloze: Under the {{c1::UCC}}, {{c2::risk of loss}} rules determine which party bears the loss when goods are lost or destroyed before the buyer has fully taken responsibility. The main categories are: {{c3::shipment vs. destination contracts}}, {{c4::merchant vs. non-merchant sellers in non-carrier cases}}, {{c5::FOB (Free On Board) terms and the named location}}, and {{c6::effects of destruction before risk passes and breach (rejection/revocation)}}.
cards.easyContent: Under the UCC, risk of loss depends on: (1) whether the contract is a shipment or destination contract; (2) whether the seller is a merchant or non-merchant when there is no carrier; (3) any FOB term and its named location; and (4) whether goods are destroyed before risk passes or there is a breach such as rejection or revocation.
cards.mediumContent: Risk of loss in UCC sales turns on four main categories: (1) carrier contracts, where the shipment vs. destination distinction controls when risk passes; (2) non-carrier contracts, where merchant sellers bear risk until the buyer takes possession, while non-merchant sellers shift risk at tender; (3) FOB (Free On Board) terms, which allocate risk at the named location; and (4) special rules when goods are destroyed before risk passes without fault, and when there is breach by rejection or revocation of acceptance, keeping risk on the seller until cure or acceptance.
cards.hardContent: Under the UCC, risk of loss determines who bears the loss when goods are lost or destroyed before the buyer has fully taken responsibility. The doctrine is structured around: (1) carrier contracts, split into shipment contracts—where the seller’s duty is to deliver goods to a carrier and risk passes at delivery to the carrier, with shipment contracts presumed when carrier shipment is required and terms are otherwise silent—and destination contracts, where the seller must ensure goods reach the named destination and risk passes only when the buyer takes delivery there; (2) non-carrier contracts, where a merchant seller bears risk until the buyer takes physical possession, while a non-merchant seller shifts risk upon tender of delivery; (3) FOB (Free On Board) terms, under which the seller bears risk and expense up to the named FOB location, and risk then passes to the buyer at that location; and (4) overlay rules: if goods are destroyed before risk passes and no party is at fault, the contract is avoided, and if the buyer rightfully rejects or revokes acceptance of defective goods, risk remains with the seller until cure or subsequent acceptance.
cards.mnemonic: SHIP vs DEST, MERCH vs NON: risk tracks who holds goods.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into: (1) shipment vs. destination contracts, (2) merchant vs. non-merchant non-carrier rules, (3) FOB terms, and (4) destruction before risk passes and breach effects.
cards.clozeLite: UCC risk of loss turns on {{c1::carrier vs. non-carrier contracts}}, {{c2::merchant vs. non-merchant sellers}}, {{c3::FOB terms and named location}}, and {{c4::special rules for destruction or breach}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 020. Warranties and UCC Implied Warranties
cards.front: Warranties and UCC Implied Warranties – Overview
cards.backPlain: UCC Article 2 recognizes several types of warranties in the sale of goods, including express warranties and two key implied warranties (merchantability and fitness for a particular purpose). An express warranty is created by the seller’s affirmations of fact, promises, descriptions, samples, or models that become part of the basis of the bargain, and is breached when the goods fail to conform. In addition, a merchant seller who deals in goods of the kind automatically gives an implied warranty of merchantability that the goods are fit for their ordinary purpose. A separate implied warranty of fitness for a particular purpose arises when the seller has reason to know of the buyer’s special purpose and reliance, and the buyer actually relies on the seller to select suitable goods. The parties can structure warranty liability by using disclaimers (which can limit or eliminate implied warranties, but generally not express warranties) and by limiting remedies for breach (e.g., to repair or replacement), subject to unconscionability and the limitation not failing of its essential purpose. Damages for breach of warranty are typically measured by the difference between the value of the goods as delivered and the value as warranted, plus allowable incidental and consequential damages.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the main types of warranties under the UCC (express, merchantability, and fitness), and in general how can warranty liability and remedies be limited?
cards.cloze: UCC Article 2 recognizes several types of warranties in the sale of goods, including {{c1::express warranties}} and two key {{c2::implied warranties}} ({{c3::merchantability}} and {{c4::fitness for a particular purpose}}). An express warranty is created by the seller’s {{c5::affirmations of fact, promises, descriptions, samples, or models}} that become part of the {{c6::basis of the bargain}}, and is breached when the goods {{c7::fail to conform}}. In addition, a {{c8::merchant seller who deals in goods of the kind}} automatically gives an implied warranty of merchantability that the goods are {{c9::fit for their ordinary purpose}}. A separate implied warranty of fitness for a particular purpose arises when the seller has {{c10::reason to know of the buyer’s special purpose and reliance}}, and the buyer actually {{c11::relies on the seller to select suitable goods}}. The parties can structure warranty liability by using {{c12::disclaimers}} (which can limit or eliminate {{c13::implied warranties}}, but generally not {{c14::express warranties}}) and by {{c15::limiting remedies}} for breach (e.g., to repair or replacement), subject to {{c16::unconscionability}} and the limitation not {{c17::failing of its essential purpose}}. {{c18::Damages for breach of warranty}} are typically measured by the {{c19::difference between the value of the goods as delivered and the value as warranted}}, plus allowable {{c20::incidental and consequential damages}}.
cards.easyContent: Under the UCC, sellers can create express warranties by what they say or show about the goods, and implied warranties of merchantability (ordinary use) and fitness for a particular purpose (special purpose + buyer reliance + seller knowledge). Parties can use disclaimers and remedy limitations to shape warranty liability, and damages are measured by the difference between value as delivered and as warranted plus incidental and consequential damages.
cards.mediumContent: UCC sales law recognizes express warranties created by the seller’s affirmations of fact, promises, descriptions, samples, or models that become part of the basis of the bargain, which are breached when goods fail to conform. A merchant seller automatically gives an implied warranty of merchantability that goods are fit for their ordinary purpose. An implied warranty of fitness for a particular purpose arises when the seller has reason to know of the buyer’s special purpose and reliance and the buyer actually relies on the seller to select suitable goods. Parties may limit or disclaim implied (but generally not express) warranties and may limit remedies (e.g., repair or replacement) so long as the limitation is not unconscionable and does not fail of its essential purpose. Damages for breach are usually the value-as-warranted minus value-as-delivered plus incidental and consequential damages.
cards.hardContent: A warranty is a promise regarding the quality, description, or performance of goods. Under UCC Article 2, sellers can create express warranties by any affirmation of fact, promise, description, sample, or model that relates to the goods and becomes part of the basis of the bargain; breach occurs when the goods do not conform. In sales by a merchant who deals in goods of the kind, an implied warranty of merchantability automatically provides that the goods are fit for their ordinary purpose. An implied warranty of fitness for a particular purpose arises when the buyer has a particular purpose, the seller has reason to know of that purpose and of the buyer’s reliance, and the buyer actually relies on the seller to select suitable goods. Warranty liability can be structured by (1) disclaimers, which may eliminate or limit implied warranties but generally cannot disclaim express warranties, and must be conspicuous and, to disclaim merchantability, must mention "merchantability"; and (2) remedy limitations, which can restrict the buyer’s recovery (e.g., to repair or replacement) and are generally valid for all warranties unless unconscionable or they fail of their essential purpose. Damages for breach of warranty are typically measured by the difference between the value of the goods as delivered and as warranted, plus allowable incidental and consequential damages.
cards.mnemonic: M-Fit: Merchantability = ordinary use; Fitness = special purpose + reliance + knowledge.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into four children: (1) express warranties, (2) implied warranty of merchantability, (3) implied warranty of fitness for a particular purpose, and (4) disclaimers, remedy limitations, and damages.
cards.clozeLite: UCC warranties include {{c1::express warranties}}, {{c2::implied warranty of merchantability}}, and {{c3::implied warranty of fitness for a particular purpose}}; parties may {{c4::disclaim implied warranties}} and {{c5::limit remedies}} if not unconscionable.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.topic: Perfect Tender and Rejection of Goods
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 021. Perfect Tender and Rejection of Goods
cards.front: Perfect Tender and Rejection of Goods
cards.backPlain: 1. In general: Under UCC contracts, the seller's performance must be perfect with respect to the goods delivered and the manner of delivery. Imperfect tender means the seller sends defective or nonconforming goods. 2. Buyer's options upon seller's imperfect tender (the buyer can either): 2.1 Keep: Retain the goods delivered and sue for damages; or 2.2 Reject: Reject some or all of the goods and sue for damages. 3. Requirements for rejection (a buyer who rejects goods must): 3.1 Notify the seller of rejection within a reasonable time; 3.2 Hold the rejected goods using reasonable care; and 3.3 Give the seller a reasonable time to arrange for removal of the goods. 3.4 If the seller gives no information regarding removal, the buyer can return the goods to the seller, store the goods for the seller, or resell the goods on behalf of the seller (for the seller's benefit). 4. Installment contracts (where delivery of goods occurs in separate lots): 4.1 Rejection: The buyer can only reject a delivery/installment if: 4.1.1 The defect substantially impairs the value of that installment; and 4.1.2 The defect cannot be cured. 4.1.3 Rejection is limited to the defective installment, not the entire contract. 4.1.4 The buyer can cancel the entire contract due to a defective installment only if the nonconformity in that installment substantially impairs the value of the entire contract. 4.2 Note: A seller of imperfect goods may have a right to cure under the UCC, depending on the time for performance and the seller's reasonable belief that the tender would be acceptable.
cards.frontPrompt: Under the UCC perfect tender rule, what can a buyer do when goods are nonconforming, what are the requirements for rejection, and how do installment contracts change the analysis?
cards.cloze: 1. In general: Under {{c1::UCC}} contracts, the seller's performance must be {{c2::perfect}} with respect to the goods delivered and the manner of delivery. {{c3::Imperfect tender}} means the seller sends defective or nonconforming goods. 2. Buyer's options upon seller's imperfect tender (the buyer can either): 2.1 {{c4::Keep}}: Retain the goods delivered and sue for damages; or 2.2 {{c5::Reject}}: Reject some or all of the goods and sue for damages. 3. Requirements for {{c6::rejection}} (a buyer who rejects goods must): 3.1 {{c7::Notify the seller}} of rejection within a reasonable time; 3.2 {{c8::Hold the rejected goods using reasonable care}}; and 3.3 {{c9::Give the seller a reasonable time to arrange for removal}} of the goods. 3.4 If the seller gives no information regarding removal, the buyer can {{c10::return the goods to the seller, store the goods for the seller, or resell the goods on behalf of the seller}} (for the seller's benefit). 4. {{c11::Installment contracts}} (where delivery of goods occurs in separate lots): 4.1 Rejection: The buyer can only reject a delivery/installment if: 4.1.1 The defect {{c12::substantially impairs the value of that installment}}; and 4.1.2 The defect {{c13::cannot be cured}}. 4.1.3 Rejection is {{c14::limited to the defective installment}}, not the entire contract. 4.1.4 The buyer can {{c15::cancel the entire contract}} due to a defective installment only if the nonconformity in that installment {{c16::substantially impairs the value of the entire contract}}. 4.2 Note: A seller of imperfect goods may have a right to {{c17::cure}} under the UCC, depending on the time for performance and the seller's reasonable belief that the tender would be acceptable.
cards.easyContent: Under the UCC perfect tender rule, any nonconformity lets the buyer keep the goods and sue or reject them and sue, subject to reasonable rejection procedures and a more lenient standard for installment contracts.
cards.mediumContent: Under the UCC, the seller must make a perfect tender of goods and delivery; any nonconformity is an imperfect tender. The buyer may either retain the goods and sue for damages, or reject some or all and sue for damages. To reject, the buyer must timely notify the seller, hold the goods with reasonable care, and allow reasonable time for the seller to remove them, and if the seller is silent, may return, store, or resell the goods for the seller’s benefit. In installment contracts, the buyer may reject only an installment whose defect substantially impairs the value of that installment and cannot be cured; rejection is limited to that installment unless the nonconformity substantially impairs the entire contract, in which case the buyer may cancel the whole contract. The UCC also gives the seller a right to cure under appropriate circumstances.
cards.hardContent: Under the UCC perfect tender rule, the seller must deliver goods and tender performance in exact conformity with the contract; any defect in goods or delivery is an imperfect tender. When the seller makes an imperfect tender, the buyer can either (1) keep the goods and sue for damages or (2) reject some or all of the goods and sue for damages. A buyer who rejects must notify the seller of rejection within a reasonable time, hold the rejected goods with reasonable care, and give the seller a reasonable opportunity to arrange for their removal. If the seller provides no instructions, the buyer may return the goods, store them for the seller, or resell them on the seller’s behalf and account to the seller. For installment contracts, where goods are delivered in separate lots, the buyer may reject only an installment whose nonconformity substantially impairs the value of that installment and cannot be cured; rejection is limited to the defective installment. The buyer may cancel the entire contract only if the nonconformity in an installment substantially impairs the value of the whole contract. Additionally, the UCC may give the seller a right to cure nonconforming tender within the contract time or when the seller reasonably believed the tender would be acceptable.
cards.mnemonic: Perfect is picky; installments need substantial impairment.
cards.clozeLite: Under the UCC {{c1::perfect tender rule}}, any {{c2::nonconformity}} lets the buyer {{c3::accept and sue}} or {{c4::reject and sue}}. In {{c5::installment contracts}}, defect must {{c6::substantially impair}} value.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.topic: Perfect Tender and Acceptance of Goods
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 022. Perfect Tender and Acceptance of Goods
cards.front: Perfect Tender and Acceptance of Goods – Overview
cards.backPlain: Under the UCC, a buyer's post-delivery rights turn on (1) whether and how she has accepted the goods, and (2) whether she can later revoke that acceptance. 1. Acceptance of goods: A buyer does not officially accept goods until they are delivered and she has a reasonable opportunity to inspect and either indicate acceptance or fail to seasonably reject. 2. Revocation of acceptance: Even after acceptance, the buyer may in limited circumstances revoke acceptance if a defect substantially impairs the goods' value and specific conditions related to cure, ignorance, or reliance on the seller's assurances are met. These rules govern when a buyer is stuck with the goods versus when she can still unwind the transaction.
cards.frontPrompt: Under the UCC, how do acceptance and revocation of acceptance structure a buyer’s post-delivery rights in goods?
cards.cloze: Under the {{c1::UCC}}, a buyer's post-delivery rights turn on (1) whether and how she has {{c2::accepted}} the goods, and (2) whether she can later {{c3::revoke that acceptance}}. A buyer generally does not accept until she has a {{c4::reasonable opportunity to inspect}} and either indicates acceptance or fails to seasonably reject. Even after acceptance, the buyer may in limited circumstances revoke if a {{c5::defect substantially impairs the goods' value}} and specific conditions related to {{c6::cure, ignorance, or reliance on assurances}} are met.
cards.easyContent: Under the UCC, a buyer’s post-delivery rights focus on (1) whether she has accepted the goods and (2) whether she can revoke that acceptance. Acceptance generally requires a chance to inspect and either an indication that she will keep the goods or a failure to reject. Revocation is only allowed for substantially impairing defects under narrow conditions.
cards.mediumContent: Under the UCC, a buyer does not accept goods until delivery plus a reasonable chance to inspect. Acceptance can occur by the buyer indicating she will keep the goods (even if nonconforming) or by failing to reject in a reasonable time. Once accepted, the buyer usually cannot reject, but she may revoke acceptance if a defect substantially impairs the value of the goods and certain cure, ignorance, or reliance conditions are met.
cards.hardContent: Under the UCC, acceptance and revocation of acceptance define a buyer’s post-delivery remedies. A buyer does not accept until the goods are delivered and she has a reasonable opportunity to inspect them. Acceptance can occur either by the buyer affirmatively indicating that the goods conform or that she will keep them despite nonconformance, or by her silence in failing to reject within a reasonable time. Payment without an opportunity to inspect is not acceptance. Once accepted, the buyer cannot reject, but she may revoke acceptance if she later discovers a defect that substantially impairs the goods’ value and specific grounds related to cure, ignorance, or reliance are satisfied.
cards.mnemonic: AIR: Accept after Inspection, Risk silence, Revoke only for substantial defect.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into (1) UCC acceptance of goods and (2) revocation of acceptance requirements.
cards.clozeLite: Under the UCC, a buyer does not {{c1::accept goods}} until delivery plus a {{c2::reasonable chance to inspect}}. Once accepted, the buyer usually cannot {{c3::reject}}, but may {{c4::revoke acceptance}} if a defect {{c5::substantially impairs}} the goods’ value.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.topic: Perfect Tender and Seller's Ability to Cure
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 023. Perfect Tender and Seller's Ability to Cure
cards.front: Perfect Tender and Seller's Ability to Cure
cards.backPlain: 1. In general: If the buyer has notified the seller of an imperfect tender (delivery of nonconforming goods), the seller may have an opportunity to cure. 2. Requirements (when the seller can cure): 2.1 Seller gives buyer notice of intent to cure and time for performance has not yet expired: The seller must give the buyer reasonable notice and then deliver conforming goods within the original contract time. 2.2 Seller had reasonable grounds to believe the nonconforming goods would be acceptable: Reasonableness is usually based on the seller's prior dealings with the buyer; in this case, the seller will have an additional reasonable time period to tender conforming goods. 3. Note: The buyer cannot compel the seller to cure; the right to cure belongs to the seller under the UCC.
cards.frontPrompt: Under the UCC perfect tender rule, when does a seller have a right to cure a nonconforming tender?
cards.cloze: 1. In general: If the buyer has notified the seller of an {{c1::imperfect tender}} (delivery of {{c2::nonconforming goods}}), the seller may have an opportunity to {{c3::cure}}. 2. Requirements (when the seller can cure): 2.1 Seller gives buyer notice of intent to cure and {{c4::time for performance has not yet expired}}: The seller must give the buyer {{c5::reasonable notice}} and then deliver {{c6::conforming goods}} within the original contract time. 2.2 Seller had {{c7::reasonable grounds to believe}} the nonconforming goods would be acceptable: Reasonableness is usually based on the seller's {{c8::prior dealings with the buyer}}; in this case, the seller will have an {{c9::additional reasonable time}} period to tender conforming goods. 3. Note: The buyer {{c10::cannot compel the seller to cure}}; the {{c11::right to cure}} belongs to the seller under the {{c12::UCC}}.
cards.easyContent: Under the UCC, when a buyer rightfully rejects a nonconforming tender, the seller often has a right to cure by providing conforming goods, either within the original time for performance or within an additional reasonable time if cure was reasonably expected to be acceptable.
cards.mediumContent: If the buyer notifies the seller of an imperfect tender, the UCC allows the seller to cure in two main situations: (1) when the seller gives notice of intent to cure and the contract time has not yet expired, allowing cure within that time after reasonable notice; and (2) when the seller had reasonable grounds to believe the nonconforming goods would be acceptable (often based on prior dealings), in which case the seller gets an additional reasonable time to tender conforming goods. The buyer cannot force the seller to cure; the right to cure is the seller's.
cards.hardContent: Under the UCC perfect tender framework, if the buyer notifies the seller of an imperfect tender (nonconforming goods), the seller may have a right to cure. The seller can cure by: (1) giving the buyer notice of intent to cure and delivering conforming goods within the original time for performance, provided that time has not expired; or (2) if the seller had reasonable grounds to believe the nonconforming tender would be acceptable, usually based on prior dealings with the buyer, the seller is afforded an additional reasonable time to make a conforming tender. The buyer cannot compel cure; the right to cure belongs solely to the seller.
cards.mnemonic: Seller’s cure: NT or RG—Notice & Time, or Reasonable Grounds & extra Time.
cards.clozeLite: Under the UCC, a seller may cure an {{c1::imperfect tender}} by giving {{c2::notice of intent to cure}} and tendering {{c3::conforming goods}} within the {{c4::original contract time}} or, if it had {{c5::reasonable grounds to believe}} the goods would be acceptable, within an {{c6::additional reasonable time}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 024. Substantial Performance
cards.backPlain: 1. In general (common law): Under a common law contract, if one party has substantially performed, the other party is obligated to perform and complete performance. 1.1 Substantial performance is usually considered at least halfway complete. 1.2 Less than perfect performance by one party does not excuse the other party from his obligation to perform. 1.3 Thus, substantial performance by Party A obligates Party B to perform, but Party B may seek money damages for the difference between the performance rendered and the performance expected. 1.4 Substantial performance issues commonly arise in construction contracts or other similar service contracts.
cards.frontPrompt: In common law contracts, what is substantial performance, and what are its consequences for the other party's duty to perform and damages?
cards.cloze: 1. In general ({{c1::common law}}): Under a common law contract, if one party has {{c2::substantially performed}}, the other party is {{c3::obligated to perform and complete performance}}. 1.1 {{c4::Substantial performance}} is usually considered at least {{c5::halfway complete}}. 1.2 {{c6::Less than perfect performance}} by one party does not excuse the other party from his obligation to perform. 1.3 Thus, substantial performance by Party A obligates Party B to perform, but Party B may seek {{c7::money damages}} for the {{c8::difference between the performance rendered and the performance expected}}. 1.4 Substantial performance issues commonly arise in {{c9::construction contracts}} or other similar {{c10::service contracts}}.
cards.easyContent: Under common law, if a party has substantially performed—generally meaning performance is more than half complete—the other party must perform but can claim damages for any shortfall from full performance.
cards.mediumContent: In common law contracts, substantial performance (often at least halfway complete performance) by one party triggers the other party's duty to perform and complete performance. Less than perfect performance does not excuse the other party's obligation, but the nonbreaching party can recover money damages equal to the difference between the performance rendered and the performance expected. These issues frequently arise in construction and similar service contracts.
cards.hardContent: Under the common law, when a party has substantially performed—typically understood as performance being at least roughly halfway complete—the other party's duty to perform is triggered and he must complete his own contractual obligations. The fact that the performance is less than perfect does not discharge the other party's duties; instead, the nonbreaching party's remedy is money damages measured by the difference between the performance actually rendered and the performance expected under the contract, often seen in construction or service contracts.
cards.mnemonic: SUBSTANTIAL: Still Owes, But Shortfall = Damages.
cards.clozeLite: In common law, {{c1::substantial performance}} triggers the other party's {{c2::duty to perform}} but allows {{c3::damages for the shortfall}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 025. Material Breach
cards.backPlain: 1. In general (common law): A material breach occurs when one party's failure to perform under the contract substantially deprives the other party of the benefit of the bargain. 1.1 Material breach by one party excuses performance by the other. 1.2 Materiality of breach is a question of fact. 1.3 Damages: Damages are recoverable for any breach to the extent they are foreseeable as a probable result of the breach. 2. Timeliness of performance: 2.1 Failure to perform by the time stated in a contract is not a material breach if performance is rendered within a reasonable time after the time stated. 2.2 Exception: "Time is of the essence" clauses. 2.2.1 If timely performance is essential as stated in the contract, failure to perform by that time is a material breach. 2.2.2 This arises if one party indicates as a term of the contract that performance by a given date is essential. 3. Note: Material breach rules apply to common law contracts and do not apply to UCC contracts.
cards.frontPrompt: Under common law, what is a material breach, what are its consequences, and how does timeliness and a time-is-of-the-essence clause affect whether a breach is material?
cards.cloze: 1. In general ({{c1::common law}}): A {{c2::material breach}} occurs when one party's failure to perform under the contract {{c3::substantially deprives the other party of the benefit of the bargain}}. 1.1 Material breach by one party {{c4::excuses performance}} by the other. 1.2 {{c5::Materiality}} of breach is a {{c6::question of fact}}. 1.3 Damages: Damages are recoverable for any breach to the extent they are {{c7::foreseeable}} as a probable result of the breach. 2. {{c8::Timeliness of performance}}: 2.1 Failure to perform by the time stated in a contract is {{c9::not a material breach}} if performance is rendered within a {{c10::reasonable time}} after the time stated. 2.2 Exception: {{c11::"Time is of the essence" clauses}}. 2.2.1 If timely performance is {{c12::essential as stated in the contract}}, failure to perform by that time is a {{c13::material breach}}. 2.2.2 This arises if one party indicates as a term of the contract that performance by a given date is {{c14::essential}}. 3. Note: Material breach rules apply to {{c15::common law contracts}} and do not apply to {{c16::UCC}} contracts.
cards.easyContent: Under common law, a material breach is a failure of performance that substantially deprives the other party of the benefit of the bargain, excusing that party's duty to perform and allowing damages. Delay is usually not material if performance is rendered within a reasonable time, unless time is expressly made of the essence.
cards.mediumContent: A material breach under the common law occurs when one party's nonperformance substantially deprives the other of the contract's expected benefit; such a breach excuses the nonbreaching party's performance and allows recovery of foreseeable damages. Whether a breach is material is a fact question. As to timing, late performance is generally not a material breach if rendered within a reasonable time after the contract date, but if a "time is of the essence" clause or similar term makes timely performance essential, failure to perform on time constitutes a material breach. These rules apply to common law contracts, not UCC contracts.
cards.hardContent: In common law contracts, a material breach is a failure to perform that substantially deprives the other party of the benefit of the bargain. A material breach by one party excuses the other party from further performance and entitles the nonbreaching party to damages to the extent they are foreseeable as a probable result of the breach. The materiality of a breach is a question of fact. With respect to timeliness, failure to meet the exact contract date is ordinarily not material if performance is rendered within a reasonable time thereafter. However, where the contract includes a "time is of the essence" clause or clearly indicates that performance by a specific date is essential, failure to perform by that date is itself a material breach. These material breach rules govern common law contracts and do not apply to UCC contracts.
cards.mnemonic: Material breach = BIG HIT: Big Impact on Gain, Halts other party’s performance, Triggers damages.
cards.clozeLite: Under {{c1::common law}}, a {{c2::material breach}} is nonperformance that {{c3::substantially deprives the other party of the contract’s expected benefit}}, {{c4::excusing the other party’s performance}} and allowing {{c5::foreseeable damages}}; if {{c6::time is of the essence}}, late performance is a material breach.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 026. Conditions
cards.backPlain: Overview of conditions in contract law: 1. Definition and effect: 1.1 A condition is an agreed-upon limitation on performance that makes a party's duty contingent on the occurrence of some event. 1.2 Conditions are often indicated by words such as "if," "provided that," "on condition that," or similar language. 1.3 Condition vs. promise: Failure of a promise is a breach giving rise to damages; failure of a condition means the related performance obligation does not arise or is discharged. 2. Types of conditions: 2.1 Conditions may be express or implied. 2.2 The main timing categories are: • Condition precedent: Must occur before performance is due. • Condition subsequent: Occurs after performance has begun and, when it occurs, excuses the duty to continue performing. 3. Interpretation, waiver, and excuse: 3.1 Courts interpret conditions in light of their purpose and the parties' intent, often to protect a particular party. 3.2 A party protected or benefitted by a condition may waive it or be estopped from insisting on its enforcement. 3.3 Conditions may also be excused by doctrines such as breach, anticipatory repudiation, waiver, and wrongful prevention or hindrance of the condition's occurrence.
cards.frontPrompt: In contract law, what is a condition, how does it differ from a promise, what are the main timing types of conditions, and how are conditions generally interpreted, waived, or excused?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::A condition}} is an agreed-upon {{c2::limitation on performance}} that makes a party's duty {{c3::contingent on the occurrence of some event}}. 1.1 Conditions are often indicated by words such as {{c4::"if," "provided that," "on condition that"}}. 1.2 {{c5::Condition vs. promise}}: Failure of a {{c6::promise}} is a {{c7::breach}} with damages; failure of a {{c8::condition}} means the related {{c9::performance obligation does not arise or is discharged}}. 2. Types of conditions: 2.1 Conditions may be {{c10::express or implied}}. 2.2 Main timing categories: • {{c11::Condition precedent}} – must occur {{c12::before performance is due}}. • {{c13::Condition subsequent}} – occurs {{c14::after performance has begun}} and, when it occurs, {{c15::excuses the duty to continue performing}}. 3. Interpretation, waiver, and excuse: 3.1 Courts interpret conditions in light of their {{c16::purpose}} and the parties' {{c17::intent}}. 3.2 A party protected by a condition may {{c18::waive}} it or be {{c19::estopped}} from enforcing it. 3.3 Conditions may be excused by {{c20::breach, anticipatory repudiation, waiver, or wrongful prevention or hindrance}}.
cards.easyContent: A condition is a contract term that makes a duty contingent on an event; if the event doesn’t occur, the duty may never arise or be discharged, unlike a promise whose failure is a breach. Conditions can be express or implied, and are usually classified as conditions precedent (before performance is due) or subsequent (after performance has begun). Courts look to purpose and intent, and the protected party can waive or lose the right to insist on the condition; some doctrines like breach or wrongful prevention can excuse a condition.
cards.mediumContent: Conditions are agreed limits on performance that make a party’s duty contingent on some event, often signaled by words like “if,” “provided that,” or “on condition that.” Nonoccurrence of a condition means the related duty does not arise or is discharged, whereas nonperformance of a promise is a breach with damages. Conditions may be express or implied and are commonly divided into conditions precedent (must occur before performance is due) and conditions subsequent (occur after performance has begun and excuse the duty going forward). Courts interpret conditions based on their purpose and the parties’ intent, often to protect a specific party; that party can waive the condition or be estopped from enforcing it. Conditions can also be excused by breach, anticipatory repudiation, waiver, or wrongful prevention or hindrance of the condition’s occurrence.
cards.hardContent: In contract law, a condition is an agreed-upon limitation on performance that makes a party's duty contingent on the occurrence of some event, commonly signaled by language such as “if,” “provided that,” or “on condition that.” The critical distinction is that failure of a promise constitutes a breach with damages, whereas failure of a condition means the related performance obligation does not arise or is discharged. Conditions can be express or implied and are typically grouped by timing into conditions precedent—events that must occur before performance is due, such that nonoccurrence excuses performance—and conditions subsequent—events that occur after performance has begun and, when they occur, terminate the duty to continue performing. Courts interpret conditions in light of their purpose and the parties’ intent, often construing them to protect a particular party; that protected party can waive the condition or be estopped from insisting on its enforcement. In addition, conditions may be excused by doctrines such as breach, anticipatory repudiation, waiver, or wrongful prevention or hindrance of the condition’s occurrence, in which case the condition may be treated as satisfied and the duty remains.
cards.mnemonic: "If, then" = condition; breach = broken promise.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into three children: (1) definition and condition vs. promise, (2) types of conditions—precedent vs subsequent, and (3) interpretation, waiver, and excuse of conditions.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::condition}} makes a duty {{c2::contingent on an event}}, unlike a {{c3::promise}} whose failure is a {{c4::breach}}; conditions are typically {{c5::precedent or subsequent}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 027. Insecurity and Adequate Assurances
cards.backPlain: 1. In general 1.1 Insecurity arises when a party to a contract has reasonable grounds to believe the other party will be unwilling or unable to perform under the contract. 1.2 A justifiably insecure party may demand adequate assurances that the other party will perform and may suspend its own performance in the meantime. 1.3 This doctrine arises out of the UCC, but many states apply it to non-UCC contracts as well. 2. Demand for adequate assurances 2.1 The demand must be made in writing and must be based on reasonable and justified grounds for insecurity. 2.2 No response is required if the demand is unjustified or unreasonable (i.e., if the party seeking adequate assurances is unreasonably insecure). 2.3 A justifiably insecure party may suspend performance until adequate assurances are provided. 3. Adequate assurances 3.1 Adequate assurances are a commercially reasonable commitment (within 30 days) from a party that it will perform under the contract. 3.2 If adequate assurances are not provided within a reasonable time (no more than 30 days under the UCC), the insecure party may treat the contract as repudiated. 3.3 Failure to respond to an unreasonable demand is not a repudiation. 3.4 If adequate assurances are provided, the formerly insecure party must perform; failure to do so will constitute a breach. 4. Insecurity vs. anticipatory repudiation 4.1 Insecurity involves uncertainty regarding the other party's performance. 4.2 Anticipatory repudiation involves a clear indication the other party will not perform.
cards.frontPrompt: When may a party demand adequate assurances of performance, what can it do while it waits, and what happens if adequate assurances are or are not given?
cards.cloze: 1. In general 1.1 {{c1::Insecurity}} arises when a party to a {{c2::contract}} has {{c3::reasonable grounds}} to believe the other party will be unwilling or unable to perform under the contract. 1.2 A {{c4::justifiably insecure party}} may demand {{c5::adequate assurances}} that the other party will perform and may {{c6::suspend its own performance}} in the meantime. 1.3 This doctrine arises out of the {{c7::UCC}}, but many states apply it to {{c8::non-UCC contracts}} as well. 2. Demand for adequate assurances 2.1 The demand must be made {{c9::in writing}} and must be based on {{c10::reasonable and justified grounds for insecurity}}. 2.2 No response is required if the demand is {{c11::unjustified or unreasonable}} (i.e., if the party seeking adequate assurances is unreasonably insecure). 2.3 A justifiably insecure party may {{c12::suspend performance until adequate assurances are provided}}. 3. Adequate assurances 3.1 Adequate assurances are a {{c13::commercially reasonable commitment}} (within {{c14::30 days}}) from a party that it will perform under the contract. 3.2 If adequate assurances are not provided within a reasonable time (no more than {{c15::30 days under the UCC}}), the insecure party may treat the contract as {{c16::repudiated}}. 3.3 Failure to respond to an {{c17::unreasonable demand}} is not a repudiation. 3.4 If adequate assurances are provided, the formerly insecure party must perform; failure to do so will constitute a {{c18::breach}}. 4. Insecurity vs. anticipatory repudiation 4.1 Insecurity involves {{c19::uncertainty}} regarding the other party's performance. 4.2 {{c20::Anticipatory repudiation}} involves a {{c21::clear indication}} the other party will not perform.
cards.easyContent: If a party has reasonable grounds to be insecure about the other side’s performance, it may demand written adequate assurances and suspend its own performance until they are provided. Failure to give commercially reasonable assurances within a reasonable time (no more than 30 days under the UCC) lets the insecure party treat the contract as repudiated.
cards.mediumContent: Insecurity arises when a party has reasonable grounds to believe the other side will be unwilling or unable to perform. A justifiably insecure party may make a written demand for adequate assurances based on reasonable grounds and suspend performance while waiting. Adequate assurances are a commercially reasonable commitment (within 30 days under the UCC) that performance will occur; if not provided, the insecure party may treat the contract as repudiated, but failure to respond to an unreasonable demand is not repudiation. If assurances are given, the demanding party must perform. Insecurity reflects uncertainty, unlike anticipatory repudiation, which requires a clear indication of nonperformance.
cards.hardContent: Insecurity occurs when a contracting party has reasonable grounds to believe the other party will be unwilling or unable to perform. The doctrine comes from the UCC but is often applied to non-UCC contracts. A justifiably insecure party may make a written demand for adequate assurances, based on reasonable and justified grounds for insecurity, and may suspend its own performance until such assurances are provided. Adequate assurances consist of a commercially reasonable commitment, given within a reasonable time (no more than 30 days under the UCC), that the party will perform. If adequate assurances are not provided, the insecure party may treat the contract as repudiated; however, failure to respond to an unjustified or unreasonable demand does not constitute repudiation. Once adequate assurances are furnished, the formerly insecure party must resume performance or be in breach. Insecurity involves uncertainty as to performance, whereas anticipatory repudiation requires a clear indication that the other party will not perform.
cards.mnemonic: WRS-30: Written demand, Reasonable insecurity, Suspend; 30 days for assurances.
cards.clozeLite: If {{c1::reasonably insecure}}, a party may {{c2::demand written adequate assurances}} and {{c3::suspend its own performance}}; failure to give {{c4::commercially reasonable assurances within 30 days (UCC)}} lets it {{c5::treat the contract as repudiated}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 028. Anticipatory Repudiation
cards.backPlain: 1. In general 1.1 Anticipatory repudiation arises when one party to a contract makes it clear that they will not perform under the contract. 1.2 Effect: Anticipatory repudiation excuses performance by the other party. 2. Requirements (anticipatory repudiation arises if one party to a contract): 2.1 Makes an unambiguous statement or engages in unambiguous conduct. 2.2 Does so prior to the time performance is due (i.e., before full performance is due). 2.3 Clearly indicates they will not perform. 2.4 Example: A hires B to remodel A's kitchen. B is almost finished when A tells B she does not want the remodel and will not pay. B can treat the contract as breached, which excuses B's obligation to continue working. 2.5 Note: Distinguish from insecurity, which involves mere uncertainty regarding the other party's performance. 3. Withdrawal of repudiation 3.1 A repudiation can be withdrawn unless the other party has either: 3.1.1 Materially changed position in reliance on the repudiation; 3.1.2 Cancelled the contract in response to the repudiation; or 3.1.3 Indicated they consider the repudiation to be final. 4. Non-repudiating party's options (they may either): 4.1 Treat the anticipatory repudiation as a total repudiation and sue immediately. 4.2 Suspend performance until the performance date is due and wait to sue. 4.3 Treat the repudiation as an offer to rescind and treat the contract as discharged. 4.4 Ignore the repudiation and urge the promisor to perform.
cards.frontPrompt: What is anticipatory repudiation, what are its requirements, and what options does the non-repudiating party have (including withdrawal of repudiation)?
cards.cloze: 1. In general 1.1 {{c1::Anticipatory repudiation}} arises when one party to a {{c2::contract}} makes it {{c3::clear}} that they will not perform under the contract. 1.2 Effect: Anticipatory repudiation {{c4::excuses performance}} by the other party. 2. Requirements (anticipatory repudiation arises if one party to a contract): 2.1 Makes an {{c5::unambiguous statement}} or engages in {{c6::unambiguous conduct}}. 2.2 Does so {{c7::prior to the time performance is due}} (i.e., before full performance is due). 2.3 Clearly {{c8::indicates they will not perform}}. 2.4 Example: A hires B to remodel A's kitchen. B is almost finished when A tells B she does not want the remodel and will not pay. B can treat the contract as {{c9::breached}}, which excuses B's obligation to continue working. 2.5 Note: Distinguish from {{c10::insecurity}}, which involves mere uncertainty regarding the other party's performance. 3. Withdrawal of repudiation 3.1 A repudiation can be {{c11::withdrawn}} unless the other party has either: 3.1.1 {{c12::Materially changed position}} in reliance on the repudiation; 3.1.2 {{c13::Cancelled the contract}} in response to the repudiation; or 3.1.3 Indicated they consider the repudiation to be {{c14::final}}. 4. Non-repudiating party's options (they may either): 4.1 Treat the anticipatory repudiation as a {{c15::total repudiation}} and {{c16::sue immediately}}. 4.2 {{c17::Suspend performance}} until the performance date is due and wait to sue. 4.3 Treat the repudiation as an {{c18::offer to rescind}} and treat the contract as {{c19::discharged}}. 4.4 {{c20::Ignore}} the repudiation and {{c21::urge the promisor to perform}}.
cards.easyContent: Anticipatory repudiation occurs when before performance is due, a party clearly and unambiguously indicates they will not perform, which excuses the other party’s performance. The non-repudiating party can sue immediately, suspend performance and wait, treat the contract as rescinded, or urge performance, subject to limits on withdrawing the repudiation.
cards.mediumContent: Anticipatory repudiation arises when, before performance is due, a party makes an unambiguous statement or engages in unambiguous conduct clearly indicating they will not perform under the contract. This excuses the other side’s performance. The innocent party may (1) treat it as a total repudiation and sue immediately, (2) suspend performance and wait until performance is due to sue, (3) treat it as an offer to rescind and discharge the contract, or (4) ignore the repudiation and urge performance. The repudiating party may withdraw the repudiation unless the other party has materially changed position, cancelled the contract, or indicated they treat the repudiation as final. Anticipatory repudiation must be distinguished from mere insecurity.
cards.hardContent: Anticipatory repudiation occurs when one party to a contract, before performance is due, makes an unambiguous statement or engages in unambiguous conduct clearly indicating that they will not perform. This excuses the other party’s duty to perform. The non-repudiating party then has several options: (1) treat the anticipatory repudiation as a total repudiation and sue immediately; (2) suspend their own performance and wait until the time performance is due and then sue; (3) treat the repudiation as an offer to rescind and treat the contract as discharged; or (4) ignore the repudiation and urge the promisor to perform. The repudiating party may withdraw the repudiation if done before the other party has materially changed position in reliance on it, cancelled the contract, or indicated that they consider the repudiation final. Anticipatory repudiation requires clear nonperformance, unlike insecurity, which involves only uncertainty.
cards.mnemonic: "CAPS": Clear Advance Performance refusal Shields the other party.
cards.clozeLite: Anticipatory repudiation is when, {{c1::before performance is due}}, a party {{c2::clearly and unambiguously indicates nonperformance}}, {{c3::excusing the other side’s duty}} and allowing {{c4::immediate suit or suspension of performance}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 029. Impossibility and Impracticability
cards.backPlain: 1. In general 1.1 If an unforeseen event occurs after contract formation but before performance is complete, performance may be excused as impossible or impracticable. 2. Requirements 2.1 An unforeseen event, which neither party assumed would occur, must make completing performance either: 2.1.1 Impossible: performance is objectively impossible; or 2.1.2 Impracticable: performance is only possible with extreme and unreasonable difficulty or expense. 3. Common unforeseen events 3.1 Substantial damage or destruction of the contract's subject matter. 3.2 The damage or destruction must not have been either party's fault. 3.3 Death: Contract obligations generally survive the death of a party, unless the deceased party's contract obligations are non-delegable (usually only unique personal services are non-delegable). 3.4 Subsequent law or regulation (e.g., supervening illegality): if performance becomes illegal, there is excuse by impossibility. 4. Note on terminology 4.1 The MBE often uses the term "impossibility" broadly to encompass both impossibility and impracticability.
cards.frontPrompt: When can an unforeseen post-contract event excuse performance as impossibility or impracticability, and what are the typical qualifying events and limits?
cards.cloze: 1. In general 1.1 If an {{c1::unforeseen event}} occurs after {{c2::contract formation}} but before performance is complete, performance may be excused as {{c3::impossible}} or {{c4::impracticable}}. 2. Requirements 2.1 An unforeseen event, which {{c5::neither party assumed would occur}}, must make completing performance either: 2.1.1 {{c6::Impossible}}: performance is {{c7::objectively impossible}}; or 2.1.2 {{c8::Impracticable}}: performance is only possible with {{c9::extreme and unreasonable difficulty or expense}}. 3. Common unforeseen events 3.1 {{c10::Substantial damage or destruction}} of the contract's subject matter. 3.2 The damage or destruction must {{c11::not have been either party's fault}}. 3.3 {{c12::Death}}: Contract obligations generally survive the death of a party, unless the deceased party's contract obligations are {{c13::non-delegable}} (usually only {{c14::unique personal services}} are non-delegable). 3.4 {{c15::Subsequent law or regulation}} (e.g., supervening illegality): if performance becomes {{c16::illegal}}, there is excuse by impossibility. 4. Note on terminology 4.1 The {{c17::MBE}} often uses the term {{c18::"impossibility"}} broadly to encompass both impossibility and impracticability.
cards.easyContent: If an unforeseen event that neither party assumed would happen occurs after contract formation and makes performance objectively impossible or only possible with extreme and unreasonable difficulty or expense, performance may be excused as impossibility or impracticability.
cards.mediumContent: Impossibility or impracticability may excuse performance when, after contract formation but before performance is complete, an unforeseen event that neither party assumed would occur makes performance either objectively impossible or possible only with extreme and unreasonable difficulty or expense. Typical events include substantial destruction of the contract’s subject matter without fault of either party, death of a party with non-delegable (usually unique personal services) duties, and a subsequent law or regulation making performance illegal (supervening illegality). The MBE often uses “impossibility” broadly to include impracticability.
cards.hardContent: Where, after contract formation and before performance is complete, an unforeseen event occurs that neither party assumed would occur and that makes performance either objectively impossible or only possible with extreme and unreasonable difficulty or expense, a party’s duty to perform may be discharged under the doctrines of impossibility or impracticability. Common qualifying events include substantial damage or destruction of the contract’s subject matter, so long as the damage is not the fault of either party; death of a party whose contractual duties are non-delegable (typically unique personal services); and subsequent laws or regulations that render performance illegal (supervening illegality), which is treated as impossibility. On the MBE, the term “impossibility” is often used broadly to encompass both impossibility and impracticability.
cards.mnemonic: "FIND" for excuse: Formation, unforeseeable event, No fault, Duties Impossible/Difficult.
cards.clozeLite: Excuse for {{c1::impossibility or impracticability}} requires an {{c2::unforeseen event}} after formation, {{c3::no fault of either party}}, and performance becoming {{c4::objectively impossible or extremely difficult/expensive}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 030. Frustration of Purpose
cards.backPlain: 1. In general 1.1 A party's duty to perform under a contract may be discharged if an unforeseen event occurs that undermines (i.e., frustrates) one or both parties' principal purpose for entering into the contract. 2. Requirements (a contract may be discharged if): 2.1 An unexpected event destroys one or both parties' principal purpose for entering into the contract. 2.1.1 Whether performance is still possible after the event is irrelevant. 2.1.2 The issue is whether performance after the unforeseen event nullifies one or both parties' original purpose for the contract. 2.2 The unforeseen event is not the fault of the frustrated party. 2.3 The non-occurrence of the event was a basic assumption of the contract; it does not have to be a stated assumption in the contract. 3. Frustration of purpose vs. impossibility 3.1 Impossibility concerns duties specified in the contract (whether they can be performed at all). 3.2 Frustration of purpose concerns the reasons a party entered into the contract (whether the value or purpose of performance remains). 3.3 Example: A landlord rents space to B, a restaurateur, to open an ice cream parlor. If the property is destroyed by an earthquake, A and B are excused from performing due to impossibility. However, if the city passes an ordinance banning the sale of sweetened food, the contract's purpose is frustrated because A knew B intended to open an ice cream parlor.
cards.frontPrompt: When does frustration of purpose discharge contract duties, and how does it differ from impossibility?
cards.cloze: 1. In general 1.1 A party's duty to perform under a {{c1::contract}} may be discharged if an {{c2::unforeseen event}} occurs that {{c3::undermines (frustrates)}} one or both parties' {{c4::principal purpose}} for entering into the contract. 2. Requirements (a contract may be discharged if): 2.1 An {{c5::unexpected event}} {{c6::destroys}} one or both parties' principal purpose for entering into the contract. 2.1.1 Whether {{c7::performance is still possible}} after the event is {{c8::irrelevant}}. 2.1.2 The issue is whether performance after the unforeseen event {{c9::nullifies one or both parties' original purpose}} for the contract. 2.2 The unforeseen event is {{c10::not the fault of the frustrated party}}. 2.3 The {{c11::non-occurrence}} of the event was a {{c12::basic assumption}} of the contract; it does not have to be a stated assumption in the contract. 3. Frustration of purpose vs. impossibility 3.1 {{c13::Impossibility}} concerns {{c14::duties specified in the contract}} (whether they can be performed at all). 3.2 {{c15::Frustration of purpose}} concerns the {{c16::reasons a party entered into the contract}} (whether the value or purpose of performance remains). 3.3 Example: A landlord rents space to B, a restaurateur, to open an ice cream parlor. If the property is destroyed by an earthquake, A and B are excused from performing due to {{c17::impossibility}}. However, if the city passes an ordinance banning the sale of sweetened food, the contract's purpose is {{c18::frustrated}} because A knew B intended to open an ice cream parlor.
cards.easyContent: Frustration of purpose discharges duties when an unforeseen event, not caused by the frustrated party and whose non-occurrence was a basic assumption, destroys the contract’s principal purpose, even though performance is still physically possible. It focuses on loss of purpose, unlike impossibility, which focuses on whether performance can be done at all.
cards.mediumContent: A party’s duty may be discharged for frustration of purpose when an unforeseen, unexpected event occurs that destroys one or both parties’ principal purpose for entering into the contract. The event must not be the fault of the frustrated party, and the non-occurrence of the event must have been a basic (though not necessarily expressed) assumption of the contract. Whether physical performance is still possible is irrelevant; the question is whether performance after the event would nullify the parties’ original purpose. Frustration of purpose is distinct from impossibility: impossibility concerns whether the contractual duties can be performed, while frustration concerns whether the reasons or value of entering the contract remain, as illustrated by the ice cream parlor example.
cards.hardContent: Frustration of purpose discharges contractual duties where, after formation, an unforeseen and unexpected event occurs that is not the fault of the frustrated party and that destroys one or both parties’ principal purpose in entering into the contract. The non-occurrence of the event must have been a basic assumption of the contract, even if not expressly stated. The key inquiry is not whether performance is still physically possible but whether performance after the event would nullify the parties’ original purpose for the contract. This doctrine differs from impossibility: impossibility addresses whether the contractual duties can be performed at all (e.g., destruction of subject matter), whereas frustration of purpose addresses whether performance still has the intended value or purpose (e.g., a new law banning sweetened food frustrates a lease to open an ice cream parlor when the landlord knew the tenant’s plan).
cards.mnemonic: "PURPOSE": Performance Possible, Underlying Reason & Principal Objective Suddenly Evaporates.
cards.clozeLite: Frustration of purpose discharges duties when an {{c1::unforeseen event}} {{c2::destroys the contract’s principal purpose}}, and {{c3::non-occurrence of the event was a basic assumption}}, even though {{c4::performance is still physically possible}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 031. Rescission
cards.backPlain: 1. In general 1.1 Rescission of a contract serves to discharge duties under the contract. 1.2 Rescission occurs when the parties agree to rescind their contract. 1.3 The agreement to rescind is itself a new, binding contract supported by consideration, except in at-will employment (see below). 2. Limitations 2.1 Mutual rescission may generally be made orally. 2.2 Exception: A writing is required if the contract to be rescinded is subject to the Statute of Frauds and/or the UCC’s writing requirements. 2.3 Parties cannot rescind a contract if the rights of a third-party beneficiary have vested. 3. Unilateral rescission 3.1 Unilateral rescission occurs when only one party wants to rescind the contract. 3.2 It is usually only granted where there is a defense to contract enforcement or formation (e.g., mistake, misrepresentation, duress, lack of consideration, etc.). Unilateral rescission is typically a court-ordered remedy where there is a valid defense, and is distinguished from mutual rescission, where both parties agree to rescind. 4. At-will employment 4.1 An at-will employment agreement may be terminated (rescinded) by either party at any time. 4.2 A promise of "permanent" employment is generally considered to create an at-will employment relationship (i.e., it does not create lifetime employment).
cards.frontPrompt: What is rescission of a contract, when can parties mutually or unilaterally rescind, and what limits apply (including Statute of Frauds, third-party beneficiaries, and at-will employment)?
cards.cloze: 1. In general 1.1 {{c1::Rescission}} of a contract serves to {{c2::discharge duties}} under the contract. 1.2 Rescission occurs when the parties {{c3::agree to rescind}} their contract. 1.3 The agreement to rescind is itself a {{c4::new, binding contract}} supported by {{c5::consideration}}, except in {{c6::at-will employment}}. 2. Limitations 2.1 {{c7::Mutual rescission}} may generally be made {{c8::orally}}. 2.2 Exception: A {{c9::writing}} is required if the contract to be rescinded is subject to the {{c10::Statute of Frauds}} and/or the {{c11::UCC}} writing requirements. 2.3 Parties cannot rescind a contract if the rights of a {{c12::third-party beneficiary}} have {{c13::vested}}. 3. Unilateral rescission 3.1 {{c14::Unilateral rescission}} occurs when only one party wants to rescind the contract. 3.2 It is usually only granted where there is a {{c15::defense to contract enforcement or formation}} (e.g., {{c16::mistake, misrepresentation, duress, lack of consideration}}). Unilateral rescission is typically a {{c17::court-ordered remedy}} where there is a valid defense, and is distinguished from {{c18::mutual rescission}}, where both parties agree to rescind. 4. At-will employment 4.1 An {{c19::at-will employment}} agreement may be {{c20::terminated by either party at any time}}. 4.2 A promise of {{c21::"permanent" employment}} is generally considered to create an {{c22::at-will employment relationship}} (not lifetime employment).
cards.easyContent: Rescission is an agreement to cancel a contract and discharge both parties’ duties, which itself is a new contract supported by consideration (except in at-will employment). Mutual rescission is allowed unless the contract must be in writing or third-party beneficiary rights have vested; unilateral rescission generally requires a defense to formation or enforcement.
cards.mediumContent: Rescission discharges contractual duties when the parties agree to cancel their contract. The rescission agreement is itself a new, binding contract supported by consideration, except that at-will employment may be terminated by either party without separate consideration. Mutual rescission can usually be oral, but a writing is required if the contract being rescinded falls within the Statute of Frauds or UCC writing rules, and the parties cannot rescind once a third-party beneficiary’s rights have vested. Unilateral rescission, by contrast, occurs when only one party seeks to rescind and is typically granted only as a court-ordered remedy where there is a valid defense to contract formation or enforcement (such as mistake, misrepresentation, duress, or lack of consideration). At-will employment may be ended at any time by either party, and even a promise of "permanent" employment is usually construed as at-will, not as lifetime employment.
cards.hardContent: Rescission is the cancellation of a contract that discharges the parties’ remaining duties. It generally occurs through mutual agreement, and that agreement to rescind is itself a new, binding contract supported by consideration, except in the context of at-will employment, which either party may terminate without additional consideration. Mutual rescission may ordinarily be made orally, but a writing is required if the contract to be rescinded is subject to the Statute of Frauds or the UCC’s writing requirements. The parties may not rescind after a third-party beneficiary’s rights have vested. Unilateral rescission arises when only one party wishes to rescind and is usually available only through court order where there is a valid defense to formation or enforcement—such as mistake, misrepresentation, duress, or lack of consideration—distinguishing it from consensual mutual rescission. In the special case of at-will employment, either party may terminate the relationship at any time, and a promise of "permanent" employment is ordinarily interpreted as creating an at-will, not lifetime, relationship.
cards.mnemonic: "RAM": Rescission is an Agreement that Mutually discharges duties; unilateral rescission usually requires a defense and court involvement.
cards.clozeLite: Rescission {{c1::cancels a contract}} by {{c2::mutual agreement}} (a new contract with {{c3::consideration}}), limited by {{c4::Statute of Frauds}} and {{c5::vested third-party rights}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 032. Modification and Novation
cards.backPlain: Modification changes the terms of an existing contract, while a novation substitutes a new party and extinguishes the old party’s obligations. At common law, modification generally requires mutual assent and consideration (subject to a modern fair‑and‑unanticipated exception). Under the UCC, good‑faith modifications of contracts for the sale of goods do not require consideration but may need to be in writing under the Statute of Frauds or under a contract clause requiring written modifications. A novation is a new contract that substitutes a new party, requires a prior valid contract and the consent of all parties to a new valid contract that extinguishes the old duties between the original parties, and releases the original party from further contractual obligations and liability.
cards.frontPrompt: How do modification and novation differ in contract law, and what are the key requirements and effects of each (including under the UCC)?
cards.cloze: A {{c1::modification}} changes the terms of an existing contract, while a {{c2::novation}} substitutes a new party and extinguishes the old party’s obligations. At {{c3::common law}}, modification generally requires {{c4::mutual assent}} and {{c5::consideration}} (subject to a modern {{c6::fair‑and‑unanticipated circumstances}} exception). Under the {{c7::UCC}}, {{c8::good‑faith modifications}} do not require consideration but may need to be in {{c9::writing}} under the {{c10::Statute of Frauds}} or a contract clause requiring written modifications. A novation is a new contract that {{c11::substitutes a new party}}, {{c12::extinguishes duties between the original parties}}, and {{c13::releases the original party}} from further contractual obligations and liability.
cards.easyContent: A modification changes the terms of a contract; a novation swaps in a new party and releases the original one. Common law usually needs consideration for modification (with a narrow modern exception), while the UCC allows good‑faith modifications of goods contracts without consideration but may require a writing. A proper novation extinguishes the old party’s duties and liabilities.
cards.mediumContent: Modification is a change to existing contract terms. Common‑law modification requires mutual assent and consideration, although some courts enforce fair modifications caused by unanticipated circumstances without new consideration. Under the UCC, a good‑faith modification of a sale‑of‑goods contract is enforceable without consideration, but a writing is needed if the contract as modified is within the Statute of Frauds or if the contract requires written modifications. Novation is a new contract that substitutes a new party, requires a prior valid contract, agreement of all parties (including the new one), extinguishment of duties between the original parties, and a new valid contract; it releases the original party from performance and liability.
cards.hardContent: Modification and novation are distinct ways to alter contractual relationships. A modification is a subsequent change to the terms of an existing contract: the parties agree to discharge the original terms in favor of new ones, but the contract itself generally remains in place unless they clearly intend to discharge it entirely. At common law, modification requires mutual assent and consideration, typically found because each party limits rights under the original contract; under the modern trend, some courts enforce a fair modification prompted by unanticipated circumstances without new consideration. For contracts for the sale of goods, UCC Article 2 allows good‑faith modifications without consideration but may require a writing if the contract as modified falls within the Statute of Frauds or if the original agreement requires modifications to be in writing; parol evidence is admissible to prove such subsequent modifications. A novation is a new contract that substitutes a new party for an original party: it requires (1) a prior valid contract, (2) agreement of all parties, including the new party, to a new contract, (3) extinguishment of contractual duties between the original parties, and (4) a new valid and enforceable contract. The effect is that the original party is excused from performance and has no further contractual obligations or liability on the old contract.
cards.mnemonic: Novation: NEW party, NEW contract, NO old liability.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into three children: (1) common-law modification requirements, (2) UCC modification rules, and (3) novation definition, requirements, and effects.
cards.clozeLite: At common law, {{c1::modification}} needs {{c2::mutual assent and consideration}}; under the {{c3::UCC}}, a {{c4::good‑faith modification}} needs {{c5::no consideration but may need a writing}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 033. Accord and Satisfaction
cards.backPlain: 1. In general 1.1 In an accord and satisfaction, the parties to an existing contract agree to accept different performance in satisfaction of the original obligation. 2. Accord 2.1 An accord is a new agreement to accept alternative performance in lieu of the original performance obligation. 2.2 Consideration for the accord is generally required. 2.3 Consideration when the alternative performance is of lesser value 2.3.1 Consideration is sufficient if the new consideration is either: 2.3.1.1 Different from the originally bargained-for consideration. 2.3.1.2 To be paid or rendered to a third party. 2.3.1.3 Given to resolve a good-faith dispute concerning the original contract. 3. Satisfaction 3.1 Satisfaction is the performance of the accord agreement. 3.2 Satisfaction discharges both the original contract and the accord. 4. Effect of breach of an accord 4.1 If there has been no satisfaction (i.e., the accord is breached), the nonbreaching party may sue under either the original obligation or the accord.
cards.frontPrompt: What is an accord and satisfaction, what consideration is required for an accord (especially where performance is of lesser value), and what are the effects of satisfaction or breach?
cards.cloze: 1. In general 1.1 In an {{c1::accord and satisfaction}}, the parties to an existing contract agree to accept {{c2::different performance}} in satisfaction of the original obligation. 2. {{c3::Accord}} 2.1 An accord is a {{c4::new agreement to accept alternative performance}} in lieu of the original performance obligation. 2.2 {{c5::Consideration}} for the accord is generally required. 2.3 Consideration when the alternative performance is of lesser value 2.3.1 Consideration is sufficient if the new consideration is either: 2.3.1.1 {{c6::Different from the originally bargained-for consideration}}. 2.3.1.2 To be {{c7::paid or rendered to a third party}}. 2.3.1.3 Given to resolve a {{c8::good-faith dispute concerning the original contract}}. 3. {{c9::Satisfaction}} 3.1 Satisfaction is the {{c10::performance of the accord agreement}}. 3.2 Satisfaction {{c11::discharges both the original contract and the accord}}. 4. Effect of breach of an accord 4.1 If there has been no satisfaction (i.e., the accord is breached), the nonbreaching party may sue under either the {{c12::original obligation}} or the {{c13::accord}}.
cards.easyContent: Accord and satisfaction occurs when parties agree to accept different performance instead of the original one, and then that alternative performance is carried out. The accord is the new agreement; satisfaction is its performance, which discharges the original contract and the accord.
cards.mediumContent: Accord and satisfaction arises when parties agree to accept different performance in place of the original obligation. The accord is a new agreement that generally requires consideration, which may be found even if the new performance is of lesser value so long as it is different, paid to a third party, or resolves a good‑faith dispute. Satisfaction is performance of the accord and discharges both the original contract and the accord; if the accord is breached, the nonbreaching party may sue on either the original obligation or the accord.
cards.hardContent: Accord and satisfaction occurs when parties to an existing contract agree that a different performance will satisfy the original obligation. The accord is a new agreement to accept this alternative performance in lieu of the original performance duty and generally requires consideration. Even if the alternative performance is of lesser value, consideration is sufficient if the new consideration is different from what was originally bargained for, is to be paid or rendered to a third party, or is given to resolve a good‑faith dispute about the original contract. Satisfaction is the performance of the accord agreement. Once satisfaction occurs, both the original contract and the accord are discharged. If there is no satisfaction because the accord is breached, the nonbreaching party can elect to sue either on the original obligation or on the accord.
cards.mnemonic: A+S: Accord is Alternative agreement; Satisfaction Settles both obligations.
cards.clozeLite: An {{c1::accord}} is a new agreement for {{c2::different performance}} that usually requires {{c3::consideration}}; {{c4::satisfaction}} (performance of the accord) {{c5::discharges both the original contract and the accord}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 034. Third Party Beneficiaries
cards.backPlain: 1. In general 1.1 A third party that benefits from a contract entered into between other parties is a third-party beneficiary. 2. Types of third-party beneficiaries 2.1 Intended third-party beneficiaries (TPBs) 2.1.1 The parties to the contract intend for the TPB to benefit from the contract. 2.1.2 An intended TPB has rights under the contract. 2.2 Incidental third-party beneficiaries 2.2.1 An incidental TPB stands to benefit from the contract although not intended by the parties to the contract. 2.2.2 An incidental TPB has no rights under the contract. 3. Determining TPB status 3.1 Whether a TPB is an intended beneficiary under the contract is a question of fact. 3.2 Courts look at the following factors: 3.2.1 Is the TPB expressly designated in the contract? 3.2.2 Does the TPB directly benefit from some performance under the contract? 3.2.3 Does the TPB have rights under the contract? 3.2.4 Does the TPB stand in such a relationship to the promisee under the contract that an intent to benefit the third party can be inferred? 3.2.5 If the answer to any of the above is yes, it is more likely that the TPB is intended. 4. TPB characteristics 4.1 TPBs are not parties to the contract; they are merely beneficiaries. 4.2 Intended TPBs have a right to sue for breach of contract even though they are not parties to the contract. 4.3 Creditor TPBs: The benefit is conferred based on a debt owed by the promisee to the third-party beneficiary. 4.4 Donee TPBs: The benefit is conferred gratuitously (as a gift).
cards.frontPrompt: In contract law, who qualifies as a third-party beneficiary, how do courts determine if a TPB is intended or incidental, and what rights do different types of TPBs have?
cards.cloze: 1. In general 1.1 A third party that benefits from a contract entered into between other parties is a {{c1::third-party beneficiary}}. 2. Types of third-party beneficiaries 2.1 {{c2::Intended third-party beneficiaries (TPBs)}} 2.1.1 The parties to the contract {{c3::intend}} for the TPB to benefit from the contract. 2.1.2 An intended TPB has {{c4::rights under the contract}}. 2.2 {{c5::Incidental third-party beneficiaries}} 2.2.1 An incidental TPB stands to benefit from the contract although {{c6::not intended}} by the parties to the contract. 2.2.2 An incidental TPB has {{c7::no rights under the contract}}. 3. Determining TPB status 3.1 Whether a TPB is an intended beneficiary under the contract is a {{c8::question of fact}}. 3.2 Courts look at the following factors: 3.2.1 Is the TPB {{c9::expressly designated}} in the contract? 3.2.2 Does the TPB {{c10::directly benefit from some performance}} under the contract? 3.2.3 Does the TPB {{c11::have rights under the contract}}? 3.2.4 Does the TPB stand in such a {{c12::relationship to the promisee}} under the contract that an intent to benefit the third party can be inferred? 3.2.5 If the answer to any of the above is yes, it is more likely that the TPB is {{c13::intended}}. 4. TPB characteristics 4.1 TPBs are {{c14::not parties to the contract}}; they are merely beneficiaries. 4.2 {{c15::Intended}} TPBs have a right to {{c16::sue for breach of contract}} even though they are not parties to the contract. 4.3 {{c17::Creditor TPBs}}: The benefit is conferred based on a {{c18::debt owed by the promisee}} to the third-party beneficiary. 4.4 {{c19::Donee TPBs}}: The benefit is conferred {{c20::gratuitously (as a gift)}}.
