cards.easyContent: A third-party beneficiary is someone who benefits from a contract between other parties. Intended beneficiaries have contract rights (including the right to sue), while incidental beneficiaries do not.
cards.mediumContent: A third-party beneficiary is a nonparty who benefits from a contract. Intended TPBs are those the contracting parties meant to benefit, and they can enforce the contract; incidental TPBs only benefit by happenstance and have no rights. Courts decide if a TPB is intended based on factors such as express designation, direct benefit, stated rights, and the TPB’s relationship to the promisee. Intended TPBs include creditor beneficiaries (benefit based on a debt owed by the promisee) and donee beneficiaries (benefit conferred as a gift).
cards.hardContent: A third-party beneficiary is a third person who benefits from a contract entered into between others. Intended TPBs are those the contracting parties intend to benefit, and they have rights under the contract, including the ability to sue for breach even though they are not parties. Incidental beneficiaries, by contrast, merely stand to benefit without any intent by the parties and have no contract rights. Whether a TPB is intended is a question of fact. Courts look to whether the TPB is expressly designated, directly benefits from performance, is given rights under the contract, or stands in such a relationship to the promisee that an intent to benefit can be inferred; if any of these are present, the TPB is more likely intended. TPBs are not contracting parties but beneficiaries. Intended TPBs are further classified as creditor beneficiaries, where the benefit is conferred to satisfy a debt owed by the promisee, and donee beneficiaries, where the benefit is conferred gratuitously as a gift.
cards.mnemonic: TPB types: CID—Creditor, Intended, Donee beneficiaries.
cards.clozeLite: An {{c1::intended third-party beneficiary}} is a {{c2::nonparty the contracting parties meant to benefit}} and {{c3::can enforce the contract}}, unlike {{c4::incidental beneficiaries}} who {{c5::have no rights}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 035. RIghts of Third Party Beneficiaries
cards.backPlain: 1. In general 1.1 In order to enforce rights under a contract, a third-party beneficiary's (TPB's) rights must vest. 1.2 Vesting of rights occurs when the TPB does any of the following: 1.2.1 Accepts benefits: accepts the benefits of the contract in a manner requested by the parties to the contract. 1.2.2 Sues to enforce: brings suit to enforce the contract. 1.2.3 Detrimental reliance: detrimentally relies on the contract (i.e., materially changes position in justifiable reliance on the contract). 2. Enforcing the contract 2.1 A TPB can sue the promisor. 2.2 The promisor can assert any of his own defenses. 2.3 The promisee can sue the promisor at law and in equity for specific performance. 2.4 A creditor beneficiary can sue the promisee on the existing obligation between them. 2.5 A donee beneficiary may only sue the promisee if detrimental reliance exists.
cards.frontPrompt: When do a third-party beneficiary’s rights vest, and against whom (and under what limitations) may creditor and donee beneficiaries enforce the contract?
cards.cloze: 1. In general 1.1 In order to enforce rights under a contract, a {{c1::third-party beneficiary's (TPB's) rights must vest}}. 1.2 {{c2::Vesting}} of rights occurs when the TPB does any of the following: 1.2.1 {{c3::Accepts benefits}}: accepts the benefits of the contract in a manner requested by the parties to the contract. 1.2.2 {{c4::Sues to enforce}}: brings suit to enforce the contract. 1.2.3 {{c5::Detrimental reliance}}: detrimentally relies on the contract (i.e., materially changes position in justifiable reliance on the contract). 2. Enforcing the contract 2.1 A TPB can sue the {{c6::promisor}}. 2.2 The promisor can assert any of his own {{c7::defenses}}. 2.3 The {{c8::promisee}} can sue the promisor at law and in equity for {{c9::specific performance}}. 2.4 A {{c10::creditor beneficiary}} can sue the promisee on the {{c11::existing obligation}} between them. 2.5 A {{c12::donee beneficiary}} may only sue the promisee if {{c13::detrimental reliance}} exists.
cards.easyContent: A third-party beneficiary’s rights vest when the beneficiary accepts benefits, sues to enforce, or materially relies on the contract. After vesting, the TPB can sue the promisor, and creditor and donee beneficiaries have limited rights against the promisee.
cards.mediumContent: A TPB’s rights must vest before the TPB can enforce the contract. Vesting occurs when the TPB accepts the contract benefits as requested, brings suit to enforce, or materially changes position in justifiable reliance on the contract. Once vested, the TPB can sue the promisor, who may raise his own defenses; the promisee may also sue the promisor, including for specific performance. A creditor beneficiary may sue the promisee on their existing obligation, while a donee beneficiary may sue the promisee only if there is detrimental reliance.
cards.hardContent: To enforce rights under a contract, a third-party beneficiary’s rights must vest. Vesting occurs when the TPB either (1) accepts the benefits of the contract in the manner requested by the parties, (2) brings suit to enforce the contract, or (3) detrimentally relies on the contract by materially changing position in justifiable reliance. After vesting, a TPB may sue the promisor, and the promisor can assert any of his own defenses against the TPB. The promisee may still sue the promisor, both at law and in equity, including seeking specific performance. A creditor beneficiary can sue the promisee on the existing obligation between them. A donee beneficiary, by contrast, may sue the promisee only if the donee beneficiary has detrimentally relied on the promise.
cards.mnemonic: Vesting for TPBs is "A-S-R": Accept, Sue, Reliance.
cards.clozeLite: A TPB’s rights vest when they {{c1::accept benefits as requested}}, {{c2::bring suit to enforce}}, or {{c3::materially change position in justifiable reliance}}. Once vested, the TPB may {{c4::sue the promisor}}; a {{c5::creditor beneficiary}} may also sue the promisee on the existing obligation, while a {{c6::donee beneficiary}} may sue the promisee only if there is detrimental reliance.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 036. Assignment
cards.backPlain: 1. In general 1.1 An assignment is a transfer of rights under a contract to a third party after the contract is formed. 1.2 A party (the assignor) can assign rights under a contract to a third party (the assignee), who is then in a contractual relationship with the remaining party (the obligor). 1.3 Consideration is not required for an assignment, but an assignment without consideration is considered gratuitous. 1.4 The assignor can transfer only the rights the assignor has in a contract at the time of assignment. 2. Common law limitations 2.1 Common law bars any assignment that substantially changes the duties of the obligor. 2.2 Assignment of the right to payment is not a substantial change. 2.3 An assignment of rights fails if the obligor's risk is substantially altered. 3. Contractual limitations on assignment (contracts may contain non-assignment clauses) 3.1 "Non-assignment of contract" language bars delegation of the assignor's duties only; it does not prohibit assignment of rights. 3.2 "Non-assignment of rights" language bars the right to assign, but not the power to assign (i.e., an assignment is still effective between assignor and assignee, but the obligor may sue the assignor for breach). 3.3 Language stating that any assignment is void makes an assignment ineffective (i.e., the assignor has neither the power nor the right to assign).
cards.frontPrompt: What is an assignment of contract rights, what common-law and contractual limits apply, and how do different non-assignment clauses affect the validity and consequences of an assignment?
cards.cloze: 1. In general 1.1 An {{c1::assignment}} is a transfer of {{c2::rights under a contract}} to a third party after the contract is formed. 1.2 A party (the {{c3::assignor}}) can assign rights under a contract to a third party (the {{c4::assignee}}), who is then in a contractual relationship with the remaining party (the {{c5::obligor}}). 1.3 {{c6::Consideration}} is not required for an assignment, but an assignment without consideration is considered {{c7::gratuitous}}. 1.4 The assignor can transfer only the {{c8::rights the assignor has}} in a contract at the time of assignment. 2. Common law limitations 2.1 Common law bars any assignment that {{c9::substantially changes the duties of the obligor}}. 2.2 Assignment of the {{c10::right to payment}} is not a substantial change. 2.3 An assignment of rights fails if the obligor's {{c11::risk}} is substantially altered. 3. Contractual limitations on assignment (contracts may contain non-assignment clauses) 3.1 "{{c12::Non-assignment of contract}}" language bars {{c13::delegation of the assignor's duties only}}; it does not prohibit assignment of rights. 3.2 "{{c14::Non-assignment of rights}}" language bars the {{c15::right to assign, but not the power to assign}} (i.e., an assignment is still effective between assignor and assignee, but the obligor may sue the assignor for breach). 3.3 Language stating that any assignment is {{c16::void}} makes an assignment {{c17::ineffective}} (i.e., the assignor has neither the power nor the right to assign).
cards.easyContent: An assignment is a transfer of contract rights from the assignor to an assignee, creating a direct relationship between assignee and obligor. Assignments cannot substantially change the obligor’s duties or risk, and contract clauses can limit or void assignments.
cards.mediumContent: An assignment is the post-formation transfer of contract rights from an assignor to an assignee, who can then enforce those rights against the obligor. No consideration is required, though a no‑consideration assignment is gratuitous, and the assignor can transfer only the rights it currently has. At common law, assignments that substantially change the obligor’s duties or significantly increase the obligor’s risk are barred, but assigning the right to payment is generally allowed. Contract clauses can further limit assignments: “non-assignment of contract” bars delegation of duties only, “non-assignment of rights” bars the right but not the power to assign (so the assignment is effective but the assignor may be liable for breach), and language making assignments void renders attempted assignments ineffective.
cards.hardContent: An assignment is a transfer of contract rights to a third party after contract formation. The assignor transfers its rights to an assignee, who then stands in the assignor’s shoes and can assert those rights directly against the obligor. Consideration is not required for a valid assignment, but a no‑consideration assignment is gratuitous and may be more easily revoked; in all cases, the assignor can only transfer the rights it has at the time of assignment. At common law, assignments are invalid if they substantially change the obligor’s duties or significantly alter the obligor’s risk; by contrast, assigning the right to payment is not deemed a substantial change. Contracts may contain non-assignment clauses: language of “non-assignment of contract” restricts only delegation of duties and does not prevent assignment of rights; language of “non-assignment of rights” cuts off the right to assign but not the power, so any assignment remains effective between assignor and assignee but the obligor may sue the assignor for breach of that clause; and language declaring assignments "void" eliminates both the right and the power to assign, making any attempted assignment ineffective.
cards.mnemonic: A-A-O: Assignor to Assignee against ObligOR; contract=duties, rights=breach, void=no assignment.
cards.clozeLite: An {{c1::assignment}} is a post‑formation transfer of {{c2::contract rights}} from {{c3::assignor}} to {{c4::assignee}}, and cannot {{c5::substantially change the obligor’s duties or risk}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 037. Revocability and Enforcement of Assignments
cards.backPlain: 1. Revocability of assignments: 1.1 Assignments made for consideration are irrevocable. 1.2 Gratuitous assignments are generally revocable. 1.3 Exception: a gratuitous assignment becomes irrevocable if either: 1.3.1 The obligor has already performed. 1.3.2 The assignee has received a written claim or tangible object signifying the right to collect (e.g., stock certificate). 1.3.3 The assignee has detrimentally relied on the assignment (estoppel). 2. Assignee's right to sue: 2.1 Against obligor: The assignee can sue the obligor for non-performance, and the obligor can raise any defense to the contract that could have been raised against the assignor. 2.2 Against assignor: The assignee can sue the assignor for breach of any of the assignor's implied warranties, including: 2.2.1 There was no prior assignment of the same right. 2.2.2 The right to assign was not subject to defenses. 2.2.3 The assignor will not interfere with the assigned right.
cards.frontPrompt: When is an assignment revocable or irrevocable, and what rights does the assignee have to sue the obligor and assignor?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Revocability of assignments}}: 1.1 Assignments made {{c2::for consideration}} are {{c3::irrevocable}}. 1.2 {{c4::Gratuitous assignments}} are generally {{c5::revocable}}. 1.3 Exception: a gratuitous assignment becomes irrevocable if either: 1.3.1 The {{c6::obligor has already performed}}. 1.3.2 The assignee has received a {{c7::written claim or tangible object signifying the right to collect}} (e.g., stock certificate). 1.3.3 The assignee has {{c8::detrimentally relied}} on the assignment ({{c9::estoppel}}). 2. {{c10::Assignee's right to sue}}: 2.1 Against {{c11::obligor}}: The assignee can sue the obligor for {{c12::non-performance}}, and the obligor can raise any {{c13::defense to the contract that could have been raised against the assignor}}. 2.2 Against {{c14::assignor}}: The assignee can sue the assignor for breach of any of the assignor's {{c15::implied warranties}}, including: 2.2.1 There was {{c16::no prior assignment of the same right}}. 2.2.2 The right to assign was {{c17::not subject to defenses}}. 2.2.3 The assignor will {{c18::not interfere with the assigned right}}.
cards.easyContent: Assignments made for consideration are irrevocable, while gratuitous assignments are generally revocable unless certain events (like performance, delivery of a claim document, or detrimental reliance) make them irrevocable. The assignee can sue the obligor for non-performance and the assignor for breach of implied warranties about the assignment.
cards.mediumContent: Assignments supported by consideration are irrevocable, while gratuitous assignments are normally revocable unless the obligor has already performed, the assignee has received a written claim or tangible object evidencing the right, or the assignee detrimentally relies. The assignee may sue the obligor for non-performance (subject to any defenses the obligor had against the assignor) and may sue the assignor for breach of implied warranties that there was no prior assignment, that the right is not subject to defenses, and that the assignor will not interfere.
cards.hardContent: Assignments made for consideration are irrevocable; gratuitous assignments are generally revocable. A gratuitous assignment becomes irrevocable if the obligor has already performed, the assignee has received a written claim or tangible object signifying the right to collect (such as a stock certificate), or the assignee has detrimentally relied on the assignment (estoppel). The assignee can sue the obligor for non-performance of the assigned obligation, but the obligor may assert any contract defenses that could have been raised against the assignor. The assignee may also sue the assignor for breach of implied warranties, including that there was no prior assignment of the same right, that the right is not subject to defenses, and that the assignor will not interfere with the assignee's enjoyment of the right.
cards.mnemonic: GIVE: Given performance, Issued writing, assignee’s reliance Expense.
cards.clozeLite: {{c1::Assignments for consideration}} are {{c2::irrevocable}}; {{c3::gratuitous assignments}} are usually {{c4::revocable unless performed, written evidence, or detrimental reliance}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 038. Delegation
cards.backPlain: 1. In general: 1.1 A delegation occurs when one party to a contract (the delegator) delegates the duties she owes to another party to the contract (the obligee) to a third party (the delegatee). 1.2 The obligee must generally accept performance from the delegatee. 1.3 Only duties may be delegated, whereas rights are transferred to a third party via assignment. 2. Liability: 2.1 The delegator remains liable for the delegatee's performance. 2.2 The obligee may sue the delegator for non-performance by the delegatee. 2.3 The obligee may sue the delegatee only if the delegatee has assumed the duties of the entire contract. 3. Exceptions (duties are non-delegable if): 3.1 The duties involve personal judgment or skill. 3.2 Delegation would materially change the obligee's expectancy under the contract. 3.3 The contract prohibits delegation. 3.4 Delegation is prohibited by statute or public policy. 4. Delegation vs. novation: 4.1 A novation arises when all parties agree that a substitute person will take over duties under the contract. 4.2 A delegation occurs when one party unilaterally decides to delegate duties to a third party, but the original obligor (delegator) remains liable absent novation.
cards.frontPrompt: What is delegation of contractual duties, when is it permitted, who remains liable, and how does it differ from a novation?
cards.cloze: 1. In general: 1.1 A {{c1::delegation}} occurs when one party to a contract (the {{c2::delegator}}) delegates the {{c3::duties}} she owes to another party to the contract (the {{c4::obligee}}) to a third party (the {{c5::delegatee}}). 1.2 The obligee must generally {{c6::accept performance from the delegatee}}. 1.3 Only {{c7::duties}} may be delegated, whereas {{c8::rights}} are transferred to a third party via {{c9::assignment}}. 2. {{c10::Liability}}: 2.1 The delegator {{c11::remains liable}} for the delegatee's performance. 2.2 The obligee may sue the {{c12::delegator}} for {{c13::non-performance by the delegatee}}. 2.3 The obligee may sue the {{c14::delegatee}} only if the delegatee has {{c15::assumed the duties of the entire contract}}. 3. Exceptions (duties are {{c16::non-delegable}} if): 3.1 The duties involve {{c17::personal judgment or skill}}. 3.2 Delegation would {{c18::materially change the obligee's expectancy}} under the contract. 3.3 The contract {{c19::prohibits delegation}}. 3.4 Delegation is prohibited by {{c20::statute or public policy}}. 4. {{c21::Delegation vs. novation}}: 4.1 A {{c22::novation}} arises when all parties agree that a substitute person will take over duties under the contract. 4.2 A delegation occurs when one party unilaterally decides to delegate duties to a third party, but the original obligor (delegator) {{c23::remains liable absent novation}}.
cards.easyContent: Delegation is when a party transfers her contractual duties—not rights—to a third party, but the original obligor generally remains liable unless there is a novation. Duties involving personal skill, material change in expectancy, or barred by contract or law cannot be delegated.
cards.mediumContent: Delegation occurs when a delegator transfers her contractual duties to a delegatee, and the obligee usually must accept performance from the delegatee. Only duties, not rights, are delegated. The delegator remains liable, and the obligee may sue the delegator for the delegatee's non-performance and may sue the delegatee only if the delegatee has assumed the entire contract. Duties are non-delegable if they involve personal judgment or skill, materially change the obligee's expectancy, are contractually prohibited, or are prohibited by statute or public policy. A novation, unlike delegation, is an agreement by all parties that the substitute party takes over and the original obligor is released.
cards.hardContent: Delegation is the transfer of contractual duties from a delegator to a delegatee, owed to an obligee. The obligee generally must accept performance from the delegatee, but only duties can be delegated; contractual rights are transferred by assignment. The delegator remains liable for the delegatee’s performance, and the obligee may sue the delegator for the delegatee’s non-performance and may also sue the delegatee if the delegatee has assumed the duties of the entire contract. Duties are non-delegable where they involve personal judgment or skill, where delegation would materially change the obligee’s expectancy under the contract, where the contract prohibits delegation, or where statute or public policy forbids it. A novation, by contrast, is a new agreement in which all parties consent to a substitute person taking over the duties and the original obligor is discharged; mere delegation without novation does not release the delegator.
cards.mnemonic: Delegation = Duties kept liable; Novation = New party, old released.
cards.clozeLite: In {{c1::delegation}}, a party transfers {{c2::contractual duties (not rights)}} to a third party; the {{c3::delegator remains liable}} unless there is a {{c4::novation releasing the original obligor}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 039. Standard Money Damages
cards.backPlain: 1. Expectation damages: 1.1 Standard measure of money damages. 1.2 Puts the party in the economic position they would be in if the contract had been performed (i.e., if the breach never occurred). 1.3 When in doubt, select the remedy that most closely gives the damaged party what they would have received absent the breach. 2. Reliance damages: 2.1 Alternative measure used when expectation damages are too speculative. 2.2 Designed to compensate the plaintiff based on the value of their performance and put them in the position they would have been in had the contract never been formed. 3. Consequential damages: 3.1 Foreseeable losses indirectly resulting from a breach (e.g., lost profits); recoverable if: 3.1.1 The damages are a foreseeable result of the breach. 3.1.2 When the contract was formed, the defendant had reason to know the plaintiff would suffer special, unpreventable, or unexpected damages in the event of a breach. 3.2 Under the UCC, only buyers can recover consequential damages. 4. Incidental damages: 4.1 Commercially reasonable expenses incurred by the non-breaching party in UCC contracts (e.g., costs of inspecting, returning, storing, or reselling goods). 5. Duty to mitigate: 5.1 The plaintiff cannot recover reasonably avoidable damages, but may recover the costs of reasonably avoiding further damages.
cards.frontPrompt: What are expectation, reliance, consequential, and incidental damages in contract law, and what is the plaintiff’s duty to mitigate?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Expectation damages}}: 1.1 {{c2::Standard measure}} of money damages. 1.2 Puts the party in the economic position they would be in if the contract had been {{c3::performed}} (i.e., if the breach never occurred). 1.3 When in doubt, select the remedy that most closely gives the damaged party what they would have received {{c4::absent the breach}}. 2. {{c5::Reliance damages}}: 2.1 {{c6::Alternative measure}} used when expectation damages are {{c7::too speculative}}. 2.2 Designed to compensate the plaintiff based on the {{c8::value of their performance}} and put them in the position they would have been in had the contract {{c9::never been formed}}. 3. {{c10::Consequential damages}}: 3.1 {{c11::Foreseeable losses indirectly resulting}} from a breach (e.g., lost profits); recoverable if: 3.1.1 The damages are a {{c12::foreseeable result}} of the breach. 3.1.2 When the contract was formed, the defendant had {{c13::reason to know}} the plaintiff would suffer {{c14::special, unpreventable, or unexpected damages}} in the event of a breach. 3.2 Under the {{c15::UCC}}, only {{c16::buyers}} can recover consequential damages. 4. {{c17::Incidental damages}}: 4.1 {{c18::Commercially reasonable expenses}} incurred by the non-breaching party in UCC contracts (e.g., costs of inspecting, returning, storing, or reselling goods). 5. {{c19::Duty to mitigate}}: 5.1 The plaintiff cannot recover {{c20::reasonably avoidable damages}}, but may recover the {{c21::costs of reasonably avoiding further damages}}.
cards.easyContent: Expectation damages are the standard measure that put the plaintiff where they would be if the contract had been performed; reliance damages put them where they would be if the contract had never been made. Consequential and incidental damages cover certain foreseeable and commercially reasonable additional losses, and the plaintiff must mitigate avoidable damages.
cards.mediumContent: Expectation damages put the injured party in the position they would have occupied had the contract been fully performed. Reliance damages are an alternative when expectation damages are too speculative and reimburse the value of the plaintiff’s performance, restoring them to their pre-contract position. Consequential damages are foreseeable, indirect losses (such as lost profits) recoverable when they were foreseeable and the defendant had reason to know of special risks; under the UCC, only buyers may recover consequential damages. Incidental damages are commercially reasonable expenses in UCC contracts, such as inspection, return, storage, or resale costs. The plaintiff must mitigate by avoiding reasonably preventable losses but can recover reasonable mitigation costs.
cards.hardContent: Expectation damages are the standard contract remedy and aim to put the injured party in the economic position they would have occupied if the contract had been performed, selecting the measure that most closely gives them the benefit of the bargain. Reliance damages are an alternative where expectation damages are too speculative and compensate the plaintiff based on the value of their performance, placing them in the position they would have been in had the contract never been made. Consequential damages are foreseeable, indirect losses (e.g., lost profits) recoverable only if they are a foreseeable result of the breach and, at contract formation, the defendant had reason to know the plaintiff would suffer special, unpreventable, or unexpected losses in the event of breach; under the UCC, only buyers may recover them. Incidental damages in UCC cases are commercially reasonable expenses incurred by the non-breaching party, such as expenses of inspecting, returning, storing, or reselling goods. The plaintiff has a duty to mitigate and cannot recover damages that could have been reasonably avoided, though they may recover reasonable mitigation costs.
cards.mnemonic: Think "ERCI": Expectation, Reliance, Consequential, Incidental damages.
cards.clozeLite: Contract money damages: {{c1::expectation}} (benefit of the bargain), {{c2::reliance}} (pre-contract position), {{c3::consequential}} (foreseeable indirect losses), {{c4::incidental}} (commercially reasonable expenses), plus duty to {{c5::mitigate reasonably avoidable losses}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 040. Non Monetary Damages
cards.backPlain: 1. In general: 1.1 In the event of a breach, non-monetary remedies (equitable relief) may be available if money damages are unavailable or inadequate. 2. Specific performance and related equitable relief: 2.1 Specific performance is usually available only for contracts involving real estate or unique goods (e.g., antiques, art). 2.2 For service contracts, courts may issue injunctions preventing breach (e.g., injunction enforcing a non-compete clause), but will not order specific performance of personal services. 3. Rescission: 3.1 Rescission is cancellation of a contract. 3.2 The purpose is to restore the parties to their positions before the contract was made. 3.3 Rescission often arises where there is mistake, misrepresentation, duress, or some other defense to contract enforcement or formation. 4. Reformation: 4.1 Reformation is a remedy whereby a contract is changed so that it reflects the parties' original intent. 4.2 It can arise where there is a mistake in contract formation such that the final written contract varies from a prior agreement of the parties. 4.3 It can also arise where the contract is inaccurate due to misrepresentation. 5. Reclamation (UCC): 5.1 In UCC contracts, unpaid sellers may stop delivery or reclaim goods from an insolvent buyer. 5.2 An unpaid seller generally cannot reclaim goods from subsequent good-faith purchasers for value.
cards.frontPrompt: What non-monetary (equitable) remedies are available for breach of contract, including specific performance, rescission, reformation, and reclamation?
cards.cloze: 1. In general: 1.1 In the event of a breach, {{c1::non-monetary remedies}} ({{c2::equitable relief}}) may be available if money damages are {{c3::unavailable or inadequate}}. 2. {{c4::Specific performance}} and related equitable relief: 2.1 Specific performance is usually available only for contracts involving {{c5::real estate}} or {{c6::unique goods}} (e.g., antiques, art). 2.2 For {{c7::service contracts}}, courts may issue {{c8::injunctions}} preventing breach (e.g., enforcing a non-compete clause), but will not order {{c9::specific performance of personal services}}. 3. {{c10::Rescission}}: 3.1 Rescission is {{c11::cancellation of a contract}}. 3.2 The purpose is to {{c12::restore the parties to their pre-contract positions}}. 3.3 Rescission often arises where there is {{c13::mistake, misrepresentation, duress}}, or some other {{c14::defense to contract formation or enforcement}}. 4. {{c15::Reformation}}: 4.1 Reformation is a remedy whereby a contract is {{c16::changed so that it reflects the parties' original intent}}. 4.2 It can arise where there is a {{c17::mistake in contract formation}} such that the final written contract varies from a prior agreement of the parties. 4.3 It can also arise where the contract is inaccurate due to {{c18::misrepresentation}}. 5. {{c19::Reclamation}} (UCC): 5.1 In UCC contracts, {{c20::unpaid sellers}} may {{c21::stop delivery or reclaim goods}} from an {{c22::insolvent buyer}}. 5.2 An unpaid seller generally {{c23::cannot reclaim goods from subsequent good-faith purchasers for value}}.
cards.easyContent: When money damages are inadequate, courts may grant equitable remedies such as specific performance of real estate or unique goods contracts, rescission to unwind a contract, reformation to correct a writing to match the parties’ intent, and UCC reclamation allowing unpaid sellers to reclaim goods from an insolvent buyer.
cards.mediumContent: Equitable relief is available when legal (money) damages are inadequate. Specific performance is typically limited to contracts for real estate and unique goods, while service contracts may be enforced through negative injunctions (like non-competes) but not by ordering personal service. Rescission cancels the contract and restores the parties to their pre-contract positions, often where there is mistake, misrepresentation, duress, or another contract defense. Reformation alters the written contract to reflect the parties’ original intent where a drafting mistake or misrepresentation has made the writing inaccurate. Under the UCC, unpaid sellers can stop delivery or reclaim goods from an insolvent buyer, but generally not from subsequent good-faith purchasers for value.
cards.hardContent: Non-monetary remedies (equitable relief) may be granted where money damages are unavailable or inadequate. Specific performance is an order to perform the contract and is usually confined to contracts for real estate or unique goods such as antiques or art; for service contracts, courts may instead grant injunctions preventing breach, such as enforcing a non-compete clause, but will not compel personal services. Rescission cancels the contract to restore the parties to their pre-contract positions and commonly arises where there is mistake, misrepresentation, duress, or another defense to contract formation or enforcement. Reformation is an equitable remedy that changes the written contract to reflect the parties’ actual agreement, such as where a drafting mistake causes the writing to differ from a prior agreement or where misrepresentation has made the writing inaccurate. Under the UCC, unpaid sellers may stop delivery or reclaim goods from an insolvent buyer, but they generally cannot reclaim from subsequent good-faith purchasers for value.
cards.mnemonic: 4 R's: Real estate goods, Rescission, Reformation, Reclamation.
cards.clozeLite: Non-monetary remedies include {{c1::specific performance}} for {{c2::real estate or unique goods}}, {{c3::rescission}}, {{c4::reformation}}, and UCC {{c5::reclamation from an insolvent buyer}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.topic: Restitution, Liquidated Damages, and Duty to Mitigate
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 041. Restitution, Liquidated Damages, and Duty to Mitigate
cards.front: Restitution, Liquidated Damages, and Duty to Mitigate
cards.backPlain: 1. In general: 1.1 Restitution and liquidated damages are additional types of damages that may be available. 2. Restitution damages: 2.1 Restitution arises where a party has been unjustly enriched. 2.2 Restitution is awarded based on the value of the benefit wrongfully conferred. 2.3 A party cannot recover both expectation damages and restitution damages for the same loss. 3. Liquidated damages: 3.1 Liquidated damages are agreed-upon contract provisions that stipulate specified damages upon the occurrence of a breach. 3.2 Requirements: A liquidated damages provision is valid only if: 3.2.1 Damages were difficult to project at the time of contract formation. 3.2.2 The amount is a reasonable estimate of probable actual damages and not a penalty. 4. Duty to mitigate: 4.1 The plaintiff cannot recover reasonably avoidable damages; for example, the plaintiff must refrain from incurring additional losses after receiving notice of breach. 4.2 The plaintiff may recover the reasonable cost of mitigation (e.g., the cost to avoid incurring further damages). 4.3 Employment contracts: The plaintiff’s damages can be reduced if the defendant can show a comparable job in the same locale was available to the plaintiff and the plaintiff failed to take it. 4.4 The defendant bears the burden of showing the plaintiff's failure to mitigate.
cards.frontPrompt: What are restitution and liquidated damages in contract law, and how does the duty to mitigate limit a plaintiff’s recovery?
cards.cloze: 1. In general: 1.1 {{c1::Restitution}} and {{c2::liquidated damages}} are additional types of damages that may be available. 2. {{c3::Restitution damages}}: 2.1 Restitution arises where a party has been {{c4::unjustly enriched}}. 2.2 Restitution is awarded based on the {{c5::value of the benefit wrongfully conferred}}. 2.3 A party cannot recover both {{c6::expectation damages}} and {{c7::restitution damages}} for the same loss. 3. {{c8::Liquidated damages}}: 3.1 Liquidated damages are {{c9::agreed-upon contract provisions}} that stipulate specified damages upon breach. 3.2 Requirements: A liquidated damages provision is valid only if: 3.2.1 Damages were {{c10::difficult to project at the time of contract formation}}. 3.2.2 The amount is a {{c11::reasonable estimate of probable actual damages}} and not a {{c12::penalty}}. 4. {{c13::Duty to mitigate}}: 4.1 The plaintiff cannot recover {{c14::reasonably avoidable damages}}; for example, the plaintiff must refrain from incurring additional losses after receiving notice of breach. 4.2 The plaintiff may recover the {{c15::reasonable cost of mitigation}} (e.g., the cost to avoid incurring further damages). 4.3 {{c16::Employment contracts}}: The plaintiff’s damages can be reduced if the defendant can show a {{c17::comparable job in the same locale}} was available to the plaintiff and the plaintiff failed to take it. 4.4 The defendant bears the {{c18::burden of showing}} the plaintiff's failure to mitigate.
cards.easyContent: Restitution prevents unjust enrichment by awarding the value of a benefit conferred, while liquidated damages are pre-agreed sums valid only if they reasonably estimate hard-to-predict losses and are not penalties. The plaintiff must mitigate by avoiding reasonably avoidable losses, though they can recover reasonable mitigation costs.
cards.mediumContent: Restitution is available when one party has been unjustly enriched and awards the value of the benefit wrongfully conferred; a party cannot double-recover both restitution and expectation damages for the same loss. Liquidated damages are contractual clauses fixing damages in advance, enforceable only if actual damages were difficult to estimate at formation and the amount is a reasonable forecast rather than a penalty. The duty to mitigate bars recovery of reasonably avoidable damages but allows recovery of reasonable mitigation costs. In employment cases, damages are reduced if the defendant shows a comparable job in the same locale was available and the plaintiff unreasonably refused it; the defendant bears the burden of proving failure to mitigate.
cards.hardContent: Restitution is an unjust enrichment remedy that arises when a party has conferred a benefit on another under circumstances making it unjust for the recipient to retain it; recovery is measured by the value of the benefit wrongfully conferred, and a party may not recover both restitution and expectation damages for the same loss. Liquidated damages clauses set a specific damage amount for breach and are enforceable only when, at contract formation, actual damages were difficult to forecast and the amount chosen is a reasonable estimate of probable actual loss rather than an impermissible penalty. The duty to mitigate limits recovery by precluding damages that the plaintiff could have reasonably avoided after breach, although the plaintiff may recover reasonable mitigation expenses. In employment contracts, the employer can reduce the employee’s damages by showing that a comparable job in the same locale was available and the employee failed to accept it; the defendant bears the burden of proving lack of mitigation.
cards.mnemonic: Liquidated = Legit if Loss is Lousy to predict and not a Penalty.
cards.clozeLite: Contract {{c1::restitution}} prevents {{c2::unjust enrichment}}; {{c3::liquidated damages}} must be a {{c4::reasonable forecast of difficult-to-estimate loss}}, not a {{c5::penalty}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 042. Damages for UCC Contracts
cards.backPlain: Under the UCC, damages in a sales contract depend on: (1) who breached (seller or buyer); and (2) who has the goods (buyer keeps, returns, or seller retains). For a seller's breach, the buyer's damages differ based on whether the buyer keeps the goods (usually value-as-warranted minus value-as-delivered) or returns/never receives them (usually market-minus-contract or cover-minus-contract, whichever is higher). For a buyer's breach, the seller's damages differ based on whether the buyer has the goods (often the contract price) or the seller keeps the goods (usually contract-minus-market or contract-minus-resale plus lost profits). Separate rules govern conversion (FMV at time of conversion), and in all cases both buyers and sellers may also recover additional lost profits and other incidental or consequential damages where available.
cards.frontPrompt: Under the UCC, how are damages for breach of a sales contract generally structured based on who breached and who has the goods, and what additional types of damages may be available?
cards.cloze: Under the UCC, damages in a sales contract depend on: (1) who {{c1::breached}} ({{c2::seller}} or {{c3::buyer}}); and (2) who {{c4::has the goods}} (buyer keeps, returns, or seller retains). For a {{c5::seller's breach}}, the buyer's damages differ based on whether the buyer {{c6::keeps the goods}} (usually {{c7::value-as-warranted minus value-as-delivered}}) or {{c8::returns/never receives}} them (usually {{c9::market-minus-contract}} or {{c10::cover-minus-contract}}, whichever is higher). For a {{c11::buyer's breach}}, the seller's damages differ based on whether the buyer {{c12::has the goods}} (often the {{c13::contract price}}) or the {{c14::seller keeps the goods}} (usually {{c15::contract-minus-market}} or {{c16::contract-minus-resale plus lost profits}}). Separate rules govern {{c17::conversion}} ({{c18::FMV at time of conversion}}), and in all cases both buyers and sellers may also recover additional {{c19::lost profits}} and other {{c20::incidental or consequential damages}} where available.
cards.easyContent: Under the UCC, damages turn on who breached and who has the goods. For seller breaches, buyers usually recover market/cover-based damages or value-as-warranted minus value-as-delivered. For buyer breaches, sellers recover the contract price or contract-minus-market/resale plus lost profits. Conversion uses FMV at the time, and both sides can also claim incidental, consequential, and lost-profit damages.
cards.mediumContent: UCC damages are organized by: (1) seller breach vs. buyer breach; and (2) whether the buyer or seller has the goods. For seller breaches, buyers either: (a) keep the goods and recover the difference between the value of perfectly delivered goods and goods as delivered/ordered; or (b) do not keep them and recover the higher of market-minus-contract or cover-minus-contract. For buyer breaches, if the buyer has the goods the seller often recovers the contract price; if the seller has the goods, the seller recovers either contract-minus-market or contract-minus-resale plus lost profits. Conversion damages equal FMV at the time of conversion, and both parties may also recover lost profits and other incidental or consequential losses.
cards.hardContent: Under the UCC, damages are structured by breach type and possession of the goods. For a seller's breach, if the buyer keeps the goods, the buyer recovers the difference between the value of perfectly delivered goods and the value of the goods as actually delivered or as ordered, and is not charged for any increased value where the nonconforming goods are superior. If the buyer does not keep the goods (seller retains or buyer returns them), the buyer's damages are the higher of: (1) FMV at the time of breach minus the contract price; or (2) cover or replacement costs minus the contract price. For a buyer's breach, if the buyer has the goods (kept, destroyed after risk passes, or returned but not resaleable), the seller's damages are typically the contract price. If the seller has the goods, the seller's damages are either: (1) contract price minus market price at the time of delivery; or (2) contract price minus resale price plus provable lost profits. Conversion is compensated by the FMV of the goods at the time of conversion. In all these scenarios, both buyers and sellers may also recover lost profits and other losses caused by breach or nonconformance, including incidental and consequential damages where the UCC allows them.
cards.mnemonic: WHO-WHO-MIC: Who breached, Who has, Market/cover, Incidental, Consequential.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into five children: (1) seller breach when buyer keeps goods, (2) seller breach when seller keeps/retakes goods, (3) buyer breach when buyer has goods, (4) buyer breach when seller has goods, and (5) conversion and additional incidental/consequential damages.
cards.clozeLite: UCC damages turn on {{c1::who breached}} and {{c2::who has the goods}}: buyer vs. seller breach plus {{c3::market/cover or contract-minus-market/resale}} and {{c4::incidental/consequential and lost profits}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 004-1. Offer – Definition and Core Elements
cards.backPlain: 1. Definition of an offer (common law): 1.1. An offer is an objective manifestation of a present intent to contract. 1.2. It must be such that a reasonable offeree would believe the communication invites acceptance. 2. Core elements of an offer: 2.1. Promise, undertaking, or commitment: 2.1.1. There must be some commitment by the offeror to enter into a contract (not merely a prediction or opinion). 2.2. Definite and certain terms: 2.2.1. Terms must be sufficiently definite that a court can enforce the contract. 2.2.2. Typically includes key terms such as quantity, time for performance, price, subject matter, and parties. 2.2.3. Vague terms or mere “agreements to agree” or negotiations are insufficient. 2.3. Communication to an identified offeree: 2.3.1. The offer must be actually communicated to the offeree. 2.3.2. The offeree must know of the offer and have the power to accept it.
cards.frontPrompt: What is an offer under common law, and what are its core elements (promise, definite terms, and communication)?
cards.cloze: An offer is an {{c1::objective manifestation}} of a {{c2::present intent to contract}} such that a {{c3::reasonable offeree}} would believe the communication {{c4::invites acceptance}}. The core elements are: - {{c5::Promise, undertaking, or commitment}} by the offeror; - {{c6::Definite and certain terms}} sufficient for a court to {{c7::enforce the contract}} (typically including {{c8::quantity, time for performance, price, subject matter, and parties}}); and - {{c9::Communication}} of the offer to an {{c10::identified offeree}} who {{c11::knows of the offer}} and has the {{c12::power to accept}}.
cards.easyContent: An offer is an outward signal that a person presently intends to contract. It requires (1) a real commitment to be bound, (2) terms clear enough for a court to enforce, and (3) communication of those terms to a specific offeree who knows of them and can accept.
cards.mediumContent: An offer is an objective manifestation of a present intent to contract that would lead a reasonable offeree to think acceptance will form a contract. It has three core elements: (1) a promise, undertaking, or commitment by the offeror; (2) definite and certain terms—such as quantity, time for performance, price, subject matter, and parties—so a court can enforce the agreement; and (3) communication of the offer to an identified offeree who knows of it and thereby has the legal power to accept.
cards.hardContent: Under common law, an offer is an objective manifestation of a present intent to contract such that a reasonable offeree would understand that acceptance will create a binding agreement. The offer must include (1) a promise, undertaking, or commitment by the offeror, rather than mere opinions or puffery; (2) sufficiently definite and certain terms—typically including quantity, time for performance, price, subject matter, and the parties—so that a court can determine if a breach has occurred and what the remedy should be, with vague or incomplete "agreements to agree" or negotiations being insufficient; and (3) actual communication of the offer to an identified offeree, who must know of the offer in order to hold the power of acceptance.
cards.mnemonic: Offer = CPC: Commitment, Precision, Communication.
cards.clozeLite: An offer is an {{c1::objective manifestation of present intent to contract}} with {{c2::definite and certain terms}} {{c3::communicated to an identified offeree}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 004-2. Offer – Objective Intent and Advertisements
cards.backPlain: 1. Objective manifestation of intent: 1.1. Standard: Would a reasonable person in the position of the offeree believe the communication is an offer inviting acceptance? 1.2. Subjective intent of the offeror is generally irrelevant if the outward expression indicates an offer. 2. Vague terms and negotiations: 2.1. Vague or incomplete terms are usually treated as preliminary negotiations, not offers. 2.2. Mere “terms of negotiation,” “price quotes,” or “invitations to deal” do not create power of acceptance. 3. Advertisements and similar communications: 3.1. General rule: Advertisements, catalogs, circulars, and price quotations are not offers but invitations to negotiate. 3.2. Exception: An advertisement may be an offer if it is: 3.2.1. Highly specific as to quantity (e.g., "first come, first served, 3 units only"); and 3.2.2. Clearly indicates who may accept and how, such that nothing is left open to negotiate. 3.3. Policy: Avoids exposing businesses to unlimited liability to the public at large.
cards.frontPrompt: How does the objective reasonable person standard determine whether a communication is an offer, and when can an advertisement be treated as an offer?
cards.cloze: The test for offer is {{c1::objective}}: Would a {{c2::reasonable person in the offeree's position}} believe the communication {{c3::is an offer inviting acceptance}}? {{c4::Vague or incomplete terms}} are usually treated as {{c5::preliminary negotiations}}, and mere {{c6::price quotes}} or {{c7::invitations to deal}} do not create a {{c8::power of acceptance}}. As a general rule, {{c9::advertisements, catalogs, and circulars}} are {{c10::not offers}} but invitations to negotiate. An advertisement becomes an offer only if it is {{c11::highly specific as to quantity}} and {{c12::clearly indicates who may accept and how}}, leaving {{c13::nothing essential open to negotiation}}.
cards.easyContent: Courts use an objective test: if a reasonable person in the offeree’s shoes would think the communication invites acceptance, it’s an offer. Vague statements, negotiations, and most ads are not offers. An ad can be an offer only when it is very specific about quantity and who can accept, leaving nothing important open.
cards.mediumContent: Offer is judged objectively: the key question is whether a reasonable offeree would believe the communication is an offer inviting acceptance. Vague phrasing, incomplete terms, and mere negotiations or price quotes generally do not qualify. Advertisements and similar mass communications are usually invitations to deal, not offers, to avoid unlimited liability, unless they are highly specific about quantity and clearly identify who may accept and how, leaving no significant terms to be negotiated.
cards.hardContent: The existence of an offer is determined by the objective theory of contracts: would a reasonable person in the offeree’s position interpret the offeror’s words and conduct as an intent to be bound upon acceptance? The offeror’s unexpressed subjective intent is irrelevant if the outward manifestation suggests an offer. Communications with vague, incomplete, or conditional terms are generally treated as preliminary negotiations or invitations to deal, and do not create a power of acceptance. Advertisements, catalog listings, circulars, and most price quotations are presumptively not offers because they are addressed to the general public and risk imposing unlimited liability; instead, they are treated as solicitations of offers. However, an advertisement may constitute an offer if it is highly specific regarding quantity and explicitly identifies who may accept and the manner of acceptance, such that no further bargaining is anticipated.
cards.mnemonic: Ads need Q&A: clear Quantity and Acceptors.
cards.clozeLite: Offer is judged {{c1::objectively}}: would a {{c2::reasonable offeree}} think it {{c3::invites acceptance}}? {{c4::Advertisements}} are usually {{c5::invitations to deal, not offers}}, unless {{c6::highly specific about quantity and who may accept}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.topic: Offer – UCC Article 2 Rules (Quantity and Missing Terms)
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 004-3. Offer – UCC Article 2 Rules (Quantity and Missing Terms)
cards.backPlain: 1. UCC Article 2 focus on quantity: 1.1. For a sale of goods, an offer (and resulting contract) generally must have a certain or ascertainable quantity term. 2. Requirement and output contracts: 2.1. Quantity may be measured by the buyer’s requirements or the seller’s output. 2.2. The chosen quantity must be in good faith. 2.3. There may be no unreasonably disproportionate increase in quantity compared to any stated estimate or prior course of performance. 3. Missing or open terms under the UCC: 3.1. The UCC is liberal in enforcing contracts despite missing terms. 3.2. Price and other terms can be left open if: 3.2.1. The parties clearly intended to make a contract; and 3.2.2. There is a reasonably certain basis for giving a remedy (e.g., UCC gap-filler provisions). 3.3. Courts will use UCC gap-fillers for price, time, and place of delivery when appropriate, but will not supply quantity except in requirement or output contracts.
cards.frontPrompt: What special rules govern offers for the sale of goods under UCC Article 2 regarding quantity, requirement/output contracts, and missing terms?
cards.cloze: Under {{c1::UCC Article 2}}, an offer for the sale of goods generally must have a {{c2::certain or ascertainable quantity term}}. In {{c3::requirement}} and {{c4::output}} contracts, quantity is measured by the buyer’s requirements or seller’s output, but any increase must be in {{c5::good faith}} and cannot be {{c6::unreasonably disproportionate}} to a stated estimate or prior dealings. The UCC allows many {{c7::missing or open terms}}—especially {{c8::price}}—if the parties {{c9::intended to make a contract}} and there is a {{c10::reasonably certain basis for giving a remedy}} using {{c11::gap-filler provisions}}. However, courts generally {{c12::will not supply a quantity term}} beyond requirement or output structures.
cards.easyContent: In UCC sales of goods, quantity is the crucial term: it must be fixed or at least capable of being determined, including via requirement or output contracts. The UCC lets many other terms like price be left open, using gap-fillers, as long as the parties clearly intended a contract and a court can craft a remedy.
cards.mediumContent: Under UCC Article 2, an enforceable offer for the sale of goods usually requires a certain or ascertainable quantity term. This can be set by requirement or output contracts, where the quantity is the buyer’s needs or the seller’s production, subject to good faith and a bar on unreasonably disproportionate increases from any estimate or prior performance. Unlike common law, the UCC tolerates missing terms such as price, time, and delivery, and supplies them through gap-fillers, so long as the parties intended to contract and there is a reasonably certain basis for granting a remedy; courts will not, however, create a quantity term out of whole cloth.
cards.hardContent: UCC Article 2 modifies common-law offer rules by focusing on quantity as the essential term for contracts for the sale of goods. An offer must include a certain or ascertainable quantity term, but quantity may be defined functionally through requirement and output contracts, in which the quantity is based on the buyer’s actual requirements or the seller’s actual output. These quantities must be demanded or tendered in good faith, and the UCC prohibits quantities that are unreasonably disproportionate to any stated estimate or prior course of performance, protecting parties from opportunistic behavior. The UCC is otherwise liberal regarding missing terms: a contract is not invalid simply because price, time, or place of delivery is left open. If the parties manifest an intent to contract and there is a reasonably certain basis for granting a remedy, courts will employ the UCC’s gap-filler provisions to supply these missing terms. However, courts are generally unwilling to supply a missing quantity term on their own, except where quantity is inherently defined by a requirement or output structure.
cards.mnemonic: UCC Q-Gap: Quantity fixed, Gaps filled.
cards.clozeLite: Under {{c1::UCC Article 2}}, an offer for goods usually needs a {{c2::certain or ascertainable quantity}}; {{c3::price and other terms}} can be {{c4::gap-filled}} if {{c5::intent to contract}} exists.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.topic: Revocation of Offers – Methods and Timing
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 006-1. Revocation of Offers – Methods and Timing
cards.front: Revocation of Offers – Methods and Timing
cards.backPlain: 1. General rule: 1.1. An offeror may revoke her offer, which terminates the offer and the offeree's power of acceptance. 2. Methods of revocation: 2.1. Direct revocation: an unambiguous statement by the offeror to the offeree indicating unwillingness or inability to contract. 2.2. Indirect revocation: the offeree becomes aware of the offeror's unambiguous conduct or statement indicating an unwillingness or inability to contract. 3. Timing and limitations: 3.1. Revocation is only effective upon receipt by the offeree. 3.2. An offer cannot be revoked once it has been accepted.
cards.frontPrompt: How can an offer be revoked, and when does revocation become effective?
cards.cloze: 1. General rule: An {{c1::offeror}} may revoke her offer, which terminates the offer and the offeree's {{c2::power of acceptance}}. 2. Methods of revocation: 2.1. {{c3::Direct revocation}}: an {{c4::unambiguous statement}} by the offeror to the offeree indicating unwillingness or inability to contract. 2.2. {{c5::Indirect revocation}}: the offeree becomes aware of the offeror's {{c6::unambiguous conduct or statement}} indicating an unwillingness or inability to contract. 3. Timing and limitations: 3.1. Revocation is only effective upon {{c7::receipt}} by the offeree. 3.2. An offer cannot be revoked once it has been {{c8::accepted}}.
cards.easyContent: An offeror can revoke by clearly telling the offeree or by conduct the offeree learns about that clearly shows the offeror will not contract. Revocation is effective only when the offeree receives it and is impossible after acceptance.
cards.mediumContent: Revocation terminates the offer and the offeree’s power of acceptance. It can be done directly, by an unambiguous statement to the offeree, or indirectly, when the offeree learns of unambiguous conduct or statements indicating the offeror will not contract. Revocation is effective only upon receipt by the offeree and is barred once the offer is accepted.
cards.hardContent: The offeror may revoke an offer at any time before acceptance, thereby terminating the offer and the offeree’s power of acceptance. Revocation can occur directly, through an unambiguous communication to the offeree that the offeror is unwilling or unable to proceed with the contract, or indirectly, when the offeree learns from a reliable source of the offeror’s unambiguous conduct or statement indicating such unwillingness or inability. Under both common law and the UCC, revocation is effective only when actually received by the offeree, and once the offeree has validly accepted the offer, revocation is no longer possible.
cards.mnemonic: REVOC: Revocation Ends power, Valid On receipt, Closed after acceptance
cards.clozeLite: Revocation {{c1::terminates the offeree’s power of acceptance}} and is {{c2::effective only upon receipt}} and {{c3::barred once the offer is accepted}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.topic: Irrevocability – Unilateral Contracts and Start of Performance
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 006-2. Irrevocability – Unilateral Contracts and Start of Performance
cards.front: Irrevocability – Unilateral Contracts and Start of Performance
cards.backPlain: 1. Unilateral contracts and offer irrevocability: 1.1. In a unilateral contract, an offer is generally revocable until performance begins. 1.2. Once the offeree starts performance, the offer becomes irrevocable for a reasonable time to allow completion of performance. 1.3. The start of performance must go beyond mere preparation. 2. Effect of irrevocability: 2.1. Once irrevocable, the offeror may not revoke for a reasonable time, but the offeree is not obligated to complete performance. 2.2. If the offeree completes performance within a reasonable time, a contract is formed; if the offeree does not complete, there is no acceptance, but the offeree may be entitled to restitution in some cases.
cards.frontPrompt: In unilateral contracts, when does an offer become irrevocable, and what counts as sufficient performance to trigger irrevocability?
cards.cloze: 1. Unilateral contracts and offer irrevocability: 1.1. In a {{c1::unilateral contract}}, an offer is generally revocable until {{c2::performance begins}}. 1.2. Once the offeree {{c3::starts performance}}, the offer becomes {{c4::irrevocable}} for a {{c5::reasonable time}} to allow completion of performance. 1.3. The start of performance must go beyond {{c6::mere preparation}}. 2. Effect of irrevocability: 2.1. Once irrevocable, the offeror may not {{c7::revoke}} for a reasonable time, but the offeree is not {{c8::obligated to complete performance}}. 2.2. If the offeree {{c9::completes performance within a reasonable time}}, a {{c10::contract is formed}}.
cards.easyContent: For unilateral contracts, once the offeree actually begins performance (not just preparing), the offer becomes irrevocable for a reasonable time to finish. The offeror can’t revoke during that time, though the offeree doesn’t have to complete performance.
cards.mediumContent: In unilateral contracts, the offer is ordinarily revocable until performance begins. Once the offeree begins performance—meaning conduct that goes beyond mere preparation—the offer becomes irrevocable for a reasonable time so the offeree can complete performance. During that period, the offeror may not revoke, though the offeree is not compelled to finish; if performance is completed in a reasonable time, acceptance occurs and a contract is formed.
cards.hardContent: For offers inviting acceptance only by performance (true unilateral contracts), the traditional rule of free revocability is modified. The offer remains revocable until the offeree actually commences performance, but once performance begins—conduct that constitutes part of the bargained-for performance and not just preparatory steps—the offer becomes irrevocable for a reasonable time to allow completion. During this period, the offeror is barred from revoking, although the offeree incurs no duty to complete performance; acceptance and a binding contract arise only upon completion of the requested performance within a reasonable time. If the offeree does not complete, there is ordinarily no contract, though restitution may be available to prevent unjust enrichment where the offeror benefits from partial performance.
cards.mnemonic: UNI starts: Once performance Starts, offer Sticks.
cards.clozeLite: In {{c1::unilateral contracts}}, an offer becomes {{c2::irrevocable once performance begins}} ({{c3::beyond mere preparation}}) for a {{c4::reasonable time to complete}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.topic: Irrevocable Offers – Option Contracts and UCC Firm Offers
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 006-3. Irrevocable Offers – Option Contracts and UCC Firm Offers
cards.front: Irrevocable Offers – Option Contracts and UCC Firm Offers
cards.backPlain: 1. Option contracts (common law and UCC when firm-offer rule does not apply): 1.1. Definition: An option contract is a separate promise to keep an offer open for a specified period. 1.2. Consideration requirement: 1.2.1. Common law: consideration is required for the option; without consideration, the offeror may generally revoke despite the promise. 1.2.2. UCC: when the UCC firm-offer rule does not apply, an option to keep a goods offer open likewise requires consideration. 2. UCC firm offers (UCC § 2-205): 2.1. Elements: 2.1.1. A merchant. 2.1.2. An offer to buy or sell goods. 2.1.3. In a signed writing. 2.1.4. That gives assurances the offer will be held open. 2.2. Effect: 2.2.1. The offer is irrevocable for the time stated, or if no time is stated, for a reasonable time not exceeding three months. 2.2.2. No consideration is required to make the firm offer irrevocable. 2.2.3. Any term of assurance on a form supplied by the offeree that is not separately signed by the offeror may be construed against irrevocability under some authorities, but the bar exam typically focuses on the basic elements and duration.
cards.frontPrompt: What is an option contract, when is consideration required, and what are the requirements and duration of a UCC firm offer?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Option contracts}} (common law and UCC when firm-offer rule does not apply): 1.1. Definition: An option contract is a {{c2::separate promise to keep an offer open}} for a specified period. 1.2. Consideration requirement: 1.2.1. {{c3::Common law}}: {{c4::consideration is required}} for the option; without it, the offeror may generally revoke. 1.2.2. {{c5::UCC}}: when the {{c6::firm-offer rule}} does not apply, an option to keep a goods offer open also {{c7::requires consideration}}. 2. {{c8::UCC firm offers}} (UCC § 2-205): 2.1. Elements: 2.1.1. A {{c9::merchant}}. 2.1.2. An offer to {{c10::buy or sell goods}}. 2.1.3. In a {{c11::signed writing}}. 2.1.4. That gives {{c12::assurances the offer will be held open}}. 2.2. Effect: 2.2.1. The offer is irrevocable for the {{c13::time stated}}, or if no time is stated, for a {{c14::reasonable time}} not exceeding {{c15::three months}}. 2.2.2. {{c16::No consideration is required}} to make the firm offer irrevocable.
cards.easyContent: An option contract is a separate, paid-for promise to keep an offer open; at common law and under the UCC when no firm offer applies, it requires consideration. A UCC firm offer is a merchant’s signed writing to buy or sell goods that assures the offer will be held open; it needs no consideration and is irrevocable for the stated time, or if none, for a reasonable time up to three months.
cards.mediumContent: Option contracts are separate agreements in which the offeror promises to keep an offer open for a set time. At common law, and under the UCC when the firm-offer rule does not apply, such an option must be supported by consideration or the offer remains freely revocable. Under UCC § 2-205, a firm offer arises when a merchant makes an offer to buy or sell goods in a signed writing that gives assurances it will be held open. That offer is irrevocable for the time stated, or, if none is stated, for a reasonable time not exceeding three months, and no consideration is required.
cards.hardContent: An option contract is a distinct contractual commitment to keep an underlying offer open for a specified period. At common law, the option must be supported by separate consideration; without consideration, the promise to hold the offer open is generally unenforceable, and the offeror may revoke at will. The same consideration requirement applies under the UCC where § 2-205’s firm-offer rule is inapplicable. By contrast, UCC § 2-205 creates a statutory irrevocable offer—the firm offer—when: (1) the offeror is a merchant; (2) the offer is to buy or sell goods; (3) the offer is contained in a signed writing; and (4) the writing gives assurances that the offer will be held open. Such a firm offer is irrevocable for the time stated, or, if no time is stated, for a reasonable time that in no event may exceed three months, and it does not require consideration to be enforceable.
cards.mnemonic: Firm offer: MSW-3 — Merchant, Signed Writing, 3 months max, no consideration.
cards.clozeLite: An {{c1::option contract}} needs {{c2::consideration}} to keep an offer open, but a {{c3::UCC § 2-205 firm offer}} by a {{c4::merchant in a signed writing}} is {{c5::irrevocable without consideration for up to three months}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 006-4. Irrevocable Offers – Detrimental Reliance
cards.backPlain: 1. Detrimental reliance as a basis for irrevocability: 1.1. An offer may be treated as irrevocable when the offeree reasonably and foreseeably relies on the offer to their detriment. 1.2. The reliance must be substantial and of a kind that the offeror should reasonably expect (e.g., subcontractor bids relied on by a general contractor in preparing a main bid). 2. Effect of detrimental reliance: 2.1. The offeror may be estopped from revoking the offer for a period necessary to avoid injustice. 2.2. Courts may enforce the offer as an option contract or provide reliance-based remedies, depending on the jurisdiction and facts. 3. Bar exam focus: 3.1. Know that reasonable, foreseeable detrimental reliance by the offeree can render an offer irrevocable, especially in construction bidding and similar contexts.
cards.frontPrompt: How can reasonable detrimental reliance by the offeree make an offer irrevocable, and in what situations is this most commonly tested?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Detrimental reliance}} as a basis for irrevocability: 1.1. An offer may be treated as irrevocable when the offeree {{c2::reasonably and foreseeably relies}} on the offer to their {{c3::detriment}}. 1.2. The reliance must be {{c4::substantial}} and of a kind that the offeror should {{c5::reasonably expect}} (e.g., {{c6::subcontractor bids relied on by a general contractor}}). 2. Effect of detrimental reliance: 2.1. The offeror may be {{c7::estopped from revoking}} the offer for a period necessary to {{c8::avoid injustice}}. 2.2. Courts may enforce the offer as an {{c9::option contract}} or provide {{c10::reliance-based remedies}}. 3. Bar exam focus: 3.1. Reasonable, foreseeable {{c11::detrimental reliance}} by the offeree can render an offer {{c12::irrevocable}}, especially in {{c13::construction bidding}} contexts.
cards.easyContent: If an offeree reasonably and foreseeably relies on an offer in a substantial way (like a general contractor relying on a subcontractor’s bid), the offeror may be estopped from revoking; the offer is treated as irrevocable to avoid injustice.
cards.mediumContent: Detrimental reliance can make an offer effectively irrevocable. When the offeree reasonably, foreseeably, and substantially changes position in reliance on the offer—such as a general contractor using a subcontractor’s bid in a main bid—the offeror can be estopped from revoking for a period necessary to prevent injustice. Courts may treat the offer like an option contract or grant reliance-based relief.
cards.hardContent: Under promissory estoppel principles, an offer may become irrevocable when the offeree reasonably and foreseeably relies on it to their detriment. The reliance must be substantial and of a type that the offeror should have reasonably anticipated, with construction bidding (general contractors relying on subcontractors’ bids) being the classic bar exam context. In such cases, courts often hold that the offeror is estopped from revoking the offer for a time sufficient to allow the offeree to accept, effectively converting the offer into a temporary option or awarding reliance damages to avoid injustice.
cards.mnemonic: RELY: Reasonable, Extensive reliance Locks the offer for You
cards.clozeLite: An offer becomes {{c1::effectively irrevocable}} when the offeree {{c2::reasonably, foreseeably, and substantially relies}} on it, like a {{c3::GC using a subcontractor’s bid}}; the offeror is {{c4::estopped from revoking}} to {{c5::prevent injustice}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.topic: Rejection of Offer – General Rule and Express Rejection
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 007-1. Rejection of Offer – General Rule and Express Rejection
cards.front: Rejection of Offer – General Rule and Express Rejection
cards.backPlain: 1. General Rule 1.1. A rejection by the offeree terminates the offer and the offeree's power of acceptance. 2. Express Rejection 2.1. Express rejection occurs when the offeree clearly communicates that they do not accept the offer (e.g., "No," "I’m not interested," "I reject your offer"). 2.2. Express rejection is effective when received by the offeror. 2.3. Once an offer is rejected, the offeree can no longer accept it unless the offeror renews or re-extends the offer.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the general rule regarding rejection of an offer, and how does an express rejection operate and become effective?
cards.cloze: 1. General Rule 1.1. A {{c1::rejection by the offeree}} {{c2::terminates the offer}} and the offeree's {{c3::power of acceptance}}. 2. Express Rejection 2.1. Express rejection occurs when the offeree {{c4::clearly communicates that they do not accept}} the offer. 2.2. Express rejection is {{c5::effective when received}} by the offeror. 2.3. Once an offer is rejected, the offeree can no longer accept it unless the offeror {{c6::renews or re-extends the offer}}.
cards.easyContent: If the offeree rejects, the offer and their power to accept are terminated. An express rejection is a clear “no” and is effective only when the offeror receives it.
cards.mediumContent: A rejection by the offeree terminates both the offer and the offeree’s power of acceptance. An express rejection is a clear communication that the offeree will not accept. It is effective when received by the offeror, and after that, the offeree cannot accept unless the offer is renewed.
cards.hardContent: A rejection by the offeree terminates the offer and the offeree’s power of acceptance. Express rejection consists of a clear statement or communication by the offeree that they do not accept the offer. It is effective when received by the offeror, not when sent. After an effective express rejection, the offeree cannot accept the original offer unless the offeror affirmatively renews or re-extends the offer.
cards.mnemonic: Express rejection: RX when Received—effective only when received.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::rejection by the offeree}} terminates the {{c2::offer}} and the {{c3::power of acceptance}}; express rejection is effective {{c4::when received by the offeror}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.topic: Rejection of Offer – Counteroffers vs. Mere Bargaining
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 007-2. Rejection of Offer – Counteroffers vs. Mere Bargaining
cards.front: Rejection of Offer – Counteroffers vs. Mere Bargaining
cards.backPlain: 1. Counteroffer 1.1. A counteroffer is a response to an offer that adds new terms or changes the terms in a way that is not a pure acceptance. 1.2. A counteroffer terminates the original offer and becomes a new offer. 2. Mere Bargaining / Requests for Information 2.1. Mere bargaining or requests for information are not counteroffers. 2.2. A response that asks, "Would you consider..." or "Can you do any better on the price?" without clearly rejecting or changing the offer is usually treated as bargaining, not a counteroffer. 2.3. Mere bargaining or information requests do not terminate the original offer; the offeree retains the power of acceptance.
cards.frontPrompt: How does a counteroffer affect the original offer, and how are counteroffers distinguished from mere bargaining or requests for information?
cards.cloze: 1. Counteroffer 1.1. A counteroffer is a response to an offer that {{c1::adds new terms or changes the terms}} instead of purely accepting. 1.2. A counteroffer {{c2::terminates the original offer}} and {{c3::becomes a new offer}}. 2. Mere Bargaining / Requests for Information 2.1. Mere {{c4::bargaining or requests for information}} are {{c5::not counteroffers}}. 2.2. Questions like {{c6::"Would you consider..." or "Can you do any better on the price?"}} usually indicate bargaining, not a counteroffer. 2.3. Mere bargaining or information requests {{c7::do not terminate}} the original offer; the offeree {{c8::retains the power of acceptance}}.
cards.easyContent: A counteroffer kills the original offer and becomes a new offer. But mere bargaining or asking for more information does not count as a counteroffer and does not terminate the original offer.
cards.mediumContent: A counteroffer is a response that changes or adds terms; it terminates the original offer and becomes a new offer. By contrast, mere bargaining or requests for information—such as asking whether the offeror can improve the terms—do not terminate the original offer and are not treated as counteroffers.
cards.hardContent: A counteroffer is a response by the offeree that is not a pure acceptance but instead introduces different or additional terms. Making a counteroffer terminates the original offer and vests the power of acceptance in the original offeror, who is now the offeree to the new offer. However, mere bargaining or requests for information—such as questions about whether the offeror might accept different terms—are not counteroffers and do not terminate the original offer; the offeree still retains the power to accept the original offer unless and until it lapses or is otherwise revoked.
cards.mnemonic: Counteroffer COUNTS as new terms; questions don’t count.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::counteroffer}} {{c2::changes or adds terms}} and {{c3::terminates the original offer}}; {{c4::mere bargaining or information requests}} do not.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 007-3. Rejection of Offer – Conditional Acceptance
cards.backPlain: 1. Conditional Acceptance – General Rule 1.1. A conditional acceptance is when the offeree purports to accept, but only on certain conditions or with different terms. 1.2. A conditional acceptance terminates the original offer and becomes a new offer. 1.3. Look for terms such as "if," "only if," "provided that," or "on the condition that." 2. Example 2.1. Offer to mow lawn; offeree says, "I accept if you also edge the walkway." This is not a true acceptance; it is a new offer. The original offeree is now the offeror. 3. Exception – Conditions That Would Be Included Anyway 3.1. If the offeree’s condition merely insists on a term that would be included in the contract anyway by operation of law, the response does not terminate the original offer. 3.2. Example: Demanding an implied warranty that would be part of the contract anyway does not convert the response into a counteroffer or terminate the original offer.
cards.frontPrompt: What is a conditional acceptance, how does it affect the original offer, and what is the exception for conditions that would be included in the contract anyway?
cards.cloze: 1. Conditional Acceptance – General Rule 1.1. A conditional acceptance occurs when the offeree {{c1::purports to accept but only on certain conditions or with different terms}}. 1.2. A conditional acceptance {{c2::terminates the original offer}} and {{c3::becomes a new offer}}. 1.3. Look for words like {{c4::"if," "only if," "provided that," "on the condition that"}}. 2. Example 2.1. Offer to mow lawn; offeree says, {{c5::"I accept if you also edge the walkway."}} This is a {{c6::new offer}}, and the original offeree becomes the {{c7::offeror}}. 3. Exception – Conditions Included Anyway 3.1. If the offeree’s condition merely insists on a term that would be {{c8::included in the contract anyway by operation of law}}, the response {{c9::does not terminate}} the original offer. 3.2. Example: Demanding an {{c10::implied warranty}} that would already be part of the contract does not convert the response into a counteroffer.
cards.easyContent: A conditional acceptance (“I accept, if/only if…”) usually kills the original offer and is treated as a new offer. But if the condition is something the law would have put into the contract anyway, it does not terminate the original offer.
cards.mediumContent: A conditional acceptance is a response that appears to accept but only on certain conditions or with different terms.
