It terminates the original offer and functions as a new offer—watch for words like “if,” “only if,” “provided that,” or “on the condition that.” However, if the supposed condition is just insisting on a term that would be included by law anyway (e.g., an implied warranty), the original offer is not terminated.
cards.hardContent: A conditional acceptance occurs when the offeree purports to accept an offer but conditions that acceptance on new or different terms. This conditional acceptance terminates the original offer and is treated as a new offer directed to the original offeror. Indicators include phrases like “if,” “only if,” “provided that,” or “on the condition that.” For example, if A offers to mow B’s lawn, and B says, “I accept if you also edge the walkway,” B has rejected A’s original offer and made a new one. However, there is an important exception: if the condition merely requires a term that would be included in the contract anyway by operation of law (such as an implied warranty), the offeree’s statement does not terminate the original offer and is not treated as a counteroffer.
cards.mnemonic: Conditional = "I accept, IF"; kills offer unless law adds term anyway.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::conditional acceptance}} ("I accept, if/only if…") {{c2::terminates the original offer}} and is {{c3::a new offer}}, unless the {{c4::condition is already supplied by law}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.topic: Rejection of Offer – Acceptance with Additional Terms (Common Law vs. UCC)
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 007-4. Rejection of Offer – Acceptance with Additional Terms (Common Law vs. UCC)
cards.front: Rejection of Offer – Acceptance with Additional Terms (Common Law vs. UCC)
cards.backPlain: 1. Common Law – Mirror-Image Rule 1.1. Under common law, acceptance must mirror the offer (mirror-image rule). 1.2. An acceptance that adds or changes terms is treated as a rejection and counteroffer. 2. UCC Article 2 – Additional Terms in Acceptance 2.1. Under the UCC, the effect of additional terms in an acceptance depends on whether both parties are merchants. 3. One or Both Parties Are Non-Merchants 3.1. If one or both parties are non-merchants, the terms of the offer govern. 3.2. A contract is formed despite the additional terms. 3.3. The additional terms are excluded and are treated as mere proposals to modify the contract. 4. Both Parties Are Merchants 4.1. If both parties are merchants, additional terms in the acceptance generally become part of the contract unless an exception applies. 4.2. Exceptions (any of which prevent the additional terms from becoming part of the contract): (a) The additional terms materially alter the offer; (b) The offer expressly limits acceptance to its terms; or (c) The offeror objects to the additional terms within a reasonable time.
cards.frontPrompt: How does acceptance with additional terms operate as a rejection and counteroffer at common law, and how does the UCC treat additional terms for merchants vs. non-merchants?
cards.cloze: 1. Common Law – Mirror-Image Rule 1.1. Under common law, acceptance must {{c1::mirror the offer}} ({{c2::mirror-image rule}}). 1.2. An acceptance that adds or changes terms is a {{c3::rejection and counteroffer}}. 2. UCC Article 2 – Additional Terms in Acceptance 2.1. Under the UCC, the effect of additional terms depends on whether both parties are {{c4::merchants}}. 3. One or Both Parties Are Non-Merchants 3.1. If {{c5::one or both parties are non-merchants}}, the {{c6::terms of the offer govern}}. 3.2. A {{c7::contract is formed}} despite the additional terms. 3.3. The additional terms are {{c8::excluded}} and treated as {{c9::mere proposals to modify}} the contract. 4. Both Parties Are Merchants 4.1. If {{c10::both parties are merchants}}, additional terms in the acceptance generally {{c11::become part of the contract}} unless an exception applies. 4.2. Exceptions: (a) The additional terms {{c12::materially alter}} the offer; (b) The offer {{c13::expressly limits acceptance to its terms}}; or (c) The {{c14::offeror objects}} to the additional terms within a {{c15::reasonable time}}.
cards.easyContent: At common law, acceptance must be a mirror image; if the offeree adds or changes terms, it’s a rejection and counteroffer. Under the UCC, additional terms may still allow a contract: if any party is a non-merchant, the offer’s terms control and extra terms are just proposals; if both are merchants, extra terms usually become part of the contract unless an exception applies (material alteration, express limitation, or timely objection).
cards.mediumContent: Under common law, the mirror-image rule requires acceptance to match the offer exactly; otherwise, the purported acceptance with additional or different terms is treated as a rejection and counteroffer. Under the UCC, the result depends on merchant status. If one or both parties are non-merchants, a contract is formed on the offer’s terms and any additional terms are excluded and treated as proposals to modify. If both parties are merchants, additional terms in the acceptance generally become part of the contract unless (1) they materially alter the offer, (2) the offer expressly limits acceptance to its terms, or (3) the offeror objects within a reasonable time.
cards.hardContent: At common law, the mirror-image rule governs: an acceptance must mirror the offer; otherwise, a purported acceptance that adds or changes terms is not an acceptance at all but a rejection and counteroffer. Under UCC Article 2, additional terms in an acceptance are treated more flexibly. If one or both parties are non-merchants, the contract is formed on the offer’s terms, and the additional terms are excluded and treated only as proposals to modify the contract. If both parties are merchants, additional terms in the offeree’s acceptance generally become part of the contract by default. However, these additional terms are kept out of the contract if (1) the terms materially alter the offer, (2) the offer expressly limits acceptance to its terms, or (3) the offeror objects to the additional terms within a reasonable time after receiving them.
cards.mnemonic: MIRROR = counter; Merchants Mostly Merge (unless MA-Limit-Object).
cards.clozeLite: Under {{c1::common law}}, the {{c2::mirror-image rule}} makes added terms a {{c3::rejection and counteroffer}}. Under {{c4::UCC §2-207}}, extra terms between {{c5::merchants}} usually {{c6::become part of the contract}} unless an exception applies.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.topic: Acceptance – General Rule & Mirror-Image Rule (Common Law)
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 008-1. Acceptance – General Rule & Mirror-Image Rule (Common Law)
cards.front: Acceptance – General Rule & Mirror-Image Rule (Common Law)
cards.backPlain: 1. General Rule of Acceptance 1.1. Acceptance arises upon the offeree's clear expression of assent to the terms of the offer. 1.2. The offeror is the master of the offer and can dictate the mode and manner by which an offer is accepted. 2. Mirror-Image Rule (Common Law) 2.1. Under the mirror-image rule, acceptance must mirror the offer's terms. 2.2. An acceptance cannot add, omit, or change terms of the offer. 2.3. Any purported acceptance that varies the terms of the offer is treated as a counteroffer, not an acceptance.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the general rule of acceptance, and what does the common-law mirror-image rule require?
cards.cloze: 1. General Rule of Acceptance 1.1. Acceptance arises upon the offeree's {{c1::clear expression of assent}} to the terms of the offer. 1.2. The {{c2::offeror is the master of the offer}} and can dictate the {{c3::mode and manner}} by which an offer is accepted. 2. {{c4::Mirror-Image Rule}} (Common Law) 2.1. Under the mirror-image rule, acceptance must {{c5::mirror the offer's terms}}. 2.2. An acceptance cannot {{c6::add, omit, or change}} terms of the offer. 2.3. A response that varies the offer's terms is treated as a {{c7::counteroffer}}, not an acceptance.
cards.easyContent: Acceptance is the offeree’s clear assent to the offer, in the way the offeror specifies as master of the offer. At common law, the mirror-image rule requires the acceptance to exactly match the offer’s terms; any change is a counteroffer, not an acceptance.
cards.mediumContent: Acceptance occurs when the offeree clearly expresses assent to the offer’s terms, using the method and manner authorized by the offeror, who is the master of the offer. Under the common-law mirror-image rule, the acceptance must exactly mirror the offer’s terms; the offeree cannot add, delete, or alter terms. If the offeree’s response varies the terms in any way, it is treated as a counteroffer instead of an acceptance.
cards.hardContent: Acceptance requires the offeree’s clear expression of assent to the specific terms proposed in the offer, and the offeror—as the master of the offer—may specify the manner and medium by which acceptance must be made. Under the common-law mirror-image rule, a valid acceptance must mirror the offer’s terms; any addition, omission, or modification of a term prevents the response from operating as an acceptance. Instead, a response that changes the offer’s terms is treated as a counteroffer, which rejects the original offer and proposes new terms.
cards.mnemonic: MIRROR: Match Identical Response; Revisions Reject Offer’s Reflection.
cards.clozeLite: At common law, {{c1::acceptance}} is {{c2::clear assent to the offer}} using the {{c3::method the offeror specifies}}. The {{c4::mirror-image rule}} requires {{c5::exactly matching the offer’s terms}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 008-2. Acceptance – UCC Additional Terms & Merchants
cards.backPlain: 1. UCC Acceptance with Additional Terms 1.1. An expression of acceptance under the UCC can include additional terms. 1.2. First determine whether both parties are merchants. 2. Both Parties Are Merchants 2.1. A contract is formed despite additional terms. 2.2. The additional terms generally become part of the contract unless: 2.2.1. The additional terms materially change the offer; or 2.2.2. The offer expressly limits acceptance to the offer's terms; or 2.2.3. The offeror objects to the additional terms within a reasonable time. 3. One or Both Parties Are Not Merchants 3.1. A contract is formed on the original terms of the offer. 3.2. The additional terms do not automatically become part of the contract. 3.3. The additional terms are treated as mere proposals for addition to the contract.
cards.frontPrompt: Under the UCC, how are additional terms in an acceptance treated when both parties are merchants versus when one or both are not merchants?
cards.cloze: 1. UCC Acceptance with Additional Terms 1.1. Under the {{c1::UCC}}, an expression of acceptance can include {{c2::additional terms}}. 1.2. First determine whether {{c3::both parties are merchants}}. 2. Both Parties Are Merchants 2.1. A {{c4::contract is formed}} despite additional terms. 2.2. The additional terms generally {{c5::become part of the contract unless}}: 2.2.1. The additional terms {{c6::materially change}} the offer; or 2.2.2. The offer {{c7::expressly limits acceptance}} to its own terms; or 2.2.3. The {{c8::offeror objects}} to the additional terms within a {{c9::reasonable time}}. 3. One or Both Parties Are Not Merchants 3.1. A contract is formed on the {{c10::original terms of the offer}}. 3.2. The additional terms {{c11::do not automatically become part}} of the contract. 3.3. The additional terms are treated as {{c12::proposals for addition}} to the contract.
cards.easyContent: Under the UCC, an acceptance can include extra terms. If both parties are merchants, the contract is formed and the extra terms usually become part of it unless they materially change the deal, the offer limits acceptance to its terms, or the offeror objects in a reasonable time. If one or both parties are non-merchants, a contract forms on the original offer terms, and the extra terms are just proposals.
cards.mediumContent: The UCC allows an expression of acceptance to contain additional terms. The first question is whether both parties are merchants. If they are, a contract is formed and the additional terms are included unless (1) they materially alter the offer, (2) the offer expressly limits acceptance to its own terms, or (3) the offeror objects within a reasonable time. If one or both parties are not merchants, a contract still forms, but only on the original terms of the offer; the extra terms do not automatically become part of the agreement and are instead treated as proposals for addition.
cards.hardContent: Under UCC Article 2, an offeree’s written confirmation or other expression of acceptance can contain additional terms and still operate as an acceptance. The critical step is determining whether both parties are merchants. If both are merchants, a contract is formed notwithstanding the additional terms, and those terms generally become part of the contract unless one of three conditions is met: (1) the additional terms would materially change the offer; (2) the offer expressly limits acceptance to the terms of the offer itself; or (3) the offeror objects to the additional terms within a reasonable time after receiving them. If either party is not a merchant, a contract is still formed based on the original offer terms, but the additional terms do not automatically enter the contract; instead, they are treated merely as proposals that the other party may accept or reject.
cards.mnemonic: MEO: Material change, Express limitation, Objection within reasonable time.
cards.clozeLite: If {{c1::both parties are merchants}}, extra terms {{c2::usually become part of the contract}} unless {{c3::material change}}, {{c4::express limitation}}, or {{c5::timely objection}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 008-3. Acceptance – UCC Acceptance by Shipment
cards.backPlain: 1. Acceptance by Shipment under the UCC 1.1. In a sale of goods, a merchant may accept an offer to buy goods by: 1.1.1. Providing a promise to ship goods (often by written confirmation); or 1.1.2. Promptly shipping conforming goods. 2. Shipment of Nonconforming Goods 2.1. Shipment of nonconforming goods generally acts as an acceptance of the offer. 2.2. However, shipment of nonconforming goods also constitutes a breach of contract. 2.3. Exception – Accommodation Shipment: 2.3.1. If the seller seasonably notifies the buyer that the nonconforming shipment is offered only as an accommodation, 2.3.2. Then the shipment operates as a counteroffer rather than an acceptance, and there is no breach if the buyer rejects.
cards.frontPrompt: How can a merchant accept an offer to buy goods by shipment under the UCC, and what is the effect of shipping nonconforming goods, including accommodation shipments?
cards.cloze: 1. Acceptance by Shipment under the UCC 1.1. In a sale of goods, a {{c1::merchant}} may accept an offer to buy goods by: 1.1.1. Providing a {{c2::promise to ship goods}} (often by written confirmation); or 1.1.2. Promptly shipping {{c3::conforming goods}}. 2. Shipment of Nonconforming Goods 2.1. Shipment of {{c4::nonconforming goods}} generally acts as an {{c5::acceptance}} of the offer. 2.2. That shipment also constitutes a {{c6::breach}} of contract. 2.3. Exception – {{c7::Accommodation Shipment}}: 2.3.1. If the seller {{c8::seasonably notifies}} the buyer that the nonconforming shipment is offered only as an {{c9::accommodation}}, 2.3.2. Then the shipment operates as a {{c10::counteroffer}} rather than an acceptance, and there is no breach if the buyer rejects.
cards.easyContent: Under the UCC, a merchant can accept an offer to buy goods by promising to ship or by promptly shipping conforming goods. If the seller ships nonconforming goods, that usually counts as acceptance plus breach. But if the seller seasonably tells the buyer the nonconforming shipment is just an accommodation, it is a counteroffer instead of an acceptance.
cards.mediumContent: In UCC sales of goods, a merchant can accept an offer either by providing a promise to ship (often via written confirmation) or by promptly shipping conforming goods. If the seller ships nonconforming goods without explanation, that shipment counts as an acceptance of the offer and simultaneously constitutes a breach. However, the seller can avoid creating a contract and a breach by seasonably notifying the buyer that the nonconforming shipment is being sent only as an accommodation. In that case, the shipment is treated as a counteroffer, and there is no breach if the buyer rejects it.
cards.hardContent: Under UCC Article 2, an offer to buy goods may be accepted by a merchant either through a promise to ship—commonly communicated by written confirmation—or by the prompt shipment of goods that conform to the offer’s specifications. Ordinarily, shipment of nonconforming goods is treated as both an acceptance of the offer and a breach of contract, giving the buyer immediate remedies for nonconformity. There is an important exception: if the seller seasonably notifies the buyer that the nonconforming goods are being tendered only as an accommodation, the shipment is construed as a counteroffer rather than an acceptance, so no contract is formed on the original terms and the seller is not in breach if the buyer rejects the shipment.
cards.mnemonic: SHIP PA: Ship, Promise; Accommodation avoids Acceptance breach.
cards.clozeLite: Under the {{c1::UCC}}, a seller accepts by {{c2::promise to ship}} or {{c3::prompt shipment of conforming goods}}; {{c4::nonconforming goods}} are {{c5::acceptance plus breach unless marked accommodation}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.topic: Defenses – Incapacity, Statute of Frauds, and Illegality
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 012-1. Defenses – Incapacity, Statute of Frauds, and Illegality
cards.front: Defenses – Incapacity, Statute of Frauds, and Illegality
cards.backPlain: 1. Incapacity - A party must have legal capacity to enter into a contract. - Common categories of incapacity include: • Minors (infancy): contracts are generally voidable at the minor’s option. • Mentally incompetent persons: contracts may be void or voidable depending on adjudication and jurisdiction. • Sometimes severely intoxicated persons, if the other party knew or should have known of the incapacity. - Effect: Typically makes the contract void or voidable by the incapacitated party, subject to exceptions (e.g., necessities). 2. Statute of Frauds (SoF) - Certain types of contracts must satisfy specific formal requirements (usually a writing signed by the party to be charged) to be enforceable. - If a contract within the SoF does not meet its requirements, it is unenforceable (though not necessarily void) against the non-signing party. - Typical SoF categories (jurisdiction-specific) include: • Marriage consideration contracts. • Contracts that cannot be performed within one year. • Land sale or interest-in-land contracts. • Suretyship (promise to answer for the debt of another). • Contracts for goods priced at or above the UCC threshold. 3. Illegality - A contract is illegal if its subject matter or purpose violates a statute or public policy (e.g., contracts to commit a crime or tort, usurious interest rates, certain noncompetes). - Effect: An illegal contract is typically void and unenforceable. Courts generally leave parties where they find them, with limited exceptions for protected classes or restitution to avoid unjust enrichment.
cards.frontPrompt: How do incapacity, the Statute of Frauds, and illegality operate as defenses to contract formation or enforcement, and what is their basic effect on the contract?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Incapacity}} – A party lacks legal capacity (e.g., {{c2::minor}}, {{c3::mentally incompetent}}, sometimes {{c4::severely intoxicated}}). Such contracts are generally {{c5::void or voidable}} by the incapacitated party. 2. {{c6::Statute of Frauds (SoF)}} – Certain contracts must satisfy {{c7::formal requirements}} (usually a {{c8::writing signed}} by the party to be charged). Failure to comply generally makes the contract {{c9::unenforceable}} against that party. 3. {{c10::Illegality}} – The contract’s {{c11::subject matter or purpose}} is illegal or against {{c12::public policy}} (e.g., crime, tort, usury). Such contracts are typically {{c13::void and unenforceable}}.
cards.easyContent: Some defenses focus on whether parties can contract at all and whether the contract is lawful and properly formalized: incapacity (e.g., minors, mental incompetence), failure to satisfy Statute of Frauds requirements for certain contracts, and illegality of the contract’s subject matter or purpose.
cards.mediumContent: Incapacity is a defense where a party lacks legal capacity (such as infancy, mental incompetence, or sometimes severe intoxication), generally making the contract void or voidable by that party. The Statute of Frauds requires certain types of contracts to be in a signed writing; failure to comply makes the contract unenforceable against the party who did not sign. Illegality makes a contract void and unenforceable when its subject matter or purpose violates statute or public policy, such as contracts to commit crimes or usurious contracts.
cards.hardContent: Incapacity: A contract requires legally competent parties. Minors, mentally incompetent individuals, and sometimes severely intoxicated persons may lack capacity. Contracts with such parties are usually voidable at the incapacitated party’s option (and sometimes void if adjudicated incompetent), subject to exceptions such as contracts for necessities. Statute of Frauds (SoF): Certain types of contracts (e.g., marriage consideration, contracts not performable within one year, land contracts, suretyship, and certain goods contracts under the UCC) must satisfy formal requirements, typically a writing signed by the party to be charged with sufficient terms. Noncompliance renders the contract unenforceable against that party, though the contract is not necessarily void. Illegality: A contract is illegal if its subject matter or its purpose contravenes a statute or public policy (e.g., agreements to commit crimes or torts, usurious loans, certain unreasonable restraints of trade). Illegal contracts are generally void and unenforceable; courts typically will not assist either party, subject to limited exceptions for protected classes or restitution in some circumstances.
cards.mnemonic: I-S-I: Incapacity, Statute of Frauds, Illegality.
cards.clozeLite: Defenses include {{c1::incapacity}}, {{c2::Statute of Frauds}}, and {{c3::illegality}}—making contracts {{c4::void, voidable, or unenforceable}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 012-2. Defenses – Misrepresentation/Fraud and Duress
cards.backPlain: 1. Misrepresentation/Fraud - Misrepresentation is a false statement of fact that is material and relied upon by the other party in entering the contract. - Fraud involves intentional or reckless misrepresentation (scienter). - Elements of fraudulent misrepresentation typically include: • A false statement of material fact (or concealment where there is a duty to disclose); • Made with knowledge of its falsity or reckless disregard for the truth; • With the intent to induce reliance; • Actual, justifiable reliance by the other party; • Resulting damage. - Effect: A contract induced by material misrepresentation or fraud is generally voidable by the misled party; in some cases, it may be rescinded and damages awarded. 2. Duress - Duress arises when a party’s assent is induced by an improper threat that leaves the victim with no reasonable alternative. - Types include: • Physical duress (threats of physical harm); • Economic or business duress (wrongful economic threats or withholding, under some standards); • Threats of criminal prosecution or bad faith legal action. - Elements commonly focus on: • Wrongful or improper threat by the other party; • Lack of reasonable alternative for the victim; • Actual inducement of the contract by the threat. - Effect: A contract entered into under duress is generally voidable by the victim; extreme physical duress may render the contract void.
cards.frontPrompt: When does misrepresentation or fraud, and when does duress, provide a defense to contract enforcement, and what is the usual effect on the contract?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Misrepresentation}} is a {{c2::false statement of material fact}} that is {{c3::relied upon}} by the other party. {{c4::Fraud}} adds {{c5::intentional or reckless}} misrepresentation ({{c6::scienter}}) and intent to {{c7::induce reliance}}. A contract induced by material misrepresentation or fraud is generally {{c8::voidable}} by the misled party. 2. {{c9::Duress}} occurs when a party’s assent is induced by an {{c10::improper threat}} that leaves the victim {{c11::no reasonable alternative}}. It can include {{c12::physical}}, {{c13::economic}}, or {{c14::legal}} threats. A contract made under duress is typically {{c15::voidable}} (and may be {{c16::void}} under extreme physical duress).
cards.easyContent: Misrepresentation or fraud is a defense when a party is induced to contract by a false, material statement they reasonably rely on, especially if it is intentional. Duress is a defense when a party’s assent is induced by an improper threat leaving no reasonable alternative. Both typically make the contract voidable by the victim.
cards.mediumContent: Misrepresentation is a false, material statement of fact that the other party justifiably relies on in entering the contract; fraud adds knowledge of falsity and intent to induce reliance. A contract induced by material misrepresentation or fraud is usually voidable and may be rescinded with damages. Duress occurs where an improper threat (physical, economic, or legal) leaves the victim with no reasonable alternative, and the threat actually induces assent; contracts made under duress are generally voidable, and in cases of extreme physical duress may be void.
cards.hardContent: Misrepresentation/Fraud: A contract is voidable when assent is induced by a material misrepresentation, on which the recipient justifiably relies. Fraudulent misrepresentation requires a false statement (or concealment where there is a duty to speak) of material fact, made with knowledge of its falsity or reckless disregard (scienter), with intent to induce reliance, actual and justifiable reliance, and resulting damage. The remedy often includes rescission and possibly damages. Duress: Duress is present when one party uses an improper or wrongful threat to obtain the other party’s assent and the victim has no reasonable alternative but to agree. Physical threats, wrongful economic pressure, or threats of criminal prosecution or bad faith civil process can qualify. The key is that the threat overbears the will of the victim and actually induces the agreement. A contract entered under duress is generally voidable by the victim; contracts made under extreme physical duress can be treated as void.
cards.mnemonic: Fraud and Duress both PUNCH consent: Pressure Undermines iNformed CHoice.
cards.clozeLite: {{c1::Misrepresentation}} is a false, material fact inducing {{c2::justifiable reliance}}; {{c3::fraud}} adds {{c4::knowledge of falsity and intent}}. Contracts induced are {{c5::voidable}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 012-3. Defenses – Unconscionability
cards.backPlain: Unconscionability 1. Concept - Unconscionability is a defense that allows a court to refuse to enforce all or part of a contract that is so unfair or oppressive that it would be unjust to enforce it. - It concerns both the fairness of the bargaining process and the resulting terms. 2. Types - Procedural unconscionability: Problems with the bargaining process, such as: • Oppression (e.g., unequal bargaining power, no meaningful choice); • Surprise (e.g., hidden terms, fine print, complex legalese). - Substantive unconscionability: Unfair or one-sided terms, such as: • Grossly excessive price or harsh allocation of risks; • One-sided remedies or waivers. 3. Standard - Many courts require some degree of both procedural and substantive unconscionability, though a strong showing of one can sometimes compensate for a lesser showing of the other. - The determination is typically made as of the time of contract formation, not in hindsight. 4. Effect - If a contract or clause is unconscionable, a court may: • Refuse to enforce the contract altogether; • Enforce the remainder of the contract without the unconscionable clause; or • Limit the application of the clause to avoid an unconscionable result.
cards.frontPrompt: What is unconscionability as a contract defense, what are its main types, and what remedies can a court apply if it finds a term or contract unconscionable?
cards.cloze: {{c1::Unconscionability}} allows a court to refuse to enforce a contract or clause that is so {{c2::unfair or oppressive}} that enforcement would be unjust. It has two main aspects: {{c3::procedural unconscionability}} (problems with the {{c4::bargaining process}}, like oppression or surprise) and {{c5::substantive unconscionability}} ({{c6::overly harsh or one-sided terms}}). Courts usually look for some degree of both, judged at the time of {{c7::contract formation}}. A court may {{c8::refuse to enforce}} the contract, {{c9::sever the unconscionable clause}}, or {{c10::limit its application}} to avoid an unconscionable result.
cards.easyContent: Unconscionability is a defense where the contract or a clause is so unfair in how it was made or in its terms that a court may refuse to enforce it. Courts look at both procedural unfairness (oppression or surprise) and substantive unfairness (harsh, one-sided terms).
cards.mediumContent: Unconscionability allows a court to refuse to enforce all or part of a contract that is unreasonably unfair. Procedural unconscionability focuses on defects in the bargaining process, such as oppression or surprise. Substantive unconscionability focuses on harsh, one-sided terms. Most courts require some combination of both, assessed at the time of contracting. The court can strike the clause, refuse to enforce the contract, or limit the clause to avoid an unfair result.
cards.hardContent: Unconscionability is an equitable defense that permits a court to police overly harsh bargains. Procedural unconscionability addresses the circumstances of formation—unequal bargaining power, adhesion contracts, lack of meaningful choice, or surprise caused by hidden, fine-print, or complex provisions. Substantive unconscionability examines the content of terms, such as gross price disparity, one-sided limitations of liability, or remedies that strongly favor one party. Many jurisdictions apply a sliding scale, requiring some showing of both procedural and substantive unconscionability, but a strong showing of one can offset a weaker showing of the other. The analysis is conducted as of the time of contracting. Upon finding unconscionability, a court may refuse to enforce the contract, sever the unconscionable term and enforce the rest, or limit the problematic term to avoid an unconscionable outcome.
cards.mnemonic: P-S Time: Procedural + Substantive, judged at signing time.
cards.clozeLite: Unconscionability lets a court {{c1::refuse to enforce all or part of a contract}} that is {{c2::procedurally unfair}} and {{c3::substantively harsh}}, {{c4::judged at the time of contracting}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 012-4. Defenses – Misunderstanding and Mistake
cards.backPlain: 1. Misunderstanding (Ambiguity) - Misunderstanding arises when a contract term is ambiguous and the parties attach materially different meanings to it. - Common rule structure: • If neither party knows (or has reason to know) of the other’s interpretation, and both attach different reasonable meanings to an ambiguous term, there is no contract as to that term. • If both parties know (or have reason to know) of the ambiguity, there is again typically no contract as to that term. • If only one party knows (or has reason to know) of the other’s different interpretation, the contract is interpreted in favor of the innocent party’s reasonable understanding. 2. Mistake - A mistake is a belief that is not in accord with the facts at the time of contracting. - Types: a. Mutual mistake: Both parties are mistaken about a basic assumption on which the contract was made, and the mistake materially affects the agreed exchange. b. Unilateral mistake: Only one party is mistaken about a basic assumption. - Mutual mistake: • Elements typically include: (1) both parties share a mistaken belief about a basic assumption, (2) the mistake materially affects the agreed performance or exchange, and (3) the party seeking relief did not bear the risk of mistake. • Effect: The contract is generally voidable by the adversely affected party if the elements are met. - Unilateral mistake: • Normally, a unilateral mistake does not make a contract voidable. • Exception: Relief may be granted if the non-mistaken party knew or had reason to know of the mistake, or if enforcement would be unconscionable, and the mistaken party did not bear the risk. • Effect: Under these conditions, the mistaken party may rescind or reform the contract.
cards.frontPrompt: How do misunderstanding (ambiguity) and mistake operate as defenses to contract formation or enforcement, and what are the key differences between mutual and unilateral mistake?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Misunderstanding}} occurs when an {{c2::ambiguous term}} is reasonably given {{c3::different meanings}} by the parties. If neither or both know of the ambiguity, there is generally {{c4::no contract}} as to that term; if only one knows, the contract is construed in favor of the {{c5::innocent party’s}} reasonable meaning. 2. {{c6::Mistake}} is a belief not in accord with the facts at the time of contracting. - {{c7::Mutual mistake}}: Both parties are mistaken about a {{c8::basic assumption}} that {{c9::materially affects}} the exchange, and the adversely affected party did not {{c10::bear the risk}}. The contract is usually {{c11::voidable}} by that party. - {{c12::Unilateral mistake}}: Only one party is mistaken. Relief is generally denied unless the non-mistaken party {{c13::knew or should have known}} of the mistake or enforcement would be {{c14::unconscionable}}, and the mistaken party did not bear the risk; then the contract may be {{c15::rescinded or reformed}}.
cards.easyContent: Misunderstanding happens when an ambiguous term is reasonably understood in different ways by each party. Sometimes this means there is no contract as to that term. Mistake is a wrong belief about existing facts. Mutual mistake involves both parties being wrong about a basic assumption and can make the contract voidable. Unilateral mistake involves only one party and usually gets relief only if the other side knew of the mistake or enforcement would be very unfair.
cards.mediumContent: Misunderstanding focuses on ambiguity in contract terms: if both parties reasonably interpret an ambiguous term differently and neither (or both) know of the discrepancy, there is no agreement as to that term; if only one party knows of the ambiguity, the contract is interpreted according to the innocent party’s reasonable meaning. Mistake is a wrongful belief about existing facts. Mutual mistake, when both parties are mistaken about a basic assumption that materially affects the exchange and the risk is not allocated to the party seeking relief, makes the contract voidable. Unilateral mistake, where only one party is mistaken, generally does not allow avoidance unless the other party knew or should have known of the mistake or enforcement would be unconscionable, and the mistaken party did not bear the risk.
cards.hardContent: Misunderstanding (ambiguity) is concerned with the parties’ differing, but reasonable, interpretations of an ambiguous term. If neither party knows (or has reason to know) of the other’s interpretation, or if both know or have reason to know of the ambiguity, there is no contract as to that term and potentially no contract at all if the ambiguity is central. If only one party knows of the other’s different understanding, courts typically construe the term in line with the innocent party’s reasonable interpretation. Mistake is a belief not in accord with the facts at the time of contracting. For mutual mistake, both parties share a mistaken belief about a basic assumption that materially affects the agreed exchange, and the party seeking relief must not have assumed the risk of the mistake (by contract, conscious ignorance, or otherwise). In that case, the contract is generally voidable by the adversely affected party. For unilateral mistake, only one party is mistaken; the usual rule is no relief, but exceptions allow rescission or reformation if the non-mistaken party knew or had reason to know of the mistake or if enforcement would be unconscionable, provided the mistaken party did not bear the risk of the error.
cards.mnemonic: Think A-M-M: Ambiguity → Misunderstanding; Mutual error → Mutual mistake; Mine alone → Unilateral mistake.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::misunderstanding}} involves {{c2::ambiguous terms reasonably read differently}}. {{c3::Mutual mistake}} makes a contract {{c4::voidable}} if about a {{c5::basic assumption}} and no {{c6::risk allocation}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 013-1. Incapacity – Who Lacks Capacity
cards.backPlain: Persons who lack capacity to contract include: 1. Infants (Minors) - A minor (typically under 18) generally lacks capacity to enter into binding contracts. 2. Mentally Incompetent Persons - Persons who lack the ability to understand the nature and consequences of the transaction are treated as mentally incompetent and lack capacity. 3. Intoxicated Persons (in limited circumstances) - An intoxicated person may lack capacity to contract if: a. The intoxication is such that the person cannot understand the nature and consequences of the transaction, and b. The other party has reason to know of the intoxication. Contracts with these persons are generally not automatically void, but are typically voidable at the option of the person lacking capacity or their representative.
cards.frontPrompt: Which categories of persons lack capacity to contract, and under what condition does intoxication qualify?
cards.cloze: Persons who lack capacity to contract include: 1. {{c1::Infants (minors)}} – generally under the age of majority and lacking contractual capacity. 2. {{c2::Mentally incompetent persons}} – those who cannot understand the {{c3::nature and consequences}} of the transaction. 3. {{c4::Intoxicated persons}} – but only where the intoxication prevents understanding of the {{c5::nature and consequences}} of the transaction and the {{c6::other party has reason to know}} of the intoxication. Contracts with these persons are generally {{c7::voidable}} at the option of the person lacking capacity or their representative.
cards.easyContent: Infants, mentally incompetent persons, and some intoxicated persons lack capacity to contract. Intoxication counts only if it prevents understanding and the other party has reason to know.
cards.mediumContent: Contractual incapacity covers three groups: (1) infants (minors), (2) mentally incompetent persons who cannot understand the nature and consequences of the transaction, and (3) intoxicated persons whose intoxication prevents such understanding and where the other party has reason to know. Contracts with these parties are typically voidable at the option of the incapacitated party.
cards.hardContent: Incapacity doctrine identifies categories of persons who may avoid contractual obligations. First, infants (minors) are presumed to lack capacity and therefore can typically avoid contracts they enter into. Second, mentally incompetent persons—those who lack the ability to understand the nature and consequences of the transaction—also lack capacity. Third, an intoxicated person may be treated as lacking capacity where the intoxication is severe enough to prevent understanding of the transaction and the other party has reason to know of the intoxication. In each case, any contract formed is generally voidable at the election of the incapacitated party or their guardian or representative.
cards.mnemonic: I-MI: Infants, Mentally Incompetent, and Intoxicated (if the other side knows).
cards.clozeLite: Incapacity covers {{c1::infants}}, {{c2::mentally incompetent persons}}, and {{c3::intoxicated persons}} whose {{c4::intoxication prevents understanding}} and {{c5::other party has reason to know}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 013-2. Incapacity – Right to Disaffirm
cards.backPlain: Right to Disaffirm for Persons Lacking Capacity: 1. General Rule - A person who lacked capacity to contract (such as an infant, mentally incompetent person, or qualifying intoxicated person) generally has a right to disaffirm the contract. 2. Effect of Disaffirmance - Disaffirmance renders the contract voidable at the option of the incapacitated party. - The incapacitated party may avoid contractual obligations by timely disaffirming. 3. Timing - Disaffirmance typically must occur: a. During the period of incapacity, or b. Within a reasonable time after gaining or regaining capacity (for example, after reaching majority for minors). 4. Restoration - Depending on the jurisdiction and facts, the incapacitated party may be required to return any remaining benefits or consideration still in their possession upon disaffirmance, but they are typically not liable for full performance as if the contract were fully enforceable.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the right to disaffirm for a person who lacked capacity to contract, and what is its effect on the contract?
cards.cloze: A person who {{c1::lacked capacity to contract}} (such as an infant, mentally incompetent person, or qualifying intoxicated person) generally has a {{c2::right to disaffirm}} the contract. Exercising this right renders the contract {{c3::voidable}} at the option of the incapacitated party, allowing them to {{c4::avoid contractual obligations}}. Disaffirmance must generally occur during the period of incapacity or within a {{c5::reasonable time after}} capacity is gained or regained.
cards.easyContent: Someone who lacked capacity when contracting has a right to disaffirm, making the contract voidable at their option, usually during the incapacity or within a reasonable time after regaining capacity.
cards.mediumContent: If a party lacked capacity—because they were an infant, mentally incompetent, or a qualifying intoxicated person—they can disaffirm the contract. Disaffirmance makes the contract voidable at their election, and typically must occur during the incapacity or within a reasonable time after capacity is restored. The incapacitated party may need to return remaining benefits but is not held to full contractual performance.
cards.hardContent: The right to disaffirm protects parties who lacked capacity at the time of contract formation, such as infants, mentally incompetent persons, and qualifying intoxicated persons. The incapacitated party may choose to disaffirm, rendering the agreement voidable rather than automatically void. Disaffirmance allows the party to avoid contractual duties, but usually must be exercised either while the incapacity exists or within a reasonable period after capacity is gained or restored, such as after reaching majority in the case of a minor. Upon disaffirmance, the incapacitated party may be obliged to return any remaining benefits or consideration they still possess, but they are not treated as fully bound to the contract’s terms.
cards.mnemonic: Lack Capacity? Later Cancel: contract is your choice.
cards.clozeLite: A person who {{c1::lacked capacity}} may {{c2::disaffirm the contract}}, making it {{c3::voidable at their option}} if done {{c4::during incapacity or within a reasonable time after restoration}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 013-3. Incapacity – Infancy Exception: Implied Affirmation (Ratification)
cards.backPlain: Infancy Exception – Implied Affirmation (Ratification): 1. General Rule - Although contracts entered into by infants (minors) are generally voidable at the minor’s option, a contract can be enforced against a former minor if she later ratifies it after gaining capacity. 2. Implied Affirmation (Ratification) - Ratification need not be express; it can be implied by conduct. - A contract made while a party was an infant may be enforced if, after reaching majority, the former minor behaves in a way that affirms the contract. 3. Requirements for Implied Affirmation A contract formed during infancy may be enforced against the former infant where: 1) Agreement entered into before capacity - The contract was made while the party lacked capacity (i.e., during infancy). 2) Capacity has since been gained - The party has since reached the age of majority or otherwise gained capacity. 3) Benefits have been retained - After gaining capacity, the former minor retains or continues to enjoy the benefits of the contract instead of disaffirming. 4. Effect - Once ratified (expressly or impliedly), the contract is binding on the former minor, and the right to disaffirm on grounds of infancy is lost.
cards.frontPrompt: How does the infancy exception of implied affirmation (ratification) work, and what are its elements?
cards.cloze: Infants generally have the right to disaffirm contracts, but a contract can nonetheless be {{c1::enforced against}} a former minor if there is {{c2::implied affirmation (ratification)}} after gaining capacity. Ratification can be shown where: 1) The {{c3::agreement was entered into before capacity}} (while the party was an infant); 2) The party has since {{c4::gained capacity}} (e.g., reached majority); 3) After gaining capacity, the party {{c5::retains the benefits}} of the contract rather than disaffirming. When these elements are met, the contract is considered {{c6::ratified}} and the former minor {{c7::loses the right to disaffirm}} on the basis of infancy.
cards.easyContent: A minor’s contract can become binding if, after reaching majority, the former minor ratifies it—either expressly or by keeping the benefits after gaining capacity.
cards.mediumContent: Although minors can usually disaffirm contracts, they can lose that protection through ratification. Implied affirmation occurs where the contract was made during infancy, the person later gains capacity, and then retains the contract’s benefits rather than disaffirming. That conduct ratifies the agreement and makes it enforceable against the former minor.
cards.hardContent: The infancy defense is limited by the doctrine of ratification. A contract entered while a party was an infant is normally voidable, but it can later bind the former minor through implied affirmation. The elements are: (1) the contract was formed before the party had capacity (during infancy); (2) the party subsequently gains capacity, such as by reaching the age of majority; and (3) after gaining capacity, the party retains or continues to enjoy the benefits of the contract without timely disaffirming. This post-majority conduct operates as ratification—either expressly or impliedly—and extinguishes the former minor’s right to avoid the contract on the ground of infancy.
cards.mnemonic: Ratify by R&R: Reach majority and Retain benefits.
cards.clozeLite: Implied affirmation (ratification) binds a {{c1::former minor}} when a contract made {{c2::during infancy}} is kept {{c3::after gaining capacity}} by {{c4::retaining its benefits}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 013-4. Incapacity – Infant Liability for Necessities
cards.backPlain: Infant Liability for Necessities: 1. General Rule - Although infants generally lack capacity and can disaffirm contracts, they are still liable for the reasonable value of "necessities." 2. What Counts as Necessities - Necessities typically include items essential for the minor’s health and welfare, such as: • Food • Clothing • Medical care • Possibly shelter or other essential services, depending on circumstances. 3. Basis of Liability – Quasi-Contract - Liability is based on quasi-contract (restitution), not on enforcing the contract itself. - Because there is no fully enforceable contract, the infant cannot be sued for breach of contract. - Instead, the claim is for the reasonable value of the goods or services actually provided as necessities. 4. Effect of Disaffirmance - Even if the infant disaffirms the contract, the provider of necessities may still recover the reasonable value of those necessities in quasi-contract.
cards.frontPrompt: How are infants liable for necessities despite lacking contractual capacity, and what is the basis of that liability?
cards.cloze: Infants are legally obligated to pay for {{c1::necessities}} even though they generally lack capacity to contract. Necessities typically include essentials such as {{c2::food}}, {{c3::clothing}}, and {{c4::medical care}}. This liability is based on {{c5::quasi-contract (restitution)}}, not on enforcing the contract itself, so the infant cannot be sued for {{c6::breach of contract}}. Instead, the provider may recover the {{c7::reasonable value}} of the necessities supplied, even if the infant {{c8::disaffirms}} the underlying contract.
cards.easyContent: Minors must pay for necessities like food, clothing, and medical care, not under the contract, but in quasi-contract for the reasonable value of what they received.
cards.mediumContent: Even though minors generally can disaffirm contracts, they remain liable for necessities such as food, clothing, medical care, and similar essentials. The liability arises in quasi-contract, allowing the provider to recover the reasonable value of the necessities, but the minor cannot be sued for breach of the unenforceable contract.
cards.hardContent: The infancy defense is limited by an obligation to pay for necessities. A minor who receives essentials—such as food, clothing, medical care, or similar items necessary for health and subsistence—must compensate the provider. This duty arises in quasi-contract (restitution), not from enforcement of the contract’s terms. Accordingly, the infant cannot be held liable for breach of contract, but the provider may recover the reasonable value of the benefits conferred as necessities, even if the minor disaffirms the underlying agreement.
cards.mnemonic: Minors Need Restitution, Not contractual Remedies.
cards.clozeLite: Minors are liable for {{c1::necessities}} like food and medical care in {{c2::quasi-contract}}, for the {{c3::reasonable value}} not {{c4::breach of contract}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.topic: Statute of Frauds – General Rule and Purpose
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 014-1. Statute of Frauds – General Rule and Purpose
cards.front: Statute of Frauds – General Rule and Purpose
cards.backPlain: General Rule: • Contracts subject to the Statute of Frauds require special proof of their existence. • Failure to satisfy the Statute of Frauds requirements may result in an invalid or unenforceable contract. Purpose: • The Statute of Frauds is designed to prevent fraud and perjury in the enforcement of certain important contracts by requiring reliable evidence of the agreement (usually a writing or qualifying performance).
cards.frontPrompt: What is the general rule and purpose of the Statute of Frauds, and what happens if it is not satisfied?
cards.cloze: Under the {{c1::Statute of Frauds}}, certain contracts require {{c2::special proof of their existence}}. If SoF requirements are not met, the contract may be {{c3::invalid or unenforceable}}. The purpose of the SoF is to prevent {{c4::fraud and perjury}} by requiring {{c5::reliable evidence}} of the agreement, such as a writing or qualifying performance.
cards.easyContent: Some contracts fall within the Statute of Frauds and need special proof, usually a writing or performance. If the SoF isn’t satisfied, the contract may not be enforceable.
cards.mediumContent: The Statute of Frauds applies to certain categories of contracts and demands special proof of the agreement. If a contract within the SoF lacks a proper writing or other recognized form of proof, it may be invalid or unenforceable. The doctrine’s purpose is to reduce fraud and false claims by insisting on reliable evidence of key agreements.
cards.hardContent: The Statute of Frauds is a formal requirement for certain categories of contracts. Those contracts must be supported by special proof—most commonly a writing or other recognized evidentiary substitute—showing that an agreement exists. If the SoF is not satisfied, the contract may be deemed invalid or unenforceable in court. The underlying policy is to prevent fraud and perjury in the enforcement of important or high-stakes agreements by requiring trustworthy, objective evidence of their terms and existence.
cards.mnemonic: SoF: Some contracts need Special prOof or they Fail.
cards.clozeLite: The {{c1::Statute of Frauds}} applies to certain {{c2::categories of contracts}} and requires {{c3::a writing or other special proof}} to {{c4::reduce fraud and false claims}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.topic: Statute of Frauds – Signed Writing & UCC Merchant Confirmation
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 014-2. Statute of Frauds – Signed Writing & UCC Merchant Confirmation
cards.front: Statute of Frauds – Signed Writing & Merchant Confirmation
cards.backPlain: 1. Signed Writing (common method of satisfying the SoF): • A writing containing the signature of the party to be charged (the party asserting the Statute of Frauds defense). • The writing must reasonably identify the subject matter and show that a contract has been made, usually with essential terms. 2. UCC Merchant Confirmation Between Merchants (SoF satisfied without the defendant’s signature if): 2.1 Both parties are merchants; and 2.2 The party asserting the Statute of Frauds defense received a signed writing (confirmation memo) that: • Memorializes the agreement; and • States the essential terms; and 2.3 The receiving merchant fails to respond with a written objection within 10 days of receipt. Effect: In that case, the confirmation memo satisfies the Statute of Frauds against the non-signing merchant.
cards.frontPrompt: How can the Statute of Frauds be satisfied by a signed writing, and how does the UCC merchant confirmation rule work between merchants?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Signed writing}}: • A {{c2::writing}} containing the {{c3::signature of the party to be charged}} (the party asserting the SoF defense) that reasonably identifies the subject matter and shows a contract was made. 2. {{c4::UCC merchant confirmation}} (no defendant signature needed if): • {{c5::Both parties are merchants}}; and • The party asserting the SoF defense received a {{c6::signed writing memorializing the agreement and its essential terms}}; and • That party {{c7::failed to object in writing within 10 days}} of receipt. If these elements are met, the {{c8::confirmation memo satisfies the Statute of Frauds}} against the non-signing merchant.
cards.easyContent: The Statute of Frauds is usually met by a signed writing from the party to be charged. Under the UCC, between merchants, a signed confirmation memo sent to the other merchant and not objected to within 10 days also satisfies the SoF.
cards.mediumContent: To satisfy the SoF in most cases, you need a writing signed by the party to be charged that shows a contract and its essential terms. Under the UCC, if both parties are merchants and one sends the other a signed confirmation memo that states the agreement and its essential terms, and the recipient merchant does not object in writing within 10 days, that memo satisfies the SoF even though the recipient did not sign it.
cards.hardContent: A standard method of satisfying the Statute of Frauds is a writing that is signed by the party to be charged. The writing must reasonably identify the subject matter, indicate that a contract has been made, and include the essential terms. Under the UCC’s merchant confirmation rule, the SoF may be satisfied without the defendant merchant’s signature when: (1) both parties are merchants; (2) one merchant sends the other a signed writing (confirmation memo) that memorializes the agreement and states the essential terms; and (3) the receiving merchant fails to object in writing within 10 days of receipt. In that scenario, the confirmation memo operates to satisfy the SoF against the non-signing merchant.
cards.mnemonic: For merchants, think “Memo + 10 days = bound.”
cards.clozeLite: SoF is usually met by a {{c1::signed writing by the party to be charged}}. Under the UCC, between merchants, a {{c2::signed confirmation memo}} not {{c3::objected to in writing within 10 days}} also satisfies the SoF.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 014-3. Statute of Frauds – Performance (Services & Goods)
cards.front: Statute of Frauds – Performance for Services and Goods
cards.backPlain: Performance can satisfy the Statute of Frauds in certain situations. 1. Service Contracts: • Only full performance by one party satisfies the Statute of Frauds. • Part performance of a service contract is not enough to overcome the SoF bar for the unperformed portion. 2. Sale of Goods Contracts (UCC): 2.1 Delivery and Acceptance: • Delivery and acceptance of goods by the buyer satisfies the Statute of Frauds for the goods that have been delivered and accepted. 2.2 Custom-Made (Specially Manufactured) Goods: • For custom-made goods not suitable for sale to others in the ordinary course of the seller’s business, the SoF is satisfied once the seller makes a substantial beginning toward performance (e.g., begins manufacture or makes commitments for their procurement).
cards.frontPrompt: How can performance satisfy the Statute of Frauds for service contracts and for sales of goods, including custom-made goods?
cards.cloze: Performance and the Statute of Frauds: 1. {{c1::Service contracts}}: • Only {{c2::full performance}} by one party satisfies the SoF. • {{c3::Part performance}} alone does not satisfy the SoF for the remaining unperformed portion. 2. {{c4::Sale of goods contracts (UCC)}}: 2.1 {{c5::Delivery and acceptance}}: • {{c6::Delivery and acceptance of goods}} by the buyer satisfies the SoF for the goods that have been delivered and accepted. 2.2 {{c7::Custom-made (specially manufactured) goods}}: • The SoF is satisfied once the seller makes a {{c8::substantial beginning toward performance}} (e.g., beginning manufacture or making commitments for their procurement).
cards.easyContent: Performance can sometimes replace a writing. For services, only full performance satisfies the SoF. For goods, delivery and acceptance satisfies the SoF for those goods, and for custom-made goods, a substantial beginning by the seller is enough.
cards.mediumContent: The SoF may be satisfied by performance. For service contracts, full performance by one side takes the contract out of the SoF problem, but mere part performance is not sufficient. For sales of goods, the SoF is satisfied to the extent of goods actually delivered and accepted. For specially manufactured goods that are not suitable for sale to others, the seller’s substantial beginning toward their manufacture or procurement satisfies the SoF even without a signed writing.
cards.hardContent: Performance functions as an evidentiary substitute for a writing under the Statute of Frauds in limited ways. In service contracts, only full performance by one party will satisfy the SoF; part performance alone will not make the entire oral service contract enforceable. Under the UCC, for sales of goods, the Statute of Frauds is satisfied for goods that have actually been delivered to and accepted by the buyer. In addition, for custom-made or specially manufactured goods that are not suitable for sale to others in the ordinary course of the seller’s business, the SoF is satisfied once the seller makes a substantial beginning toward performance—such as starting manufacture or making firm commitments for the goods’ procurement.
cards.mnemonic: ALL services, DELIVERED goods, CUSTOM goods need start.
cards.clozeLite: SoF can be met by {{c1::full performance for services}}, {{c2::delivery and acceptance of goods}}, and {{c3::substantial beginning on specially manufactured goods}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.topic: Statute of Frauds – Real Estate Part Performance (Two of Three)
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 014-4. Statute of Frauds – Real Estate Part Performance (Two of Three)
cards.front: Statute of Frauds – Real Estate Part Performance Test
cards.backPlain: Real Estate Contracts – Buyer’s Part Performance Exception: Part performance by the buyer can satisfy the Statute of Frauds for a real estate contract when the buyer has done two of the following three acts: 1. Full or part payment of the purchase price. 2. Taking possession of the property. 3. Making improvements to the property. If the buyer satisfies two of these three factors, most courts will enforce the oral land contract notwithstanding the lack of a signed writing, because the actions strongly indicate the existence of the agreement.
cards.frontPrompt: How can a buyer’s part performance satisfy the Statute of Frauds in a real estate contract, and what is the two-out-of-three test?
cards.cloze: In real estate contracts, the buyer’s {{c1::part performance}} can satisfy the Statute of Frauds if the buyer has done {{c2::two of the following three}} acts: 1. {{c3::Full or part payment}} of the purchase price. 2. {{c4::Possession}} of the property. 3. {{c5::Improvements}} to the property. If the buyer meets this {{c6::two-out-of-three}} test, many courts will enforce the oral land contract despite the lack of a signed writing.
cards.easyContent: For land contracts, a buyer can satisfy the Statute of Frauds without a writing by doing any two of: paying (full or part), taking possession, or making improvements to the property.
cards.mediumContent: There is a part performance exception to the SoF for land sale contracts. If the buyer does two out of three of the following—pays all or part of the price, takes possession, and makes improvements—courts will usually treat this as enough evidence of the contract and enforce the oral agreement despite the lack of a signed writing.
cards.hardContent: Real estate contracts ordinarily fall within the Statute of Frauds and require a writing. However, an equitable part performance doctrine allows enforcement of an oral land sale contract where the buyer’s conduct strongly evidences the agreement. Specifically, the SoF is satisfied when the buyer completes any two of these three acts: (1) full or part payment of the purchase price; (2) taking possession of the property; and (3) making improvements to the property. Satisfying two of these three factors is typically deemed sufficient proof to enforce the oral contract notwithstanding the absence of a formal signed writing.
cards.mnemonic: PPI land deal: Pay, Possess, Improve (any 2 of 3).
cards.clozeLite: SoF land sale part performance is met if buyer does {{c1::two of three}}: {{c2::pay price}}, {{c3::take possession}}, {{c4::make improvements}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.topic: Illegality and Public Policy as Contract Defenses
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 016-1. Illegality and Public Policy as Contract Defenses
cards.front: Illegality and Public Policy as Contract Defenses
cards.backPlain: Illegality and public policy can render a contract unenforceable. 1. In general: Illegality is a defense to contract formation or enforcement. 2. Illegal subject matter: 2.1 If the subject matter of the contract is illegal, the contract is not enforceable. 3. Legal subject matter but illegal purpose: 3.1 If the subject matter is legal but the contract is formed for an illegal purpose, the contract is only enforceable by a party who did not know of the illegal purpose. 4. Timing of legality: 4.1 Legality is judged based on the law in effect at the time of contract formation. 5. Public policy and enforcement: 5.1 Even where terms violate a public policy, a court may enforce the contract to avoid frustrating that public policy. 5.2 This is especially true where the violated policy is intended to benefit or protect the party seeking relief.
cards.frontPrompt: How do illegality and public policy operate as defenses to contract formation or enforcement?
cards.cloze: Illegality and public policy can render a contract unenforceable. 1. In general: {{c1::Illegality}} is a defense to {{c2::contract formation or enforcement}}. 2. {{c3::Illegal subject matter}}: 2.1 If the subject matter of the contract is illegal, the contract is {{c4::not enforceable}}. 3. {{c5::Legal subject matter but illegal purpose}}: 3.1 If the subject matter is legal but the contract is formed for an illegal purpose, the contract is only enforceable by a party who {{c6::did not know of the illegal purpose}}. 4. {{c7::Timing of legality}}: 4.1 Legality is judged based on the {{c8::law in effect at the time of contract formation}}. 5. {{c9::Public policy and enforcement}}: 5.1 Even where terms violate a {{c10::public policy}}, a court may enforce the contract to avoid {{c11::frustrating that public policy}}. 5.2 This is especially true where the violated policy is intended to {{c12::benefit or protect the party seeking relief}}.
cards.easyContent: A contract is generally unenforceable if its subject matter is illegal. If the subject is legal but the purpose is illegal, only an innocent party can enforce it. Legality is judged at formation, and courts consider public policy, sometimes enforcing a contract to avoid harming the very people a policy is meant to protect.
cards.mediumContent: Illegality is a defense where the contract’s subject matter is illegal, making it unenforceable. If the subject is legal but the purpose is illegal, the contract is only enforceable by a party who did not know of the illegal purpose. Legality is judged under the law in effect when the contract is formed. Courts also look to public policy and may enforce or refuse enforcement so as not to frustrate a policy designed to protect the party seeking relief.
cards.hardContent: Illegality and public policy operate as contract defenses. A contract whose subject matter is illegal is not enforceable. Where the subject matter is legal but the parties agree to an illegal purpose, the contract is generally unenforceable except that an innocent party who did not know of the illegal purpose may enforce it. Legality is assessed based on the law at the time of contract formation, not later changes. Public policy concerns can also control: a court may still enforce a contract whose terms technically violate a policy if refusing enforcement would frustrate that policy, especially where the policy is intended to protect the party now seeking relief.
cards.mnemonic: S-P-T-P: Subject, Purpose, Time, Public policy.
cards.clozeLite: A contract with {{c1::illegal subject matter}} is unenforceable; an {{c2::innocent party}} may enforce a contract with {{c3::legal subject but illegal purpose}}. Legality is judged {{c4::at formation}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 016-2. Misrepresentation (Fraud) as a Contract Defense
cards.backPlain: Misrepresentation (fraud) can make a contract voidable. 1. Definition: 1.1 Misrepresentation (fraud) consists of false assertions, concealment, or misstatements about a material fact. 1.2 It must occur before contract formation or performance. 2. Reliance and effect: 2.1 The misrepresentation must induce the other party to enter the contract. 2.2 The party must reasonably and detrimentally rely on the misrepresentation. 2.3 If these conditions are met, the contract is voidable at the option of the misled party.
cards.frontPrompt: What is misrepresentation (fraud) in contract law, and when does it make a contract voidable?
cards.cloze: Misrepresentation (fraud) can make a contract voidable. 1. Definition: 1.1 Misrepresentation (fraud) consists of {{c1::false assertions, concealment, or misstatements}} about a {{c2::material fact}}. 1.2 It must occur {{c3::before contract formation or performance}}. 2. Reliance and effect: 2.1 The misrepresentation must {{c4::induce}} the other party to enter the contract. 2.2 The party must {{c5::reasonably}} and {{c6::detrimentally rely}} on the misrepresentation. 2.3 If these conditions are met, the contract is {{c7::voidable}} at the option of the {{c8::misled party}}.
cards.easyContent: Fraud in contracts involves a material false statement, concealment, or misrepresentation that induces a party to contract. If the party reasonably relies on it to their detriment, they can void the contract.
cards.mediumContent: Misrepresentation (fraud) is a false assertion, concealment, or misstatement about a material fact made before contract formation or performance. It must induce the other party to contract, and that party must reasonably and detrimentally rely on it. When these elements are met, the contract is voidable by the misled party.
cards.hardContent: In contract law, misrepresentation (fraud) occurs when one party makes a false assertion, conceals information, or otherwise misstates a material fact prior to contract formation or performance. The misrepresentation must be material and must induce the other party to enter the contract. The misled party must reasonably and detrimentally rely on the misrepresentation. When those conditions are satisfied, the contract is voidable at the option of the misled party, who may seek rescission and, in cases of fraud, potentially damages.
cards.mnemonic: Fraud = FIRM: False, Induces, Relied, Material.
cards.clozeLite: Fraud in contracts requires a {{c1::false assertion or concealment}} of a {{c2::material fact}} that {{c3::induces contracting}} and is {{c4::reasonably and detrimentally relied on}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.topic: Undue Influence as a Contract Defense
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 016-3. Undue Influence as a Contract Defense
cards.front: Undue Influence as a Contract Defense
cards.backPlain: Undue influence can make a contract voidable. 1. Definition: 1.1 Undue influence occurs when a contract is entered into under excessive pressure. 1.2 It typically involves a party who is unduly susceptible to pressure. 2. Elements: 2.1 A susceptible party (e.g., due to weakness, dependency, or special relationship). 2.2 Excessive or overbearing pressure applied by the other party. 3. Effect: 3.1 A contract induced by undue influence is voidable at the option of the influenced (susceptible) party.
cards.frontPrompt: What is undue influence in contract law, and what is its effect on a contract?
cards.cloze: Undue influence can make a contract voidable. 1. Definition: 1.1 Undue influence occurs when a contract is entered into under {{c1::excessive pressure}}. 1.2 It typically involves a party who is {{c2::unduly susceptible to pressure}}. 2. Elements: 2.1 A {{c3::susceptible party}} (e.g., due to weakness, dependency, or special relationship). 2.2 {{c4::Excessive or overbearing pressure}} applied by the other party. 3. Effect: 3.1 A contract induced by undue influence is {{c5::voidable}} at the option of the {{c6::influenced (susceptible) party}}.
cards.easyContent: Undue influence exists when a vulnerable or susceptible person is pushed into a contract by excessive pressure. The resulting contract is voidable by the influenced party.
cards.mediumContent: Undue influence arises where one party, unduly susceptible to pressure (often because of weakness or a special relationship), enters into a contract under excessive or overbearing pressure from the other party. A contract obtained by undue influence is voidable at the option of the influenced party.
cards.hardContent: Undue influence is a contract defense that focuses on unfair persuasion rather than outright threats. It occurs when a party unduly susceptible to pressure—often because of age, dependency, or a confidential relationship—is subjected to excessive or overbearing pressure in connection with contract formation. This combination of susceptibility and excessive pressure undermines the voluntariness of assent. A contract induced by undue influence is voidable at the election of the influenced party, who may seek to rescind the agreement.
cards.mnemonic: Soft PUSH: Pressured Unduly Sways Helpless party.
cards.clozeLite: Undue influence arises when a {{c1::susceptible}} party faces {{c2::excessive or overbearing pressure}}, making the contract {{c3::voidable by the influenced party}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.topic: Duress (Physical and Non-Physical) as a Contract Defense
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 016-4. Duress (Physical and Non-Physical) as a Contract Defense
cards.front: Duress (Physical and Non-Physical) as a Contract Defense
cards.backPlain: Duress involves wrongful pressure that overcomes a party’s free will. 1. Definition: 1.1 Duress is a wrongful act or threat that overcomes a party's free will. 2. Physical duress: 2.1 Physical threats or violence used to obtain assent. 2.2 A contract induced by physical duress is void. 3. Non-physical duress (economic or other improper threats): 3.1 Non-physical wrongful acts or threats (e.g., economic duress) that overcome the party’s free will. 3.2 A contract induced by non-physical duress is voidable by the coerced or threatened party.
cards.frontPrompt: What is duress in contract law, and how do physical and non-physical duress affect contract validity?
cards.cloze: Duress involves wrongful pressure that overcomes a party’s free will. 1. Definition: 1.1 Duress is a {{c1::wrongful act or threat}} that overcomes a party's {{c2::free will}}. 2. {{c3::Physical duress}}: 2.1 Physical threats or violence used to obtain assent. 2.2 A contract induced by physical duress is {{c4::void}}. 3. {{c5::Non-physical duress}} (economic or other improper threats): 3.1 Non-physical wrongful acts or threats (e.g., economic duress) that overcome the party’s free will. 3.2 A contract induced by non-physical duress is {{c6::voidable}} by the {{c7::coerced or threatened party}}.
cards.easyContent: Duress is wrongful pressure that destroys free choice. Physical duress (like violence) makes a contract void; non-physical duress (like improper economic threats) makes it voidable by the coerced party.
cards.mediumContent: Duress requires a wrongful act or threat that overcomes a party’s free will. If physical threats or violence induce the agreement, the contract is void. If non-physical wrongful threats—such as economic duress—overcome free will, the contract is voidable at the option of the coerced or threatened party.
cards.hardContent: Duress is a contract defense that focuses on coercion. It consists of a wrongful act or threat that overcomes a party’s free will. Physical duress, such as threats of bodily harm or actual violence, renders the resulting contract void because true assent is absent. Non-physical duress, often economic or other improper threats (for example, wrongful threats to breach a contract unless additional payments are made), can also overcome free will; contracts induced by such non-physical duress are voidable at the option of the coerced or threatened party.
cards.mnemonic: P-N-V: Physical = Null, Non-physical = Voidable.
cards.clozeLite: Duress is {{c1::a wrongful act or threat}} that {{c2::overcomes a party’s free will}}; {{c3::physical duress}} makes a contract {{c4::void}}, while {{c5::non-physical duress}} makes it {{c6::voidable}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 016-5. Unconscionability as a Contract Defense
cards.backPlain: Unconscionability allows a court to refuse to enforce all or part of a contract. 1. General rule: 1.1 Courts may refuse to enforce all or part of a contract that is unfair or oppressive to one party. 1.2 The focus is on the bargaining process and/or the contract terms. 2. Procedural unconscionability (bargaining process): 2.1 Involves unfairness in how the contract was formed (e.g., high-pressure sales tactics, fine print, surprise, or lack of meaningful choice). 2.2 Look for an absence of meaningful choice by the disadvantaged party. 3. Substantive unconscionability (contract terms): 3.1 Involves overly harsh or one-sided terms. 3.2 Common examples include adhesion contracts and exculpatory clauses for intentional acts. 4. Effect: 4.1 If a court finds unconscionability, it may refuse to enforce the contract, enforce the remainder without the unconscionable term, or limit the application of an unconscionable term.
cards.frontPrompt: What is unconscionability in contract law, and how does it affect enforcement of a contract?
cards.cloze: Unconscionability allows a court to refuse to enforce all or part of a contract. 1. General rule: 1.1 Courts may refuse to enforce all or part of a contract that is {{c1::unfair or oppressive}} to one party. 1.2 The focus is on the {{c2::bargaining process}} and/or the {{c3::contract terms}}. 2. {{c4::Procedural unconscionability}} (bargaining process): 2.1 Involves unfairness in how the contract was formed (e.g., high-pressure sales tactics, fine print, surprise, or lack of meaningful choice). 2.2 Look for an {{c5::absence of meaningful choice}} by the disadvantaged party. 3. {{c6::Substantive unconscionability}} (contract terms): 3.1 Involves overly {{c7::harsh or one-sided terms}}. 3.2 Common examples include {{c8::adhesion contracts}} and {{c9::exculpatory clauses for intentional acts}}. 4. Effect: 4.1 If a court finds unconscionability, it may {{c10::refuse to enforce the contract}}, {{c11::enforce the remainder without the unconscionable term}}, or {{c12::limit the application}} of an unconscionable term.
cards.easyContent: Unconscionability lets courts refuse to enforce contracts (or terms) that are grossly unfair. It can stem from an unfair bargaining process (procedural) or from harsh, one-sided terms (substantive), often where the weaker party has no meaningful choice.
cards.mediumContent: A contract is unconscionable where it is unfair or oppressive to one party, considering both the bargaining process and the contract terms. Procedural unconscionability focuses on how the contract was formed and looks for an absence of meaningful choice. Substantive unconscionability focuses on harsh or one-sided terms, often found in adhesion contracts or exculpatory clauses for intentional acts. If a court finds unconscionability, it may refuse to enforce the contract, strike the offending term, or limit its application.
cards.hardContent: Unconscionability is an equitable defense that allows courts to deny enforcement of all or part of a contract that is unfair or oppressive to one party, in light of both the bargaining process and the resulting terms. Procedural unconscionability looks at the process of formation—such as fine print, surprise, high-pressure tactics, and especially whether the disadvantaged party had any meaningful choice. Substantive unconscionability looks at the content of the agreement, asking whether the terms are overly harsh or one-sided. Typical examples include adhesion contracts presented on a take-it-or-leave-it basis and exculpatory clauses purporting to release a party from liability for intentional acts. Upon finding unconscionability, a court may refuse to enforce the contract, enforce the remainder without the unconscionable term, or limit that term to avoid an unconscionable result.
cards.mnemonic: Unconscionable = U-P-S: Unfair, Procedural, Substantive.
