cards.clozeLite: {{c1::Unconscionability}} is an {{c2::equitable defense}} based on {{c3::procedural}} and {{c4::substantive}} unfairness that lets a court {{c5::refuse or limit enforcement}} of a contract or term.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 017-1. Misunderstanding – Ambiguity and Awareness
cards.backPlain: Misunderstanding (ambiguity concerning terms of the contract): 1. Concept: - A misunderstanding arises when a term in the contract is ambiguous and the parties attach different meanings to it. 2. Neither party aware of ambiguity: - No contract is formed unless both parties actually intended the same meaning. 3. One party aware of ambiguity: - A contract is formed. - The contract is enforced according to the intention of the unaware party. - Example: If A knows B misunderstands but A remains silent, the contract is enforced according to B's understanding. 4. Both parties aware of ambiguity: - No contract is formed unless both parties actually intended the same meaning.
cards.frontPrompt: How does a misunderstanding due to ambiguity affect contract formation when neither, one, or both parties are aware of the ambiguity?
cards.cloze: {{c1::Misunderstanding}} arises when a {{c2::term is ambiguous}} and the parties attach different meanings. 1. {{c3::Neither party aware of ambiguity}}: - {{c4::No contract is formed}} unless both parties actually intended the same meaning. 2. {{c5::One party aware of ambiguity}}: - {{c6::A contract is formed}}. - The contract is enforced according to the intention of the {{c7::unaware party}}. - If A knows B misunderstands but A remains silent, the contract is enforced according to {{c8::B's understanding}}. 3. {{c9::Both parties aware of ambiguity}}: - {{c10::No contract is formed}} unless both parties actually intended the same meaning.
cards.easyContent: A misunderstanding from an ambiguous term affects contract formation based on who knows about the ambiguity: if neither or both know, no contract unless they actually intended the same meaning; if only one knows, a contract is formed and enforced according to the innocent party's meaning.
cards.mediumContent: Misunderstanding occurs when contract language is ambiguous and the parties attach different meanings. If neither or both parties are aware of the ambiguity, no contract is formed unless they actually intended the same meaning. If only one party is aware of the ambiguity, a contract is formed and it is interpreted in favor of the party who was unaware of the ambiguity.
cards.hardContent: A misunderstanding arises when an ambiguous contract term leads the parties to attach different meanings. If neither party is aware of the ambiguity, no contract is formed unless it can be shown that they actually intended the same meaning. If one party is aware of the ambiguity and the other is not, a contract is formed and the contract is enforced according to the intention of the unaware party; for example, if A knows B misunderstands but A remains silent, the contract will be enforced according to B's understanding. If both parties are aware of the ambiguity, no contract is formed unless they in fact intended the same meaning.
cards.mnemonic: AMBIG: Aware? Make it Benefit Innocent Guy.
cards.clozeLite: If {{c1::neither or both}} parties know of an ambiguity, {{c2::no contract}} unless {{c3::same intended meaning}}; if {{c4::only one knows}}, interpret for {{c5::unaware party}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 017-2. Mutual Mistake – Elements and Effect
cards.backPlain: Mutual mistake (both parties mistaken about an underlying factual assumption at the time of contract formation): 1. Definition: - Both parties are mistaken concerning the same underlying factual assumption at the time they enter into the contract. 2. Effect: - The contract is voidable by an adversely affected party if all elements are met. 3. Elements (BMA – Basic assumption, Material effect, no Assumption of risk): 3.1 Both parties are mistaken concerning a basic assumption of fact. 3.2 The mistake materially affects the agreed-upon exchange. 3.3 The adversely affected party did not assume the risk of the mistake.
cards.frontPrompt: When does a mutual mistake make a contract voidable, and what elements must be shown?
cards.cloze: {{c1::Mutual mistake}} occurs when {{c2::both parties}} are mistaken about the same underlying factual assumption at the time of contract formation. The contract is {{c3::voidable by an adversely affected party}} if: - {{c4::Both parties are mistaken}} concerning a {{c5::basic assumption of fact}}; - The mistake {{c6::materially affects}} the agreed-upon exchange; and - The adversely affected party did {{c7::not assume the risk}} of the mistake. Mnemonic: {{c8::BMA}} – Basic assumption, Material effect, no Assumption of risk.
cards.easyContent: A mutual mistake happens when both parties share a wrong basic assumption about a fact. The adversely affected party can void the contract if the mistake goes to a basic assumption, materially affects the exchange, and that party did not assume the risk.
cards.mediumContent: Mutual mistake is when both parties are mistaken about the same basic factual assumption at the time of contracting. The contract is voidable by an adversely affected party if: (1) both are mistaken about a basic assumption of fact, (2) the mistake materially affects the agreed exchange, and (3) the adversely affected party did not assume the risk of the mistake.
cards.hardContent: Mutual mistake arises where both contracting parties are mistaken about the same underlying factual assumption at the time of contract formation. In such cases, the contract is not automatically void, but it is voidable by the party who is adversely affected if three elements are satisfied: (1) both parties are mistaken concerning a basic assumption of fact underlying the contract, (2) the mistake materially affects the agreed-upon exchange, and (3) the adversely affected party did not assume the risk of the mistake by agreement, by conscious ignorance, or otherwise. This is often remembered by BMA: Basic assumption, Material effect, no Assumption of risk.
cards.mnemonic: BMA: Basic assumption, Material effect, no Assumption of risk.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::mutual mistake}} makes a contract {{c2::voidable by an adversely affected party}} if it concerns a {{c3::basic assumption}}, {{c4::materially affects the exchange}}, and the party {{c5::did not assume the risk}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 017-3. Unilateral Mistake – Rule and Exceptions
cards.backPlain: Unilateral mistake (one party mistaken concerning facts of an agreement; usually arises with computational or clerical errors): 1. Definition: - One party makes a mistake concerning a fact of the agreement, often due to a computational or clerical error, while the other party is correct. 2. General rule: - Unilateral mistake will not prevent contract formation. 3. Exception – when the mistaken party may void the contract: - The mistaken party may void the contract if: 3.1 The mistake is material; and 3.2 Either: (a) The non-mistaken party knew or should have known of the mistake; or (b) The mistake makes the contract unconscionable.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the effect of a unilateral mistake on a contract, and when may the mistaken party void the contract?
cards.cloze: {{c1::Unilateral mistake}} occurs when only {{c2::one party}} is mistaken about a fact of the agreement, often due to a {{c3::computational or clerical error}}. General rule: - Unilateral mistake will {{c4::not prevent contract formation}}. Exception – the mistaken party may {{c5::void the contract}} if: - The mistake is {{c6::material}}; and either - The {{c7::non-mistaken party}} {{c8::knew or should have known}} of the mistake; or - The mistake makes the contract {{c9::unconscionable}}.
cards.easyContent: A unilateral mistake, usually a clerical or computational error by one party, does not stop contract formation. But the mistaken party can void a material mistake if the other party knew or should have known of it, or if enforcing the contract would be unconscionable.
cards.mediumContent: Unilateral mistake occurs when only one party is mistaken about a fact of the bargain. Contracts formed under unilateral mistake are generally enforceable, but the mistaken party may rescind if the mistake is material and either the non-mistaken party knew or should have known of the error or enforcement would be unconscionable.
cards.hardContent: Unilateral mistake involves a situation in which only one contracting party is mistaken about a fact of the agreement, commonly arising from computational or clerical errors. As a default rule, such a mistake does not prevent contract formation and the contract remains enforceable. However, the mistaken party may void the contract if the mistake is material and one of two additional conditions is satisfied: (1) the non-mistaken party knew or should have known of the mistake, indicating unfair advantage or "snapping up" a known error; or (2) enforcing the bargain despite the mistake would render the contract unconscionable. In these circumstances, rescission may be available to the mistaken party.
cards.mnemonic: UNI: Unfair Knowledge or Unconscionability for rescission
cards.clozeLite: Under {{c1::unilateral mistake}}, the contract is generally {{c2::enforceable}}, but the mistaken party may {{c3::rescind}} a {{c4::material}} mistake if the other party {{c5::knew or should have known}} or enforcement is {{c6::unconscionable}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.topic: Parol Evidence Rule – Basic Rule and Integration
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 018-1. Parol Evidence Rule – Basic Rule and Integration
cards.front: Parol Evidence Rule – Basic Rule and Integration
cards.backPlain: 1. Basic Parol Evidence Rule (PER): - Under the Parol Evidence Rule, evidence that is extrinsic to a written contract is inadmissible to supplement or contradict the written contract when the writing is an integration of the parties’ agreement. 2. Integration requirement: - The writing must be intended by the parties to be a final expression of their agreement. - Complete integration: The parties intend the writing to be not only a final expression but also the complete and exclusive statement of their agreement. - Partial integration: The writing is intended as final as to the terms it contains but does not contain all terms of the agreement. 3. Merger (integration) clause: - A merger clause recites that the written contract is the complete and final agreement of the parties. - Its presence is strong evidence of integration, often of complete integration, but it is not absolutely dispositive. 4. Temporal scope of PER: - PER bars evidence of negotiations and agreements made before the contract becomes integrated, as well as contemporaneous oral agreements that would supplement or contradict the integrated writing. - PER does not bar evidence of agreements or modifications made after the integrated writing.
cards.frontPrompt: What does the Parol Evidence Rule generally prohibit, and how do integration and merger clauses affect its application?
cards.cloze: 1. Basic {{c1::Parol Evidence Rule (PER)}}: - Under PER, evidence that is {{c2::extrinsic to a written contract}} is inadmissible to supplement or contradict the written contract when the writing is an {{c3::integration}} of the parties’ agreement. 2. {{c4::Integration}} requirement: - The writing must be intended as a {{c5::final expression}} of the parties’ agreement. - {{c6::Complete integration}}: the writing is intended to be final and the {{c7::complete and exclusive}} statement of the agreement. - {{c8::Partial integration}}: the writing is final as to the terms it contains but {{c9::does not include all terms}} of the agreement. 3. {{c10::Merger (integration) clause}}: - A merger clause recites that the written contract is the {{c11::complete and final agreement}} of the parties. - It is strong evidence of {{c12::integration}} (often complete integration) but is {{c13::not dispositive}}. 4. Temporal scope of PER: - PER bars evidence of {{c14::prior negotiations and agreements}} and {{c15::contemporaneous oral agreements}} that would supplement or contradict the integrated writing. - PER does **not** bar evidence of {{c16::agreements or modifications made after}} the integrated writing.
cards.easyContent: PER makes prior and contemporaneous extrinsic evidence inadmissible to supplement or contradict a written contract that the parties intended as an integrated (final) agreement, with merger clauses being strong evidence of complete integration.
cards.mediumContent: Under the Parol Evidence Rule, extrinsic evidence of prior or contemporaneous agreements and negotiations is inadmissible to supplement or contradict a written contract that is an integration. An integration is a writing the parties intend as a final expression of their agreement. A complete integration is intended to be the complete and exclusive statement of the agreement; a partial integration is final only as to the terms it contains. A merger clause strongly suggests the writing is a complete integration, but it is not absolutely conclusive. PER bars prior and contemporaneous extrinsic evidence, but not evidence of later modifications.
cards.hardContent: The Parol Evidence Rule (PER) provides that extrinsic evidence of prior or contemporaneous agreements or negotiations is inadmissible to supplement or contradict a written contract when the writing is an integration of the parties’ agreement. An integration exists when the parties intend the writing to be the final expression of their agreement; if they also intend the writing to be the complete and exclusive statement of their terms, it is a complete integration. If the writing is final only as to the terms it includes, but other agreed terms exist outside, it is a partial integration. A merger (integration) clause, reciting that the writing is the complete and final agreement, is powerful but not absolutely dispositive evidence of complete integration. PER bars prior and contemporaneous extrinsic evidence that would alter the integrated writing but does not bar subsequent oral or written agreements or modifications.
cards.mnemonic: FPC: Final expression, Partial vs. Complete, Clause (merger).
cards.clozeLite: Under the {{c1::Parol Evidence Rule}}, extrinsic evidence of {{c2::prior or contemporaneous agreements}} is inadmissible to {{c3::supplement or contradict}} a {{c4::final integrated writing}}, with a {{c5::merger clause}} suggesting {{c6::complete integration}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.topic: Parol Evidence Rule – Common Law Exceptions
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 018-2. Parol Evidence Rule – Common Law Exceptions
cards.front: Parol Evidence Rule – Common Law Exceptions
cards.backPlain: 1. Situations where extrinsic evidence is allowed despite PER (common law): 1.1 Partial integration / separate agreement: - The contract is only partially integrated, so consistent additional terms may be admitted. - Additional terms are of a type that would naturally be in a separate agreement. 1.2 Mistake in writing (reformation): - Evidence is admissible to show a mistake in reducing the parties’ agreement to writing and to support reformation of the writing. 1.3 Misrepresentation, fraud, duress, or illegality: - PER does not bar evidence offered to show that the apparent contract is invalid or voidable due to misrepresentation, fraud, duress, or illegality. 1.4 Condition precedent to effectiveness: - Extrinsic evidence is admissible to show that a condition precedent had to occur before the written agreement would become effective. 1.5 Subsequent modifications: - PER does not apply to oral or written modifications made after the integrated writing; such later agreements are not “parol” as to that writing. 1.6 Interpretation of terms: - Extrinsic evidence is admissible to clarify the meaning the parties intended to give particular terms in the writing, especially if the terms are ambiguous. 2. Summary: PER limits prior and contemporaneous extrinsic evidence that supplements or contradicts an integrated writing, but it permits extrinsic evidence to attack validity, correct the writing, prove conditions precedent, show partial integration or separate agreements, prove later modifications, and interpret terms.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the main common law exceptions to the Parol Evidence Rule that allow admission of extrinsic evidence?
cards.cloze: 1. Situations where extrinsic evidence is allowed despite the {{c1::Parol Evidence Rule (PER)}}: 1.1 {{c2::Partial integration / separate agreement}}: - The writing is only partially integrated, so {{c3::consistent additional terms}} may be admitted. - Additional terms are of a type that would {{c4::naturally be in a separate agreement}}. 1.2 {{c5::Mistake in writing (reformation)}}: - Evidence is admissible to show a {{c6::mistake in reducing the agreement to writing}} and to support {{c7::reformation}}. 1.3 {{c8::Misrepresentation, fraud, duress, or illegality}}: - PER does not bar evidence offered to show that the contract is {{c9::invalid or voidable}} for these reasons. 1.4 {{c10::Condition precedent}} to effectiveness: - Extrinsic evidence can show that a {{c11::condition had to occur before}} the written agreement would become effective. 1.5 {{c12::Subsequent modifications}}: - PER does not apply to oral or written modifications made {{c13::after}} the integrated writing; such later agreements are not "parol" as to that writing. 1.6 {{c14::Interpretation of terms}}: - Extrinsic evidence is admissible to clarify the {{c15::meaning the parties intended to give particular terms}}, especially ambiguous ones.
cards.easyContent: Common law allows extrinsic evidence despite PER to show partial integration or separate agreements, mistake in the writing, misrepresentation/fraud/duress/illegality, conditions precedent, later modifications, and to interpret ambiguous terms.
cards.mediumContent: Even when the Parol Evidence Rule applies, common law recognizes several exceptions that admit extrinsic evidence: (1) the writing is only partially integrated, or the additional term belongs in a separate agreement; (2) a mistake occurred in reducing the agreement to writing, justifying reformation; (3) the contract is invalid or voidable due to misrepresentation, fraud, duress, or illegality; (4) an oral condition precedent was required before the writing would become effective; (5) there were subsequent oral or written modifications; and (6) extrinsic evidence is needed to interpret or clarify the meaning the parties gave to certain terms.
cards.hardContent: At common law, the Parol Evidence Rule does not bar several important categories of extrinsic evidence. First, if the writing is only partially integrated, or if the additional term is of a type that would ordinarily be in a separate agreement, consistent additional terms may be admitted. Second, extrinsic evidence is admissible to show a mistake in the process of reducing the parties’ agreement to writing and to support reformation of the document to reflect their true agreement. Third, PER does not exclude evidence of misrepresentation, fraud, duress, or illegality when offered to show that the apparent contract is invalid or voidable. Fourth, parties may introduce extrinsic evidence of a condition precedent that had to occur before the written agreement would become effective. Fifth, PER does not apply to agreements or modifications made after the integrated writing—subsequent oral or written modifications are separate transactions. Finally, extrinsic evidence is permitted to clarify or interpret the meaning the parties intended to give particular terms in the writing, especially where there is ambiguity.
cards.mnemonic: PERMCI: Partial, Error, Rotten (fraud), Maybe (condition), Change, Interpret.
cards.clozeLite: Common law PER exceptions include {{c1::partial integration/separate agreement terms}}, {{c2::mistake and reformation}}, {{c3::fraud, duress, misrepresentation, or illegality}}, {{c4::oral conditions precedent}}, {{c5::subsequent modifications}}, and {{c6::interpretation of ambiguous terms}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.topic: Parol Evidence Rule – UCC Course of Dealing, Performance, and Usage
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 018-3. Parol Evidence Rule – UCC Course of Dealing, Performance, and Usage
cards.front: Parol Evidence Rule – UCC Course of Dealing, Performance, and Usage
cards.backPlain: 1. UCC approach to PER: - Under the UCC, a written contract’s terms may be explained or supplemented by certain types of extrinsic evidence even when the writing is an integration. 2. Course of dealing, course of performance, and usage of trade: - Course of dealing: A sequence of previous conduct between the parties that establishes a common basis of understanding. - Course of performance: A sequence of conduct between the parties in performing the current contract that shows how they interpret its terms. - Usage of trade: Any practice or method of dealing having such regularity of observance in a place, vocation, or trade as to justify an expectation that it will be observed. 3. Effect of these evidentiary sources: - These forms of extrinsic evidence may be used to explain or supplement the written terms of a UCC contract. - Parties’ own course of dealing or course of performance can show that their specific customs take precedence over a general usage of trade. 4. Hierarchy of terms: - Express terms of the contract generally carry greater weight than inconsistent extrinsic evidence. - When possible, express terms should be read consistently with course of dealing, course of performance, and usage of trade; only if they cannot reasonably be reconciled will express terms control.
cards.frontPrompt: How does the UCC treat parol evidence, and what roles do course of dealing, course of performance, and usage of trade play?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::UCC}} approach to PER: - Even when there is an integrated writing, its terms may be {{c2::explained or supplemented}} by certain extrinsic evidence. 2. {{c3::Course of dealing, course of performance, and usage of trade}}: - {{c4::Course of dealing}}: prior conduct between the parties that establishes a {{c5::common basis of understanding}}. - {{c6::Course of performance}}: conduct between the parties in performing the {{c7::current contract}} that shows how they interpret its terms. - {{c8::Usage of trade}}: a practice or method of dealing regularly observed in a {{c9::place, vocation, or trade}} such that parties expect it to be followed. 3. Effect: - These forms of extrinsic evidence may be used to {{c10::explain or supplement}} the written terms of a UCC contract. - The parties’ own {{c11::course of dealing or performance}} can show that their {{c12::specific customs}} take precedence over {{c13::general trade usage}}. 4. Hierarchy of terms: - {{c14::Express terms}} of the contract generally carry greater weight than inconsistent extrinsic evidence. - When possible, express terms should be {{c15::reconciled}} with course of dealing, course of performance, and usage of trade; only if they cannot reasonably be reconciled do express terms {{c16::control}}.
cards.easyContent: Under the UCC, even an integrated writing can be explained or supplemented by course of dealing, course of performance, and usage of trade, but express terms still control if they irreconcilably conflict.
cards.mediumContent: The UCC softens the traditional Parol Evidence Rule by allowing a written contract to be explained or supplemented by course of dealing, course of performance, and usage of trade. Course of dealing looks at prior conduct between the parties; course of performance focuses on how they carry out the current contract; and usage of trade looks to common practices in the relevant trade. These sources can fill gaps or clarify terms, and the parties’ specific customs can override more general trade customs. However, express terms of the contract generally prevail if they cannot reasonably be reconciled with this extrinsic evidence.
cards.hardContent: Under the UCC, an integrated writing does not exclude all extrinsic evidence. A contract’s terms may be explained or supplemented by (1) course of dealing, which examines prior conduct between the parties to establish a shared understanding; (2) course of performance, which looks at how the parties have actually performed under the current contract and thus how they interpret it; and (3) usage of trade, which considers regular practices or methods of dealing in the relevant place, vocation, or trade that parties fairly expect will govern. These sources of evidence may be used both to clarify ambiguous provisions and to fill gaps, and the parties’ particular course of dealing or performance can demonstrate customs that take precedence over general trade usage. Nevertheless, express terms of the contract generally carry greater weight, and where express terms cannot reasonably be reconciled with course of dealing, course of performance, or usage of trade, the express terms control.
cards.mnemonic: CD-CP-UT: Dealing, Performance, Trade—unless Express terms conflict.
cards.clozeLite: Under the UCC, an {{c1::integrated writing}} may be explained or supplemented by {{c2::course of dealing}}, {{c3::course of performance}}, and {{c4::usage of trade}}, but {{c5::express terms control if irreconcilable}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.topic: Risk of Loss – Shipment vs. Destination Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 019-1. Risk of Loss – Shipment vs. Destination Contracts
cards.front: Risk of Loss – Shipment vs. Destination Contracts
cards.frontPrompt: In UCC sales involving a carrier, how do shipment and destination contracts differ, and when does risk of loss pass to the buyer in each?
cards.backPlain: In UCC sales where goods are shipped by a carrier (e.g., FedEx), the type of contract determines when risk of loss passes: 1. Shipment contracts: 1.1 The seller is only obligated to ship the goods to the buyer by delivering them to a carrier. 1.2 Risk of loss passes to the buyer when the seller delivers the goods to the carrier. 1.3 If the contract is otherwise silent on shipment terms, a shipment contract is presumed if the contract requires shipment by a third-party carrier. 2. Destination contracts: 2.1 The seller is obligated to ensure the goods reach the buyer at the named destination. 2.2 Risk of loss passes to the buyer only when the buyer takes delivery at the destination.
cards.cloze: In UCC sales using a carrier, {{c1::contract type}} determines when risk of loss passes. In a {{c2::shipment contract}}, the seller is only obligated to {{c3::deliver the goods to a carrier}}, and risk of loss passes to the buyer when the seller {{c4::delivers the goods to the carrier}}. If a contract requires shipment by a third-party carrier but is silent on shipment terms, a {{c5::shipment contract is presumed}}. In a {{c6::destination contract}}, the seller must {{c7::ensure the goods reach the buyer at the named destination}}, and risk of loss passes to the buyer only when the buyer {{c8::takes delivery at the destination}}.
cards.easyContent: With a carrier, a shipment contract passes risk when the seller delivers goods to the carrier (and is presumed if carrier shipment is required and terms are silent). A destination contract passes risk only when the buyer takes delivery at the named destination.
cards.mediumContent: In UCC carrier cases, a shipment contract requires the seller only to deliver the goods to a carrier, and risk passes to the buyer when the goods are delivered to the carrier; such a shipment contract is presumed if the agreement requires shipment by a third-party carrier and is otherwise silent. In a destination contract, the seller must ensure the goods reach the buyer at the named destination, and risk passes only when the buyer takes delivery there.
cards.hardContent: Under the UCC, when goods are shipped by a carrier, risk of loss turns on whether the contract is a shipment or destination contract. In a shipment contract, the seller’s obligation is limited to placing the goods with a carrier, and risk of loss passes to the buyer at the moment the seller delivers the goods to that carrier. If the contract requires shipment by a third-party carrier and is silent on more specific shipment terms, the law presumes it is a shipment contract. In a destination contract, by contrast, the seller must see that the goods arrive at the named destination; risk of loss remains with the seller until the goods reach that destination and the buyer takes delivery there.
cards.mnemonic: SHIP: risk at Shipment to carrier; DEST: risk at Delivery at destination.
cards.clozeLite: In UCC {{c1::shipment contracts}}, risk passes when goods are {{c2::delivered to the carrier}}; in {{c3::destination contracts}}, risk passes when {{c4::buyer takes delivery at destination}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.topic: Risk of Loss – Non-Carrier Delivery (Merchant vs. Non-Merchant)
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 019-2. Risk of Loss – Non-Carrier Delivery (Merchant vs. Non-Merchant)
cards.front: Risk of Loss – Non-Carrier Delivery (Merchant vs. Non-Merchant)
cards.frontPrompt: Under the UCC, how does risk of loss pass in non-carrier sales, and how do the rules differ for merchant versus non-merchant sellers?
cards.backPlain: In UCC sales where goods are not shipped by a common carrier (non-carrier delivery), risk of loss turns on whether the seller is a merchant: 1. Merchant seller: 1.1 Risk of loss passes to the buyer when the buyer takes physical possession of the goods. 2. Non-merchant seller: 2.1 Risk of loss passes to the buyer upon tender of delivery—when the seller makes the goods available to the buyer.
cards.cloze: In non-carrier UCC sales, risk of loss depends on whether the seller is a {{c1::merchant}}. If the seller is a {{c2::merchant}}, risk of loss passes to the buyer when the buyer {{c3::takes physical possession}} of the goods. If the seller is a {{c4::non-merchant}}, risk of loss passes to the buyer upon {{c5::tender of delivery}}—when the seller {{c6::makes the goods available to the buyer}}.
cards.easyContent: Without a carrier, a merchant seller bears risk until the buyer actually takes physical possession. A non-merchant seller shifts risk when the seller tenders delivery by making the goods available.
cards.mediumContent: For non-carrier UCC sales, a merchant seller retains risk until the buyer takes physical possession of the goods; only then does risk shift. A non-merchant seller, however, shifts risk at tender of delivery—once the seller has made the goods available to the buyer, risk of loss passes, even if the buyer has not yet taken possession.
cards.hardContent: When goods are not shipped by a common carrier, the UCC distinguishes between merchant and non-merchant sellers for risk of loss allocation. A merchant seller—one who deals in goods of the kind—bears the risk of loss until the buyer actually takes physical possession of the goods; mere tender is insufficient. By contrast, a non-merchant seller shifts risk of loss upon tender of delivery: once the seller has made the goods available to the buyer at the agreed time and place, risk passes to the buyer even if the buyer has not yet picked up the goods.
cards.mnemonic: MERCHANT = Moves goods; NON-MERCHANT = Notice (tender).
cards.clozeLite: In non-carrier UCC sales, a {{c1::merchant seller}} bears risk until {{c2::buyer’s physical possession}}, while a {{c3::non-merchant seller}} shifts risk at {{c4::tender of delivery}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.topic: Risk of Loss – FOB (Free On Board) Terms
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 019-3. Risk of Loss – FOB (Free On Board) Terms
cards.front: Risk of Loss – FOB (Free On Board) Terms
cards.frontPrompt: What are FOB (Free On Board) terms under the UCC, and how do they affect where risk of loss passes to the buyer?
cards.backPlain: FOB (Free On Board) terms in UCC sales allocate risk and expense to a named location: 1. General rule: 1.1 The seller bears the risk and expense of getting the goods to the named FOB location. 1.2 Risk of loss passes to the buyer when the goods reach that named FOB location. 2. Example: 2.1 A in Akron sells goods to B in Boise. If the contract states "FOB Boise," A is responsible for getting the goods to Boise, and risk of loss passes to B when the goods reach Boise.
cards.cloze: Under the UCC, {{c1::FOB (Free On Board)}} terms allocate risk and expense to a {{c2::named location}}. The seller bears the risk and expense of getting the goods to the {{c3::named FOB location}}, and risk of loss passes to the buyer when the goods {{c4::reach that location}}. For example, if the contract states "{{c5::FOB Boise}}," the seller must get the goods to {{c6::Boise}}, and risk of loss passes to the buyer once the goods {{c7::arrive in Boise}}.
cards.easyContent: FOB terms shift risk at the named place: the seller bears risk and expense up to the FOB location, and risk passes to the buyer when the goods reach that location.
cards.mediumContent: An FOB (Free On Board) term names a place where the seller’s responsibility ends. The seller bears the risk and cost of getting the goods to the named FOB location, and risk of loss shifts to the buyer when the goods arrive there. For example, "FOB Boise" means the seller must get the goods to Boise, and risk passes at arrival in Boise.
cards.hardContent: FOB (Free On Board) terms are a standard way to allocate risk of loss and transportation costs in UCC sales. The term is followed by a specific location, and the seller bears both the expense and risk of getting the goods to that named FOB point. Once the goods reach that place, risk of loss shifts to the buyer. Thus, with a term like "FOB Boise," the seller must arrange transportation to Boise and bears any loss en route; when the goods arrive in Boise, risk of loss passes to the buyer from that point forward.
cards.mnemonic: FOB = Free On Board until the named point.
cards.clozeLite: An {{c1::FOB (Free On Board)}} term names a place where {{c2::the seller’s responsibility ends}} and {{c3::risk of loss shifts to the buyer}} when goods {{c4::arrive at the named FOB location}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.topic: Risk of Loss – Destruction Before Risk Passes and Breach
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 019-4. Risk of Loss – Destruction Before Risk Passes and Breach
cards.front: Risk of Loss – Destruction Before Risk Passes and Breach
cards.frontPrompt: Under the UCC, what happens if goods are destroyed before risk of loss passes, and how does breach (rejection or revocation) affect who bears the risk?
cards.backPlain: Under the UCC, special rules address destruction of goods before risk passes and breach situations: 1. Goods destroyed before risk of loss passes: 1.1 If goods are destroyed before risk of loss has passed to the buyer and no party is at fault, the contract is avoided—neither party is obligated to perform. 2. Breach and risk of loss: 2.1 If the buyer rightfully rejects defective goods or revokes acceptance, risk of loss does not pass to the buyer. 2.2 In that situation, risk of loss remains with the seller until the defects are cured or the buyer accepts the goods.
cards.cloze: If goods are {{c1::destroyed before risk of loss passes}} to the buyer and {{c2::no party is at fault}}, the contract is {{c3::avoided}}—neither party has a duty to perform. If the buyer {{c4::rightfully rejects defective goods}} or {{c5::revokes acceptance}}, {{c6::risk of loss does not pass to the buyer}}. Instead, risk of loss {{c7::remains with the seller}} until the defects are {{c8::cured}} or the buyer {{c9::accepts}} the goods.
cards.easyContent: If goods are destroyed before risk passes and no one is at fault, the contract is avoided. If the buyer rightfully rejects or revokes acceptance of defective goods, risk stays with the seller until cure or later acceptance.
cards.mediumContent: When goods are destroyed before risk of loss has shifted and neither party is at fault, the UCC treats the contract as avoided: neither party must perform. Separately, a buyer who rightfully rejects or revokes acceptance of defective goods does not bear the risk of loss; risk remains with the seller until the seller cures the defects or the buyer later accepts the goods.
cards.hardContent: The UCC overlays the general risk of loss rules with special provisions. If identified goods are destroyed before risk has passed to the buyer and the destruction is without fault of either party, the contract is effectively avoided: neither side is obligated to perform, and there is no duty to pay for the lost goods. In breach situations, if the buyer rightfully rejects nonconforming goods or revokes acceptance, risk of loss does not shift to the buyer; instead, it stays with the seller despite any earlier default risk rules, and remains there until the seller cures the nonconformity or the buyer subsequently accepts the goods.
cards.mnemonic: No fault + no risk yet = contract gone; Buyer rejects/revokes = seller keeps the risk.
cards.clozeLite: If {{c1::identified goods are destroyed}} before {{c2::risk of loss passes}} and {{c3::no one is at fault}}, the {{c4::contract is avoided}}. If the buyer {{c5::rightfully rejects or revokes}}, risk stays with the {{c6::seller}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 020-1. Warranties – Express Warranties
cards.backPlain: 1. Definition of express warranty: 1.1 An express warranty is any affirmation of fact, promise, description, sample, or model relating to the goods that becomes part of the basis of the bargain. 2. Creation: 2.1 Seller’s statements or representations about the goods (e.g., “waterproof to 20 feet”) create an express warranty if they are part of the basis of the bargain. 3. Breach: 3.1 An express warranty is breached if the product fails to conform to the seller’s promise, description, sample, or model (i.e., it falls short of what was expressly warranted).
cards.frontPrompt: What is an express warranty under the UCC, how is it created, and when is it breached?
cards.cloze: An {{c1::express warranty}} is any {{c2::affirmation of fact, promise, description, sample, or model}} relating to the goods that becomes part of the {{c3::basis of the bargain}}. Seller’s statements or representations about the goods (e.g., “waterproof to 20 feet”) create an express warranty if they are part of the bargain. An express warranty is {{c4::breached}} if the product {{c5::fails to conform}} to the seller’s promise, description, sample, or model.
cards.easyContent: An express warranty arises when the seller makes factual statements, promises, or shows samples or models about the goods that become part of the deal, and it is breached if the goods don’t live up to those express representations.
cards.mediumContent: An express warranty under the UCC is created by any affirmation of fact, promise, description, sample, or model relating to the goods that becomes part of the basis of the bargain. These representations assure the buyer that the goods will conform. If the goods fail to conform to the seller’s statements, description, sample, or model, the seller has breached the express warranty.
cards.hardContent: An express warranty is a seller-created promise about the goods. It arises when the seller makes an affirmation of fact, promise, description, sample, or model that relates to the goods and becomes part of the basis of the bargain. Such representations need not use the word "warranty" or be in writing; it is enough that they are part of what induced the buyer to enter the contract. An express warranty is breached when the goods do not conform to the statement, description, sample, or model, such as when a product touted as “waterproof to 20 feet” leaks at a lesser depth.
cards.mnemonic: EXPRESS: Explicit Promises, Representations Establish Seller’s Safeguard.
cards.clozeLite: An {{c1::express warranty}} arises from any {{c2::affirmation of fact, promise, description, sample, or model}} that is {{c3::part of the basis of the bargain}}; it’s breached if {{c4::goods fail to conform}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 020-2. Warranties – Implied Warranty of Merchantability
cards.backPlain: 1. Who gives the warranty: 1.1 In a sale by a merchant seller who deals in goods of the kind, the seller automatically gives an implied warranty of merchantability. 2. Content of the warranty: 2.1 The implied warranty of merchantability warrants that the goods are fit for their ordinary purpose. 3. Automatic nature: 3.1 This warranty arises by operation of law in UCC sales by such merchants—no specific statements or promises are required.
cards.frontPrompt: When does the UCC implied warranty of merchantability arise, and what does it guarantee about the goods?
cards.cloze: In a sale by a {{c1::merchant seller who deals in goods of the kind}}, the seller automatically gives an {{c2::implied warranty of merchantability}}. This warranty provides that the goods are {{c3::fit for their ordinary purpose}}. It arises {{c4::by operation of law}} in UCC sales by such merchants, without the need for specific statements or promises.
cards.easyContent: A merchant who regularly sells the kind of goods at issue automatically warrants that the goods are fit for their ordinary, everyday use—this is the implied warranty of merchantability.
cards.mediumContent: Under the UCC, a merchant seller who deals in goods of the kind automatically gives an implied warranty of merchantability. This warranty guarantees that the goods are fit for their ordinary purpose. It arises by default in qualifying sales and does not require the seller to make any particular statements or promises.
cards.hardContent: The implied warranty of merchantability arises in sales of goods by a merchant who regularly deals in goods of the kind sold. It is imposed by the UCC as a default term and warrants that the goods are fit for their ordinary purpose, as well as generally meeting basic standards of quality, such as being of fair, average quality within the description and adequately contained, packaged, and labeled. Because it is implied by law, the seller need not make any express representations for this warranty to attach.
cards.mnemonic: Merchantability = merchant + ordinary use.
cards.clozeLite: Under the UCC, a {{c1::merchant seller who deals in goods of the kind}} automatically gives an {{c2::implied warranty of merchantability}} that goods are {{c3::fit for their ordinary purpose}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.topic: Warranties – Implied Warranty of Fitness for a Particular Purpose
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 020-3. Warranties – Implied Warranty of Fitness for a Particular Purpose
cards.front: Implied Warranty of Fitness for a Particular Purpose
cards.backPlain: 1. Elements for implied warranty of fitness: 1.1 The buyer has a particular (special) purpose for the goods, different from the ordinary use. 1.2 The buyer relies on the seller to select or furnish suitable goods for that purpose. 1.3 The seller has reason to know of the buyer’s particular purpose and of the buyer’s reliance on the seller. 2. Content of the warranty: 2.1 If these elements are met, the seller impliedly warrants that the goods are fit for the buyer’s particular purpose. 3. Applicability: 3.1 This warranty can arise with any seller (not only merchants), so long as the elements of purpose, reliance, and seller’s knowledge are satisfied.
cards.frontPrompt: When does the UCC implied warranty of fitness for a particular purpose arise, and what does it guarantee?
cards.cloze: The {{c1::implied warranty of fitness for a particular purpose}} arises when: (1) the buyer has a {{c2::particular (special) purpose}} for the goods; (2) the buyer {{c3::relies on the seller}} to select or furnish suitable goods; and (3) the seller has {{c4::reason to know}} of the buyer’s particular purpose and {{c5::reliance}}. When these conditions are met, the seller impliedly warrants that the goods are {{c6::fit for the buyer’s particular purpose}}, and this can apply to {{c7::any seller}}, not just merchants.
cards.easyContent: The implied warranty of fitness arises when the seller knows the buyer has a special purpose and is relying on the seller to pick suitable goods; it guarantees the goods will be fit for that particular purpose.
cards.mediumContent: An implied warranty of fitness for a particular purpose arises when three conditions are met: the buyer has a special purpose for the goods, the buyer actually relies on the seller to select or furnish suitable goods, and the seller has reason to know of both the purpose and the reliance. When these elements are present, the seller impliedly warrants that the goods will be suitable for the buyer’s particular purpose, and this warranty can arise even if the seller is not a merchant.
cards.hardContent: The implied warranty of fitness for a particular purpose protects a buyer who turns to the seller for guidance about specialized needs. It arises when (1) the buyer has a particular, non-ordinary purpose for the goods, (2) the buyer is relying on the seller’s skill or judgment to select or furnish appropriate goods, and (3) the seller has reason to know both of the buyer’s particular purpose and of the buyer’s reliance. If these conditions are met, the seller impliedly warrants that the goods are fit for that specific purpose, regardless of whether the seller is a merchant. Breach occurs when the goods do not fulfill the special purpose for which they were purchased.
cards.mnemonic: Fitness = special Purpose + Reliance + seller’s Knowledge (P + R + K).
cards.clozeLite: The {{c1::implied warranty of fitness}} arises when the buyer has a {{c2::special purpose}}, {{c3::relies on the seller}}, and the {{c4::seller has reason to know}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.topic: Warranties – Disclaimers, Remedy Limitations, and Damages
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 020-4. Warranties – Disclaimers, Remedy Limitations, and Damages
cards.front: Warranty Disclaimers, Remedy Limitations, and Damages
cards.backPlain: 1. Disclaimer of warranties: 1.1 A disclaimer limits or eliminates liability for implied warranties. 1.2 Generally, a seller cannot disclaim express warranties. 1.3 Disclaimers must be conspicuous, and to disclaim the implied warranty of merchantability, the disclaimer must mention "merchantability." 2. Limitation of remedies: 2.1 A limitation of remedy restricts the buyer’s recovery upon breach of warranty (e.g., limiting remedy to repair or replacement only). 2.2 Remedy limitations are generally valid for all warranties unless they are unconscionable or they fail of their essential purpose. 3. Damages for breach of warranty: 3.1 Damages are generally measured by the difference between the value of the goods as delivered and the value they would have had as warranted by the seller. 3.2 The buyer may also recover allowable incidental and consequential damages (subject to any valid limitations).
cards.frontPrompt: How can warranty liability be disclaimed or limited under the UCC, and what is the usual measure of damages for breach of warranty?
cards.cloze: A {{c1::disclaimer}} limits or eliminates liability for {{c2::implied warranties}}, but generally cannot disclaim {{c3::express warranties}}. Disclaimers must be {{c4::conspicuous}} and, to disclaim the implied warranty of {{c5::merchantability}}, must {{c6::mention "merchantability"}}. A {{c7::limitation of remedy}} restricts the buyer’s recovery upon breach of warranty (e.g., to {{c8::repair or replacement only}}). Remedy limitations are generally valid for all warranties unless {{c9::unconscionable}} or they {{c10::fail of their essential purpose}}. Damages for breach of warranty are usually measured by the {{c11::difference between the value of the goods as delivered and the value as warranted}}, plus allowable {{c12::incidental}} and {{c13::consequential}} damages (subject to any valid limitations).
cards.easyContent: Sellers can use conspicuous disclaimers to limit or eliminate implied (but not usually express) warranties, and can limit remedies (e.g., to repair or replacement) so long as the limits are not unconscionable and do not fail of their essential purpose. Damages typically equal value-as-warranted minus value-as-delivered, plus incidental and consequential damages.
cards.mediumContent: Under the UCC, warranty liability can be managed in two main ways: (1) disclaimers can eliminate or restrict implied warranties but generally cannot disclaim express warranties; they must be conspicuous and, to disclaim merchantability, must expressly mention "merchantability." (2) Remedy limitations can restrict the buyer’s remedies for breach (such as limiting remedies to repair or replacement), and are generally valid for all warranties unless unconscionable or they fail of their essential purpose. The standard damage measure for breach of warranty is the difference between the value of the goods as delivered and as warranted, plus incidental and consequential damages, subject to any valid limitations.
cards.hardContent: The UCC permits sellers to shape their warranty exposure. First, a disclaimer can limit or eliminate implied warranties, but it generally cannot disclaim express warranties that have already been created. Disclaimers must be conspicuous, and to effectively disclaim the implied warranty of merchantability, the disclaimer must specifically mention "merchantability." Second, a limitation of remedy controls the buyer’s available recovery upon breach of warranty—often by restricting relief to repair or replacement of defective goods. Such remedy limitations are generally enforceable for all warranties unless they are unconscionable or operate so narrowly that they fail of their essential purpose, in which case broader remedies may be available. If a warranty is breached, damages are ordinarily measured by the difference between the value of the goods as delivered and the value they would have had if as warranted. In addition, the buyer may recover incidental and consequential damages, assuming those categories of damages have not been validly limited or excluded by agreement.
cards.mnemonic: D-R-D: Disclaimers, Remedy limits, Damages (value gap + extras).
cards.clozeLite: Under the UCC, {{c1::disclaimers}} can limit {{c2::implied warranties}} (not usually express) and must be {{c3::conspicuous}} and, for merchantability, mention {{c4::"merchantability"}}. Warranty damages are {{c5::value-as-warranted minus value-as-delivered plus incidental and consequential damages}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.topic: UCC Acceptance of Goods – Definition and Modes
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 022-1. UCC Acceptance of Goods – Definition and Modes
cards.front: UCC Acceptance of Goods – Definition and Modes
cards.backPlain: 1. Acceptance of goods (UCC contracts – in general): 1.1 Timing: A buyer does not officially accept goods until they are delivered and the buyer has a reasonable opportunity to inspect them and/or notify the seller. 1.2 Modes of acceptance: 1.2.1 Buyer confirms acceptance: • After a reasonable opportunity to inspect the goods, the buyer indicates to the seller that the goods conform, or that she will keep them despite nonconformance. • If the buyer accepts goods, she cannot later reject them. 1.2.2 Buyer is silent (acceptance by inaction): • The buyer fails to reject or notify the seller of rejection within a reasonable time after a reasonable opportunity to inspect. 1.3 Payment and inspection: 1.3.1 Payment without an opportunity to inspect is not acceptance.
cards.frontPrompt: Under the UCC, when does a buyer accept goods, and what are the main ways acceptance can occur or not occur?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Acceptance of goods}} ({{c2::UCC}} contracts – in general): 1.1 A buyer does not officially {{c3::accept}} goods until they are {{c4::delivered}} and the buyer has a {{c5::reasonable opportunity to inspect}} them and/or notify the seller. 1.2 Modes of acceptance: 1.2.1 Buyer {{c6::confirms acceptance}}: • After a reasonable opportunity to inspect the goods, the buyer {{c7::indicates to the seller}} that the goods {{c8::conform}}, or that she will keep them despite {{c9::nonconformance}}. • If the buyer {{c10::accepts}} goods, she cannot later {{c11::reject}} them. 1.2.2 Buyer is {{c12::silent}} (acceptance by inaction): • The buyer fails to {{c13::reject or notify the seller of rejection}} within a {{c14::reasonable time}} after a reasonable opportunity to inspect. 1.3 Payment and inspection: 1.3.1 {{c15::Payment without an opportunity to inspect}} is {{c16::not acceptance}}.
cards.easyContent: Under the UCC, a buyer accepts goods only after delivery and a reasonable chance to inspect. Acceptance happens when the buyer indicates she will keep the goods (even if nonconforming) or when she fails to reject within a reasonable time; payment alone, without an opportunity to inspect, is not acceptance, and once accepted the buyer cannot later reject.
cards.mediumContent: Under the UCC, acceptance requires delivery plus a reasonable opportunity to inspect. The buyer accepts by (1) telling the seller that the goods conform or that she will keep them despite defects, or (2) remaining silent and failing to reject or notify the seller of rejection within a reasonable time after inspection. Payment without an opportunity to inspect is not acceptance, and once the buyer accepts, she cannot later reject the goods.
cards.hardContent: Under the UCC, a buyer does not accept goods until they are delivered and she has a reasonable opportunity to inspect and/or notify the seller. Acceptance may occur affirmatively when, after that reasonable opportunity to inspect, the buyer indicates to the seller that the goods conform or that she will retain them despite nonconformance. Acceptance may also occur by inaction when the buyer fails to reject or notify the seller of rejection within a reasonable time after having a reasonable opportunity to inspect. Payment by itself, when the buyer has not had a reasonable chance to inspect, does not constitute acceptance. Once goods are accepted, the buyer cannot later reject them and must instead rely on other remedies if the goods are defective.
cards.mnemonic: UCC acceptance: DIS-SIP – Delivery, Inspection, then Signal or Inaction; Payment alone isn’t acceptance.
cards.atomizationNotes: Child 1 of 2 from contracts-022: focuses on UCC acceptance of goods.
cards.clozeLite: Under the UCC, {{c1::acceptance requires delivery plus a reasonable opportunity to inspect}} and occurs if the buyer {{c2::signals she will keep the goods}} or {{c3::fails to reject within a reasonable time}}; {{c4::payment without inspection is not acceptance}} and {{c5::once accepted, goods cannot later be rejected}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.topic: UCC Revocation of Acceptance – Requirements and Grounds
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 022-2. UCC Revocation of Acceptance – Requirements and Grounds
cards.front: UCC Revocation of Acceptance – Requirements and Grounds
cards.backPlain: 2. Revoking acceptance (UCC contracts): 2.1 General rule: Once the buyer has accepted goods, she cannot later reject them. 2.2 Exception – revocation of acceptance: 2.2.1 The buyer can revoke acceptance if she discovers a defect after acceptance. 2.2.2 Timing: The buyer must revoke within a reasonable time after discovering the defect. 2.3 Substantive requirements for revocation: 2.3.1 The defect must substantially impair the goods' value to the buyer, and either: • 2.3.1.1 The buyer accepted the goods on the reasonable belief that the defect would be cured and it has not been cured, or • 2.3.1.2 The buyer was excusably ignorant of the defect at the time of acceptance or reasonably relied on the seller's assurance that the goods conformed.
cards.frontPrompt: Under the UCC, when can a buyer who has already accepted goods revoke that acceptance, and what must be shown?
cards.cloze: 2. {{c1::Revoking acceptance}} ({{c2::UCC}} contracts): 2.1 General rule: Once the buyer has {{c3::accepted}} goods, she cannot later {{c4::reject}} them. 2.2 Exception – revocation of acceptance: 2.2.1 The buyer can revoke acceptance if she {{c5::discovers a defect}} after acceptance. 2.2.2 The buyer must revoke within a {{c6::reasonable time}} after discovering the defect. 2.3 Substantive requirements: 2.3.1 The defect must {{c7::substantially impair the goods' value}} to the buyer, and either: • The buyer accepted on the {{c8::reasonable belief that the defect would be cured}} and it has not been, or • The buyer was {{c9::excusably ignorant of the defect}} at acceptance or reasonably relied on the seller's {{c10::assurance that the goods conformed}}.
cards.easyContent: Under the UCC, a buyer who has accepted goods normally cannot reject them, but she may revoke acceptance if she discovers a defect that substantially impairs the goods, revokes within a reasonable time, and either reasonably thought the defect would be cured or was excusably ignorant of it or relied on the seller’s assurance of conformity.
cards.mediumContent: Revocation of acceptance under the UCC is an exception to the rule that acceptance cuts off the right to reject. A buyer may revoke acceptance if: (1) she discovers a defect after acceptance; (2) she revokes within a reasonable time after discovery; (3) the defect substantially impairs the value of the goods; and (4) either she accepted on the reasonable belief the defect would be cured and it was not, or she was excusably ignorant of the defect or reasonably relied on the seller’s assurances that the goods conformed.
cards.hardContent: Under the UCC, once goods are accepted, the buyer ordinarily cannot reject them, but she can in limited circumstances revoke her acceptance. Revocation is available only when: (1) the buyer discovers a defect after acceptance; (2) she revokes within a reasonable time after discovering that defect; (3) the defect substantially impairs the value of the goods to her; and (4) either (a) she accepted the goods on the reasonable belief that the defect would be cured and it has not been cured, or (b) she was excusably ignorant of the defect at the time of acceptance or reasonably relied on the seller’s assurance that the goods conformed. If these requirements are met, revocation restores rights similar to rejection.
cards.mnemonic: Revocation needs DISC: Defect, Impairment, Speedy, Cure/ignorance/assurance.
cards.atomizationNotes: Child 2 of 2 from contracts-022: focuses on revocation of acceptance requirements.
cards.clozeLite: Under the UCC, a buyer may {{c1::revoke acceptance}} if a {{c2::defect is discovered after acceptance}}, {{c3::substantially impairs the value}}, and {{c4::revocation is within a reasonable time}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.topic: Conditions – Definition and Condition vs. Promise
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 026-1. Conditions – Definition and Condition vs. Promise
cards.front: Conditions – Definition and Condition vs. Promise
cards.backPlain: 1. Definition of a condition: 1.1 A condition is an agreed-upon limitation on performance in a contract. 1.2 Performance is contingent on the occurrence of some event: the conditioned duty does not arise (or is discharged) unless and until the event occurs. 1.3 Conditions are often indicated by words such as "if," "provided that," "on condition that," or similar language. 1.4 Example: A agrees to buy B's car if B gets new tires. B getting new tires is a condition of A's performance (buying the car). 2. Condition vs. promise: 2.1 Failure of a promise leads to a breach and liability for damages. 2.2 Failure of a condition relieves the party's performance obligation: the duty either never arises or is discharged. 2.3 The same provision can sometimes be characterized as a condition or a promise; characterization affects whether nonoccurrence creates a breach with damages (promise) or merely excuses performance (condition).
cards.frontPrompt: In contract law, what is a condition, how is it signaled in contract language, and how does a condition differ from a promise in terms of legal consequences?
cards.cloze: 1. Definition of a condition: 1.1 A {{c1::condition}} is an agreed-upon {{c2::limitation on performance}} in a contract. 1.2 Performance is {{c3::contingent on the occurrence of some event}}; the conditioned duty {{c4::does not arise or is discharged}} unless and until the event occurs. 1.3 Conditions are often indicated by words such as {{c5::"if," "provided that," "on condition that"}}. 1.4 Example: A agrees to buy B's car {{c6::if B gets new tires}}; B getting new tires is a {{c7::condition}} of A's performance. 2. Condition vs. promise: 2.1 Failure of a {{c8::promise}} leads to a {{c9::breach}} and {{c10::liability for damages}}. 2.2 Failure of a {{c11::condition}} {{c12::relieves the party's performance obligation}}—the duty {{c13::never arises or is discharged}}. 2.3 Characterizing a term as a {{c14::condition}} versus a {{c15::promise}} changes whether {{c16::nonoccurrence}} results in {{c17::breach with damages}} or merely {{c18::excuse of performance}}.
cards.easyContent: A condition is a contract term that makes performance dependent on an event. It’s usually signaled by words like “if” or “provided that.” If a promise is broken, that’s a breach with damages; if a condition fails, the duty tied to it doesn’t arise or is discharged.
cards.mediumContent: A condition is an agreed limit on performance that makes a duty contingent on some event, often phrased with words like “if,” “provided that,” or “on condition that.” If the event doesn’t occur, the duty conditioned on it doesn’t arise or is discharged. By contrast, a promise is a commitment whose nonperformance is a breach giving rise to damages. How a term is characterized—as a condition or a promise—determines whether nonoccurrence excuses performance or creates liability.
cards.hardContent: In contract law, a condition is an agreed-upon limitation on performance that makes a party’s duty contingent on the occurrence of some event. Contract drafters often signal conditions with language such as “if,” “provided that,” or “on condition that.” If the specified event does not occur, the performance obligation subject to the condition does not arise or is discharged. This differs from a promise: failure of a promise constitutes a breach and exposes the promisor to liability for damages. By contrast, failure of a pure condition generally relieves the obligor of any duty to perform. Because characterization matters—breach versus excuse—courts look carefully at whether contract language creates a condition, a promise, or both.
cards.mnemonic: "IF" = condition (If event, duty); broken promise = Breach & Bucks (damages).
cards.atomizationNotes: Child 1 of 3 from Contracts 026 focusing on definition and condition vs. promise.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::condition}} makes a duty {{c2::contingent on some event}} (often signaled by {{c3::“if,” “provided that,” or “on condition that”}}), while a {{c4::promise}} creates {{c5::breach-and-damages liability}} if not performed.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 026-2. Conditions – Types: Precedent vs. Subsequent
cards.backPlain: 1. Express and implied conditions: 1.1 Conditions can be express (stated in the contract) or implied (supplied by law or inferred from the parties' agreement and conduct). 2. Condition precedent: 2.1 A condition precedent is a condition that must occur before performance is due. 2.2 Non-occurrence of a condition precedent excuses the other party's performance. 2.3 Example: A agrees to buy B's car if B gets new tires; B getting new tires is a condition precedent to A's duty to buy. 3. Condition subsequent: 3.1 A condition subsequent is a condition that occurs after performance has begun and, when it occurs, excuses the duty to continue performing. 3.2 The duty exists unless and until the condition subsequent occurs, at which point the duty is discharged. 4. Practical effect: 4.1 Both conditions precedent and subsequent are mechanisms to tie performance obligations to events, but they differ in timing—before performance is due versus after it has begun and while it continues.
cards.frontPrompt: What are express and implied conditions, and how do conditions precedent differ from conditions subsequent in timing and effect on contractual duties?
cards.cloze: 1. Express and implied conditions: 1.1 Conditions can be {{c1::express}} (stated in the contract) or {{c2::implied}} (supplied by law or inferred from the agreement and conduct). 2. Condition precedent: 2.1 A {{c3::condition precedent}} must occur {{c4::before performance is due}}. 2.2 Non-occurrence of a condition precedent {{c5::excuses the other party's performance}}. 2.3 Example: A agrees to buy B's car {{c6::if B gets new tires}}; getting new tires is a {{c7::condition precedent}} to A's duty. 3. Condition subsequent: 3.1 A {{c8::condition subsequent}} occurs {{c9::after performance has begun}} and, when it occurs, {{c10::excuses the duty to continue performing}}. 3.2 The duty exists {{c11::unless and until}} the condition subsequent occurs, at which point it is {{c12::discharged}}. 4. Practical effect: 4.1 Both types tie duties to events, but differ in {{c13::timing}}—{{c14::before performance is due}} (precedent) versus {{c15::after performance has begun}} (subsequent).
cards.easyContent: Conditions can be express or implied. A condition precedent must happen before a duty is due, so if it doesn’t happen, the duty never arises. A condition subsequent happens after performance has begun and, when it occurs, it cuts off the duty going forward.
cards.mediumContent: Contract conditions may be express (written into the agreement) or implied (supplied by law or inferred). A condition precedent is an event that must occur before performance is due; if it doesn’t occur, the other party’s duty is excused. A condition subsequent is an event that occurs after performance has begun and, when it happens, terminates the duty to continue performing. Both are timing devices that tie contractual obligations to specified events.
cards.hardContent: Conditions in contracts may be express, stated directly in the contract language, or implied, supplied by law or inferred from the parties’ agreement and conduct. A condition precedent is an event that must occur before the other party’s performance obligation matures; if the event does not occur, the conditioned duty never becomes due and performance is excused. For example, if A agrees to buy B’s car if B gets new tires, B’s getting new tires is a condition precedent to A’s duty to buy. A condition subsequent, by contrast, is an event that occurs after performance has begun and, when it occurs, discharges the duty to continue performing. The duty is in force unless and until the subsequent condition happens, at which point it is terminated. Both devices tie duties to events, but differ in whether they control the initial coming due of a duty (precedent) or its continuation (subsequent).
cards.mnemonic: PREcedent = PRE-duty; SUBsequent = Stops duty later.
cards.atomizationNotes: Child 2 of 3 from Contracts 026 focusing on types of conditions—express/implied, precedent, and subsequent.
cards.clozeLite: Conditions may be {{c1::express}} or {{c2::implied}}. A {{c3::condition precedent}} must occur before duty is due; a {{c4::condition subsequent}} later {{c5::cuts off}} the duty.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 026-3. Conditions – Interpretation, Waiver, and Excuse
cards.backPlain: 1. Purpose controls interpretation: 1.1 Courts interpret conditions in light of their purpose and the parties' intent. 1.2 Substantial performance of a condition may suffice if it fulfills the condition's purpose, especially to avoid forfeiture. 1.3 If a condition is clearly designed to protect one party, it will be interpreted consistently with that protective intent. 2. Waiver and estoppel: 2.1 A party protected or benefitted by a condition may waive the condition, either expressly or by conduct inconsistent with insisting on strict compliance. 2.2 That party may also be estopped from insisting on enforcement if the other party has reasonably relied on conduct suggesting the condition would not be strictly enforced. 3. Excuse of conditions: 3.1 Conditions may be legally excused by breach or anticipatory repudiation by the party whose performance is conditioned. 3.2 A party whose performance is subject to a condition cannot wrongfully prevent or hinder the condition's occurrence; such prevention or hindrance results in excuse of the condition. 3.3 Waiver or estoppel can also operate as an excuse, treating the condition as satisfied or disregarded so that the duty remains in effect.
cards.frontPrompt: How do courts interpret conditions, when can a protected party waive a condition or be estopped from enforcing it, and under what circumstances are conditions legally excused such as by breach or prevention?
cards.cloze: 1. Purpose controls interpretation: 1.1 Courts interpret conditions in light of their {{c1::purpose}} and the parties' {{c2::intent}}. 1.2 {{c3::Substantial performance}} of a condition may suffice if it fulfills the condition's {{c4::purpose}}, particularly to avoid {{c5::forfeiture}}. 1.3 If a condition is designed to {{c6::protect one party}}, it will be interpreted consistent with that {{c7::protective intent}}. 2. Waiver and estoppel: 2.1 A party {{c8::protected or benefitted}} by a condition may {{c9::waive}} it, expressly or by {{c10::conduct inconsistent}} with insisting on strict compliance. 2.2 That party may be {{c11::estopped}} from enforcing the condition if the other party has {{c12::reasonably relied}} on conduct suggesting it would not be strictly enforced. 3. Excuse of conditions: 3.1 Conditions may be legally excused by {{c13::breach}} or {{c14::anticipatory repudiation}} by the party whose performance is conditioned. 3.2 A party whose performance is subject to a condition cannot {{c15::wrongfully prevent or hinder}} the condition's occurrence; such conduct results in {{c16::excuse of the condition}}. 3.3 {{c17::Waiver}} or {{c18::estoppel}} can also operate as an {{c19::excuse}}, treating the condition as {{c20::satisfied or disregarded}} so the duty remains.
cards.easyContent: Courts interpret conditions based on their purpose and the parties’ intent, sometimes allowing substantial performance to count if it achieves that purpose. The party the condition protects can waive it or be estopped from enforcing it if their conduct misleads the other side. Conditions can also be excused by breach, anticipatory repudiation, or wrongful prevention or hindrance of the condition’s occurrence.
cards.mediumContent: Interpretation of conditions turns on purpose and intent; courts may treat substantial performance of a condition as enough when it fulfills the condition’s purpose and avoids forfeiture, especially where the condition protects one party. The protected party can waive the condition, expressly or by conduct, and may be estopped from enforcing it if the other party reasonably relies on an apparent relaxation. Conditions may also be excused by breach or anticipatory repudiation of the party whose duty is conditioned, or by that party’s wrongful prevention or hindrance of the condition’s occurrence, in which case the condition is treated as satisfied and the duty remains.
cards.hardContent: Courts interpret conditions in light of their underlying purpose and the parties’ manifested intent, often construing them to avoid harsh forfeitures. Where the condition’s essential purpose has been met, substantial performance may satisfy the condition, particularly if strict enforcement would result in disproportionate forfeiture. When a condition is clearly designed to protect or benefit one party, courts interpret and apply it consistently with that protective function. The protected party may waive the condition—either expressly or through conduct inconsistent with insisting on strict compliance—and may also be estopped from enforcing it if the other party has reasonably relied on assurances or behavior suggesting the condition would not be rigidly applied. Conditions may be excused by breach or anticipatory repudiation by the party whose performance is conditioned, thereby allowing the other party to treat the condition as satisfied or disregarded. Additionally, a party whose performance is subject to a condition may not wrongfully prevent or hinder the condition’s occurrence; such wrongful prevention or hindrance results in excuse of the condition, and the duty is treated as if the condition occurred. Waiver and estoppel likewise operate as excuses, preventing the protected party from invoking the nonoccurrence of the condition to avoid performance.
cards.mnemonic: PWE: Purpose, Waiver/estoppel, wrongful Prevention Excuses.
cards.atomizationNotes: Child 3 of 3 from Contracts 026 focusing on interpretation, waiver/estoppel, and excuse of conditions.
cards.clozeLite: Courts interpret conditions by {{c1::purpose and intent}}, may accept {{c2::substantial performance to avoid forfeiture}}, and conditions can be {{c3::waived, estopped, or excused by breach or wrongful prevention}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 032-1. Modification – Common Law (Definition and Requirements)
cards.backPlain: 1. Definition of modification (common law) 1.1 A modification occurs when the parties make a subsequent change to the terms of an existing contract. 1.2 The parties agree to discharge the original contract terms in favor of the new terms, but a modification does not discharge the entire original contract unless expressly agreed. 2. Requirements for modification at common law 2.1 Mutual assent: There must be mutual assent of the parties to the modification. 2.2 Consideration: Generally, consideration is required, and is usually found because the parties have limited their rights under the original contract by the modification. 2.3 Modern trend exception: A modification may be enforced without new consideration if it is fair and is due to circumstances unanticipated when the contract was made.
cards.frontPrompt: Under the common law, what is a contract modification, and what are the requirements for an enforceable modification (including the modern trend)?
cards.cloze: 1. Definition of {{c1::modification}} (common law) 1.1 A modification occurs when the parties make a {{c2::subsequent change}} to the terms of an existing {{c3::contract}}. 1.2 The parties agree to discharge the {{c4::original contract terms}} in favor of the new terms, but a modification does not discharge the {{c5::entire original contract}} unless expressly agreed. 2. Requirements for modification at {{c6::common law}} 2.1 {{c7::Mutual assent}}: There must be mutual assent of the parties to the modification. 2.2 {{c8::Consideration}}: Generally required, usually found because the parties have limited their rights under the original contract by the modification. 2.3 {{c9::Modern trend}} exception: A modification may be enforced without new consideration if it is {{c10::fair}} and is due to {{c11::circumstances unanticipated when the contract was made}}.
cards.easyContent: At common law, a modification is a later change to contract terms. It normally needs mutual assent and consideration, although some courts enforce fair modifications caused by unanticipated circumstances even without new consideration.
cards.mediumContent: A modification is a subsequent change to the terms of an existing contract; the old terms are displaced by the new ones, but the contract itself remains unless the parties clearly agree to discharge it. At common law, a valid modification requires mutual assent and consideration, typically found because each party gives up some rights under the original contract. Under the modern trend, a fair modification prompted by unanticipated circumstances may be enforced without additional consideration.
cards.hardContent: At common law, a modification is a subsequent change to the terms of an existing contract: the parties agree to replace the old terms with new ones, but the contract as a whole is not discharged unless they clearly intend to extinguish it. An enforceable modification requires (1) mutual assent to the new terms and (2) consideration. Consideration is usually found because each party limits or alters its rights or obligations under the original contract. Under the modern trend, some courts will enforce a modification without new consideration if the change is fair and is driven by circumstances that were unanticipated when the original contract was made.
cards.mnemonic: Common-law modification: MA + C, or Modern Fairness.
cards.clozeLite: At common law, a {{c1::modification}} is a later change to contract terms that requires {{c2::mutual assent}} and {{c3::consideration}}, unless a {{c4::fair, unanticipated-circumstances}} change under the {{c5::modern trend}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 032-2. Modification – UCC Rules
cards.backPlain: 1. UCC modification rules 1.1 No consideration is required for a good-faith modification of a contract for the sale of goods. 1.2 A modification must be in writing if: 1.2.1 The contract as modified falls within the Statute of Frauds; or 1.2.2 The original contract requires modifications to be in writing (e.g., a no-oral-modification clause that is effective under the UCC). 1.3 Parol evidence is admissible to show subsequent modifications to a contract.
cards.frontPrompt: Under UCC Article 2, what are the requirements for a valid modification of a contract for the sale of goods, including consideration, writing, and parol evidence?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::UCC}} modification rules 1.1 No {{c2::consideration}} is required for a {{c3::good-faith modification}} of a contract for the {{c4::sale of goods}}. 1.2 A modification must be in {{c5::writing}} if: 1.2.1 The contract as modified falls within the {{c6::Statute of Frauds}}; or 1.2.2 The original contract {{c7::requires modifications to be in writing}}. 1.3 {{c8::Parol evidence}} is admissible to show {{c9::subsequent modifications}} to a contract.
cards.easyContent: Under the UCC, a good‑faith modification of a sale‑of‑goods contract needs no consideration. It must be in writing if the modified deal is within the Statute of Frauds or if the contract requires written modifications, and parol evidence can prove later modifications.
cards.mediumContent: UCC Article 2 permits good‑faith modifications of contracts for the sale of goods without new consideration. However, if the contract as modified falls within the Statute of Frauds, or if the contract includes an effective clause requiring written modifications, the modification must be in writing. Subsequent modifications can be proved by parol evidence, because they occur after integration.
cards.hardContent: Under the UCC, contracts for the sale of goods can be modified without additional consideration so long as the modification is made in good faith. Nonetheless, the Statute of Frauds still applies: if the contract as modified is within the UCC’s Statute of Frauds (for example, raises the price above $500), the modification must be in writing and signed by the party to be charged. In addition, a contract term requiring that modifications be in writing (a no‑oral‑modification clause) is generally enforceable under the UCC, so any change must comply with that clause.
