Because these changes occur after the original agreement is integrated, parol evidence is admissible to prove subsequent modifications.
cards.mnemonic: UCC MOD: Good Faith, Only Document if SOF or clause.
cards.clozeLite: Under {{c1::UCC Article 2}}, a {{c2::good-faith modification}} needs {{c3::no new consideration}} but must be {{c4::in writing}} if {{c5::SOF or a no-oral-modification clause}} applies.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 032-3. Novation – Definition, Requirements, and Effect
cards.backPlain: 1. Definition of novation 1.1 A novation is a new contract that substitutes a new party into an existing contract. 1.2 The parties agree to substitute a new party to perform; the parties create a new contract substituting a new party, who receives the benefits and assumes the duties that belonged to an original party to the contract. 2. Requirements for novation 2.1 A previous valid contract. 2.2 All parties, including the new party (or parties), agree to a new contract. 2.3 The new contract extinguishes the contractual duties between the original parties. 2.4 A new valid and enforceable contract. 3. Effect of novation 3.1 The original party is excused from performance and no longer has any contractual obligations or liabilities on the original contract.
cards.frontPrompt: What is a novation in contract law, what are its requirements, and what is its effect on the original party’s obligations and liabilities?
cards.cloze: 1. Definition of {{c1::novation}} 1.1 A novation is a {{c2::new contract}} that {{c3::substitutes a new party}} into an existing contract. 1.2 The new party receives the {{c4::benefits}} and assumes the {{c5::duties}} that belonged to an original party. 2. Requirements for novation 2.1 A previous {{c6::valid contract}}. 2.2 {{c7::All parties, including the new party, agree}} to a new contract. 2.3 The new contract {{c8::extinguishes the contractual duties between the original parties}}. 2.4 A new {{c9::valid and enforceable contract}}. 3. Effect of novation 3.1 The {{c10::original party is excused from performance}} and no longer has any contractual {{c11::obligations or liabilities}} on the original contract.
cards.easyContent: A novation is a new contract that swaps in a new party for an old one. All parties must agree, the old obligations between the original parties are extinguished, and the original party is released from further performance and liability.
cards.mediumContent: Novation occurs when the parties create a new contract that substitutes a new party for an original party. It requires: (1) a prior valid contract; (2) agreement of all parties, including the new party, to the new contract; (3) extinguishment of duties between the original parties; and (4) a new valid and enforceable contract. The effect is that the original party is fully excused from performance and has no remaining contractual liability on the old contract.
cards.hardContent: A novation is distinct from mere delegation or assignment. In a novation, the parties form a new contract that substitutes a new party into the existing contractual relationship. The new party takes over both the benefits and the burdens that previously belonged to an original party. The elements are: (1) a previous valid contract; (2) agreement of all parties—including the original parties and the new party—to the substitution and new contract; (3) an intent that the new contract extinguish the contractual duties between the original parties; and (4) a new valid and enforceable contract. The legal effect is that the original party is discharged from performance and from any further contractual obligations or liabilities under the original contract; the new party becomes solely liable going forward under the novated agreement.
cards.mnemonic: Novation: New party, New contract, No old liability.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::novation}} is a {{c2::new contract}} that {{c3::substitutes a new party}}, requires {{c4::agreement of all parties}}, and {{c5::extinguishes the original duties}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.topic: UCC Damages – Seller Breach, Buyer Keeps Goods
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 042-1. UCC Damages – Seller Breach, Buyer Keeps Goods
cards.front: UCC Damages – Seller Breach, Buyer Keeps Goods
cards.backPlain: Seller breaches and the buyer keeps the goods (depends on whether buyer accepts): 1. Non-acceptance (buyer rightfully rejects but still has the goods): • Damages = fair market value (FMV) of perfectly delivered goods − FMV of the goods actually delivered. 2. Acceptance (buyer accepts nonconforming goods): • Damages = difference in value between the goods as delivered and the goods as ordered (value-as-warranted minus value-as-delivered). 3. Superior nonconforming goods: • If the seller delivers nonconforming but superior goods, the buyer is NOT responsible for the increased value of the superior goods when computing damages.
cards.frontPrompt: Under the UCC, when the seller breaches and the buyer keeps the goods, how are damages measured for non-acceptance versus acceptance, and what if the nonconforming goods are actually superior?
cards.cloze: Seller {{c1::breaches}} and the {{c2::buyer keeps the goods}} (depends on whether buyer accepts): 1. {{c3::Non-acceptance}} (buyer rightfully rejects but still has the goods): • Damages = {{c4::fair market value (FMV) of perfectly delivered goods − FMV of the goods actually delivered}}. 2. {{c5::Acceptance}} (buyer accepts nonconforming goods): • Damages = {{c6::difference in value between the goods as delivered and the goods as ordered}} ({{c7::value-as-warranted minus value-as-delivered}}). 3. {{c8::Superior nonconforming goods}}: • If the seller delivers nonconforming but {{c9::superior goods}}, the buyer is {{c10::not responsible}} for the {{c11::increased value of the superior goods}} when computing damages.
cards.easyContent: If the seller breaches and the buyer keeps the goods, damages are the difference in value between conforming goods and what was delivered—measured either as FMV-perfect minus FMV-delivered (non-acceptance) or value-as-warranted minus value-as-delivered (acceptance). The buyer is not charged for any increased value from superior nonconforming goods.
cards.mediumContent: For a seller breach when the buyer has the goods: (1) On non-acceptance, damages equal FMV of perfectly delivered goods minus FMV of the goods actually delivered. (2) On acceptance of nonconforming goods, damages equal the difference in value between the goods as delivered and as ordered (warranted). If the nonconforming goods are superior, the buyer is not liable for the increased value in the damages calculation.
cards.hardContent: Under the UCC, when the seller breaches and the buyer keeps the goods, the measure of damages depends on the buyer's acceptance status. If the buyer rightfully rejects but still has the goods (non-acceptance), damages equal the fair market value of perfectly delivered goods minus the fair market value of the goods actually delivered. If the buyer accepts nonconforming goods, damages equal the difference in value between the goods as delivered and the goods as ordered (value-as-warranted minus value-as-delivered). Further, where the seller delivers nonconforming but superior goods, the buyer is not responsible for the increased value of the superior goods when determining damages.
cards.mnemonic: VALUE GAP: Perfect vs. Delivered; superior goods don’t help seller.
cards.clozeLite: On seller breach when {{c1::buyer keeps the goods}}: non-acceptance damages = {{c2::FMV perfect − FMV delivered}}; acceptance damages = {{c3::value-as-warranted − value-as-delivered}}; {{c4::superior goods don’t reduce damages}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.topic: UCC Damages – Seller Breach, Seller Keeps or Retakes Goods
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 042-2. UCC Damages – Seller Breach, Seller Keeps or Retakes Goods
cards.front: UCC Damages – Seller Breach, Seller Keeps or Retakes Goods
cards.backPlain: Seller breaches and the seller keeps the goods or the buyer returns them: 1. Basic rule: • Buyer's damages = the higher of: (a) FMV of the goods at the time of breach − contract price; OR (b) Buyer's costs of covering or replacing the goods − contract price. 2. Purpose: • To put the buyer in as good a position as if the seller had fully performed, rewarding efficient cover and protecting expectation.
cards.frontPrompt: Under the UCC, if the seller breaches and the seller either retains the goods or the buyer returns them, how are the buyer’s damages calculated?
cards.cloze: Seller {{c1::breaches}} and the {{c2::seller keeps the goods}} or the {{c3::buyer returns them}}: 1. Basic rule: • Buyer's damages = the {{c4::higher}} of: (a) {{c5::FMV of the goods at the time of breach − contract price}}; OR (b) {{c6::Buyer's costs of covering or replacing the goods − contract price}}. 2. Purpose: • To put the {{c7::buyer}} in as good a position as if the seller had {{c8::fully performed}}, rewarding {{c9::efficient cover}} and protecting {{c10::expectation}}.
cards.easyContent: If the seller breaches and the buyer does not end up with the goods, the buyer’s damages are the higher of: market price at breach minus contract price, or cover cost minus contract price.
cards.mediumContent: For a seller breach where the seller keeps or retakes the goods, the UCC lets the buyer recover the higher of: (1) FMV at the time of breach minus the contract price; or (2) the buyer’s cover or replacement cost minus the contract price. This protects the buyer’s expectation and encourages reasonable cover.
cards.hardContent: When the seller breaches and the seller either retains the goods or the buyer returns them, the buyer no longer has the goods and recovers based on market and cover measures. Under the UCC, the buyer’s damages are the higher of: (1) the fair market value of the goods at the time of breach minus the contract price; or (2) the buyer’s costs of covering or replacing the goods minus the contract price. This structure ensures the buyer is made whole and incentivizes the buyer to obtain substitute performance without being penalized for doing so.
cards.mnemonic: No goods? Think HIGHER of Market or Cover minus K.
cards.clozeLite: For seller breach with no goods, buyer gets the higher of {{c1::FMV at breach − contract price}} or {{c2::cover cost − contract price}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.topic: UCC Damages – Buyer Breach, Buyer Has Goods (Contract Price)
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 042-3. UCC Damages – Buyer Breach, Buyer Has Goods (Contract Price)
cards.front: UCC Damages – Buyer Breach, Buyer Has Goods (Contract Price)
cards.backPlain: Buyer breaches and the buyer has the goods: 1. Damages: • Seller's damages = contract price. 2. Situations where this arises: • Goods are kept by the buyer; OR • Goods are destroyed after risk of loss passes to the buyer; OR • Goods are returned to the seller but the seller is unable to resell them. 3. Rationale: • The seller is entitled to the full contract price when, in substance, the buyer has consumed the benefit of the goods or made resale effectively impossible.
cards.frontPrompt: Under the UCC, when a buyer breaches and still effectively has the benefit of the goods, when is the seller entitled to recover the full contract price?
cards.cloze: Buyer {{c1::breaches}} and the {{c2::buyer has the goods}}: 1. Damages: • Seller's damages = {{c3::contract price}}. 2. Situations where this arises: • Goods are {{c4::kept by the buyer}}; OR • Goods are {{c5::destroyed after risk of loss passes to the buyer}}; OR • Goods are {{c6::returned to the seller but the seller is unable to resell}} them. 3. Rationale: • The seller is entitled to the {{c7::full contract price}} when, in substance, the buyer has {{c8::consumed the benefit}} of the goods or made {{c9::resale effectively impossible}}.
cards.easyContent: If the buyer breaches and, in effect, keeps the goods or makes them unsaleable, the seller can recover the full contract price.
cards.mediumContent: For a buyer’s breach when the buyer has the goods, the UCC allows the seller to recover the contract price. This includes cases where the buyer keeps the goods, where the goods are destroyed after the risk of loss passes to the buyer, or where the buyer returns the goods but the seller cannot resell them.
cards.hardContent: Under the UCC, when the buyer breaches and the buyer has the goods in a way that deprives the seller of resale value, the seller’s damages are the contract price. This occurs when the buyer keeps the goods, when the goods are destroyed after the risk of loss has shifted to the buyer, or when the goods are physically returned but cannot be resold. Because the seller cannot mitigate through resale, the law awards the full contract price to protect the seller’s expectation interest.
cards.mnemonic: Buyer keeps, kills, or can’t resell → full price.
cards.clozeLite: If a buyer breaches and {{c1::keeps the goods}}, they are {{c2::destroyed after risk passes}}, or {{c3::cannot be resold}}, seller gets {{c4::full contract price}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.topic: UCC Damages – Buyer Breach, Seller Has Goods
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 042-4. UCC Damages – Buyer Breach, Seller Has Goods
cards.front: UCC Damages – Buyer Breach, Seller Has Goods
cards.backPlain: Buyer breaches and the seller has the goods: 1. Market damages: • Damages = contract price − market price at the time of delivery. 2. Resale and lost-profit damages: • Damages = contract price − resale price + provable lost profits. 3. Choice of measure: • The seller may use either the market-minus-contract measure or the resale-plus-lost-profits measure, depending on which better captures the loss, especially for lost-volume sellers.
cards.frontPrompt: If the buyer breaches and the seller still has the goods under the UCC, what are the seller’s main damage measures and how are they calculated?
cards.cloze: Buyer {{c1::breaches}} and the {{c2::seller has the goods}}: 1. {{c3::Market damages}}: • Damages = {{c4::contract price − market price at the time of delivery}}. 2. {{c5::Resale and lost-profit damages}}: • Damages = {{c6::contract price − resale price + provable lost profits}}. 3. Choice of measure: • The seller may use either the {{c7::market-minus-contract}} measure or the {{c8::resale-plus-lost-profits}} measure, depending on which better captures the loss, especially for {{c9::lost-volume sellers}}.
cards.easyContent: If the buyer breaches and the seller still has the goods, the seller recovers either contract-minus-market at delivery or contract-minus-resale plus lost profits.
cards.mediumContent: When a buyer breaches and the seller keeps the goods, the UCC gives the seller two main options: (1) contract price minus market price at the time of delivery; or (2) contract price minus resale price plus provable lost profits, often used by lost-volume sellers.
cards.hardContent: Under the UCC, if the buyer breaches and the seller retains the goods, the seller may recover market or resale-based damages. The seller can recover market damages measured as contract price minus the market price at the time of delivery. Alternatively, the seller can recover damages calculated as contract price minus the actual resale price, plus any provable lost profits (for example, where the seller is a lost-volume seller who would have made both the original and resale transaction). The choice of measure allows the seller to be fully compensated for the buyer’s breach.
cards.mnemonic: Buyer breach + goods with Seller: Market OR Resale+Profits.
cards.clozeLite: If buyer breaches and seller keeps goods, seller gets {{c1::contract–market at delivery}} or {{c2::contract–resale plus lost profits (lost-volume)}}.

cards.subject: Contracts
cards.topic: UCC Damages – Conversion and Additional Incidental/Consequential Damages
cards.rawHeader: Contracts 042-5. UCC Damages – Conversion and Additional Incidental/Consequential Damages
cards.front: UCC Damages – Conversion and Additional Incidental/Consequential Damages
cards.backPlain: 1. Conversion of goods: • Damages = fair market value (FMV) of the goods at the time of the conversion. 2. Additional losses for buyers and sellers in UCC sales: • Parties may also recover lost profits or damages for other losses resulting from a breach or nonconformance. • Incidental damages: reasonable expenses incurred because of the breach (e.g., inspection, transportation, care and custody of goods, costs of cover or resale). • Consequential damages (primarily for buyers): losses resulting from the seller's breach that the seller had reason to know about at the time of contracting (e.g., lost production, lost resale profits), subject to mitigation (cover where reasonable). 3. Overall principle: • These damages supplement the primary contract, market, and cover measures to fully compensate the injured party.
cards.frontPrompt: In UCC sales, how are damages for conversion measured, and what additional incidental, consequential, and lost-profit damages can buyers and sellers recover?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Conversion}} of goods: • Damages = {{c2::fair market value (FMV) of the goods at the time of the conversion}}. 2. Additional losses for buyers and sellers in UCC sales: • Parties may also recover {{c3::lost profits}} or damages for {{c4::other losses}} resulting from a breach or nonconformance. • {{c5::Incidental damages}}: reasonable expenses incurred because of the breach (e.g., {{c6::inspection, transportation, care and custody of goods, costs of cover or resale}}). • {{c7::Consequential damages}} (primarily for buyers): losses resulting from the seller's breach that the seller had {{c8::reason to know}} about at the time of contracting (e.g., {{c9::lost production, lost resale profits}}), subject to {{c10::mitigation}} ({{c11::cover}} where reasonable). 3. Overall principle: • These damages {{c12::supplement}} the primary contract, market, and cover measures to {{c13::fully compensate}} the injured party.
cards.easyContent: Conversion damages in UCC sales equal FMV of the goods at the time of conversion. On top of basic market/cover measures, buyers and sellers can also recover incidental expenses, consequential damages (mainly buyers), and lost profits caused by the breach.
cards.mediumContent: For conversion of goods in a UCC context, damages equal the FMV of the goods at the time of conversion. Beyond the primary measures of damages, parties may recover: (1) incidental damages, such as reasonable costs for inspection, transportation, care of goods, and cover/resale; and (2) consequential damages, mainly for buyers, covering foreseeable losses like lost production or resale profits, subject to mitigation obligations. Lost profits generally fall within these categories.
cards.hardContent: In UCC sales, conversion of goods is remedied by awarding the fair market value of the goods at the time of conversion. Additionally, both buyers and sellers may recover losses beyond the basic contract/market/cover formulas. Incidental damages include reasonable expenses tied to the breach, such as inspection, transportation, storage, and costs associated with cover or resale. Consequential damages, which are primarily available to buyers, compensate for further losses the seller had reason to know about at contracting—such as lost production or anticipated resale profits—so long as the buyer reasonably mitigates, often by covering. Together with lost profits, these supplemental damages aim to fully protect the injured party’s expectation interest.
cards.mnemonic: UCC conversion: FMV plus INCidental and CONsequential losses.
cards.clozeLite: For UCC {{c1::conversion of goods}}, damages equal {{c2::FMV at time of conversion}} plus {{c3::incidental}} and {{c4::consequential (incl. lost-profit)}} damages.
